[table]
[tr]
[td][b]Round length[/b][/td]
	[td]Anything between 7 and 23 minutes[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
	[td][b]Gameplay mechanics & UI[/b][/td]
	[td]★★★★★ (Phenomenal - multiple characters (currently 57) with distinct mechanics to learn and master ; loadout system makes it so that each character can be played in several different ways ; strategically deep ; interesting map designs, technically speaking, and most of them a pleasure to traverse ; UI elements are helpful and fit the experience perfectly ; great balance between teamwork and individual player agency in defining the outcome of each match ; character roster feels balanced in the way that each and every single character has either one or multiple counter picks ; straight up fun)[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
	[td][b]Visual presentation[/b][/td]
	[td]★★★☆☆ (Good - fun looking colorful maps, though lacking in finer detail ; some of the coolest, most recognizable and memorable character designs in hero shooters I've seen to date, default skins and otherwise ; does show its age overall, graphically speaking ; [i]cartoony[/i] art style not for everyone)[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
	[td][b]Sound[/b][/td]
	[td]★★★★☆ (Excellent - a plethora of funny audio quips meant to put a smile on your face, and very effective at doing so. A great detail resides in many of the characters' skins coming with their own unique banter ; proper directional sound ; catchy audio cues provide support to the UI, adding to the gameplay experience - though these could still be subject to improvement)[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
	[td][b]Gameplay loop & Variation[/b][/td]
	[td]★★★★☆ (Excellent - several game modes, although Siege seems to be the only mode available in which the players can properly experience the game's intended nature ; ranked mode available ; 14 distinct maps on Siege mode alone, 5 distinct roles that encompass 57+ characters, each with distinct playstyles and abilities, plus a weighty loadout system that allows the player to customize each character's passives and active abilities - Paladins has plenty for anyone looking to truly dive into and learn a competitive multiplayer game ; like in other hero/champion based games, the player's experience may vary drastically depending on how many and which characters they have unlocked ; pratically no waiting time between matches (casual/ranked siege mode))[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
	[td][b]Monetization[/b][/td]
	[td]★★★★☆ (Excellent - F2P with weekly character rotation ; option to buy packages that unlock champions and provide premium currency, which are a steal when on sale ; premium currency available for purchasing cosmetic items, champions and battlepasses (event passes) ; option to unlock champions through gameplay, although the grind more than justifies putting a bit of money into the game ; many free customization options unlockable through gameplay ; battlepasses available for purchase at decent price, which unlock cosmetics and misc content)[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
	[td][b]Optimization & Stability[/b][/td]
	[td]★★★☆☆ (Good - assorted bugs present in the game's menus ; minor bugs to be found during gameplay can make the game feel [i]shaky[/i] at times ; certain graphic settings seem to cause visual oddities ; occasional crashes and server lag ; outstanding optimization where frames are concerned ; very light on the system ; general polished feel when issues are absent)[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
	[td][b]Lore[/b][/td]
	[td]★★★☆☆ (Good - character backgrounds are made available in-game ; some lore regarding factions and the history of the game's universe can be found in game trailers, online through third party websites and developer streams... but not in-game, which makes for wasted potential by not telling the story through the main channel ; very interesting character interactions are implied through various means, including within the game itself, but virtually none of it adds to the experience in some capacity)[/td]
[/tr]
[/table]

[b]Overall[/b]
[b]3.7/5[/b]

1. Bunch of bugs that never get fixed
2. Terrible character balance. It's impossible to reach a perfect balance in any game, but some characters in this game just never get a proper nerf or buff.
3. Terrible queue system that encourages losses by forcing you to play with teammates way below your skill level. People who play with friends have massive advantage, almost guaranteed wins in casual. This is the most damning part of the game because the game is extremely team reliant.
Game suffers from the same problem Overwatch had, role identity.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

This Review is geared towards Overwatch players looking to swap over to this game.  

I played this game a few times a couple years back, but I always liked Overwatch 1 better as it was more polished from a visual standpoint.  However, with Overwatch 1 going away permanently at the beginning of October, and myself having a burning hatred for being forced out of a game I did pay for and into one I did not, nor do I enjoy or want (Overwatch 2).  I am forced to look at similar, alternative games.  So, I came back and gave this another shot.  

I post this review, because I figure some people will be in the same position as me about this time next month at the latest and this may be a game they hear about or come across from their own research.  i will say this, Paladins does have stuns and CC, which were a big complaint from people who could not figure out how to play around them or learn how to bait things out, etc.  However, It offers ways to limit and counter that through purchasable perks as the match progresses and as you learn champions, you learn what to prepare for going into the matches and the buy system makes you more aware of preparing for such things.  

Also, instead of three roles, you have four.  Tank, support, damage and flank.  Tank and support are very similar to what you would expect out of those roles in Overwatch but the real difference in damage and flank is how they play.  The regular damage role if lower mobility and higher output, especially good at playing with the tanks and supports and tearing down shields.  The flanks are VERY high mobility and are designed to get in the back line and take out healers fast and get back out, or to win duels with out of place, lower mobility, squishier targets and punish them for bad positioning.  At least, that is how I play them.  

I will say that if you try this out and enjoy it, it is worth the small investment to get the forever champion unlocks. However, you can play this game and unlock every champion over time for for free and never spend a penny to play it.  

Another pro I can give this game is that, for the most part, the community around it is far more positive than other communities.  I rarely see too many insults thrown around and when they are, those of us that have come from more toxic game environments can easily shut them down and make them look like clowns with a single quick wit insult from the chamber of thousands we have stored up and they have never even considered.  Really though, I don't condone soul destroying unless they start it, otherwise, be nice or at least shutup.

The level design Paladins is actually good.  I haven't actually seen a map yet that makes me want to choke a developer.  Most of them are fun and present unique challenges depending on the strengths and weaknesses of the champion or champions you choose to play and while most of the flankers constitute "dive" there is no whole team dive, which I feel like is overly broken as of Overwatch 2 sine they did remove CC mostly, which was the only real reliable counter to that.  paladins is still a team game, but individual skill still has that "carry" potential I personally missed in Overwatch because it had not been in the game for a long time IMO.
(A few heros can still carry, but they are a select few)

So, with all that said, if you are looking for a fun alternative, I recommend Paladins.  It is worth a shot and the learning curve isn't that bad.  

TIP: You can even center your HUD in the middle like Overwatch in the game settings.  (this helped me stop forgetting my ultimate existed.)

Theres a lot of good in paladins but also a lot of bad. Many of the characters feel unique and as someone who enjoys grinding towards unlocking things that aspect alone makes for lots of hours of playtime. The modes are all fun, with siege clearly being the fan favorite. However the game falls short in terms of system optimization and balancing. Many, and I mean MANY champions are either too powerful or too weak with no in between. That and the game seemingly had issues for me in terms of crashing and loading. When it works, it works well, but the stability cannot be overlooked and in my eyes should be fixed asap. Overall, I love paladins. Its an enjoyable shooter, and I love many of the different champions. I believe it has potential to blow up even, however due to the poor optimization I fear it'll become more annoying than anything. Overall, 7/10 game, and I hope it improves as time goes on.

Also I liked the rwby collab.

This game is fun...when it's working.  Funny Heroes, Straight forward maps, cool story, proper game doesn't take itself too seriously. 
But
The stability of the servers makes this game pretty unplayable for me at this point. Sometimes I queue up for NA server and get put into Europe. Had enough of being in a completely different part of the map when I died. Would love to pick this back up if they can fix the server issues.

Is the game still fun? Yes. Should you play it? Only if you can put up with its issues.

The characters are extremely solid and fun, but that's the games main offer. As amazing as the new abilities and personalities are the game can be lacking when it comes to maps and content outside of champions.

Some amazing skins are released regularly however the game never gets any new maps and rarely gets gamemodes. Why have a roster of 50+ champions if I have to play them in the same maps over and over? Not to mention that Siege is way too prevalent, I'm sick of standing around doing nothing on the payload.
On the technical side it's extremely sensitive, crashes if ANYTHING goes even remotely wrong. Internet oscilations, any input in other apps while on the loading screen and much more makes the game crash.
There's colision issues on most maps, and models often have weird hitboxes. Good luck getting headshots.
Balancing is awful and clearly biased. Champions will often dominate for years before being addressed while a dozen are neglected.

I've stopped playing Paladins for a long time ago and I recently decided to retry the game with my friend. I remember HI-rez still spamming champions updates and problems like bugs and matchmaking, aparently, the game appear to still have those problems. I really like the game even if it's community is slowly decreassing.
Conclusion:If you want a stable experience, this game is not for you. If you can embrace the chaos, it's still an amazing game.

How to Make the Perfect Hard Boiled Egg
Hard boiled eggs are great food to have on hand as their uses are so versatile. Not only are they super delicious on their own, but they’re great in sandwiches, chopped up on salads and the foundation for all devilled eggs. The trick to great hard boiled eggs is not over-cooking them, which can leave a grey ring around the yolk and make their texture a bit rubbery. 

Things You'll Need
A pot with a lid
Eggs
Water
Instructions
Step 1 Place your eggs in a single layer on the bottom of your pot and cover with cold water. The water should be about an inch or so higher than the eggs. Cover the pot with a lid.
Step 2 Over high heat, bring your eggs to a rolling boil.
Step 3 Remove from heat and let stand in water for 10-12 minutes for large eggs. Reduce the time slightly for smaller eggs, and increase the standing time for extra-large eggs.
Step 4 Drain water and immediately run cold water over eggs until cooled. Rapid cooling helps prevent a green ring from forming around the yolks.
Did you know? Nutritionally, both brown and white eggs are identical unless the hen’s feed has been enhanced.
Tips:
For easiest peeling, use eggs that have been in the refrigerator the longest. The less fresh the egg, the easier it is to peel.
To peel a hard boiled egg, crackle the shell all over by tapping the egg on a hard surface, then roll the egg between your hands to loosen the shell. Begin peeling at the large end. Hold the egg under cold running water or dip it in a bowl of water to help remove the shell.
Hard boiled eggs with the shell on and kept in a sealed container will keep for 1 week in the fridge.
To determine whether an egg is hard boiled or raw, spin it! If it spins round and round evenly, it is hard boiled. If it wobbles while spinning, it is a raw egg.

As a person who has played both Overwatch and Paladins (but admittedly more Paladins) I would say that this game is still fun in comparison to Overwatch. I see this issue appear lots between fans of both games and I personally believe that both games have their upsides and downsides. I personally love the customisation which this game has to offer, which allows every character to be played completely differently from game to game by using different talent and load-out cards and even different items! I think this adds lots of strategic depth to the game, other than just "whoever can aim the best wins." I also think it has a very diverse range of characters, which wonderfully fill the four roles in the game (damage, flank, frontline and support). Despite this, I do understand where issues arise with the game. Firstly is that there is a defined meta, which certain characters are weakened by and certain excel in. But why not just pick the best character? Well this is where the issue of character unlocking is presented, since certain characters need to be purchased using coins or gems in the game which can be either very hard or virtually impossible to gain without spending real money. This makes the game very pay to win, allowing players who spend money on the game to have an immediate advantage. This gap can be overcome with enough time in the game however, since eventually you can unlock every character you want naturally. As stated prior, at certain times there are defined metas, where certain characters may be too powerful or not powerful enough. Overall it is a very good game however... and it's completely free to play!

Having said that, the bugs are horrible. They could very well lose you an entire match, and it is frustrating. One of the most prominent ones is where you're supposed to be on you mount, but your simply stuck walking in third person. When this happens, you cannot do any damage, or use any of your abilities. It is a wild card draw as to when it corrects itself (it does, but after a long wait), and more often than not, you are killed without any means of fending for yourself. 

The Champions themselves are either wielding weapons equivalent to Sockem Boppers, or are breaking the reasonable threshold of power, and dominate the field by far. Tyra sprays blindly, tearing into the entire enemy team, while Maeve is almost impossible to spot due to her speed. The Champions should not be a use and throw tool to make money every season. that said, the gameplay is actually really great, especially when compared to OW. the variety of game modes, FREQUENT new champion releases, and character customization through item builds/card loadouts are a few things that set it apart. I am a 54-year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing Paladins.
I am a single father to my son, who is now 14. My son recently started playing this game.
In less than a week, he had already played for over 20 hours.
This was terrible for me because it was already hard enough for me to spend time with my son
because he was always out with his friends or watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam
account to play with my son. I started playing, but this was my first time playing a video game
since the 90's, so I was quite lost. I asked my son for help, and together we spent some hours playing Paladins with other people who were surprisingly kind.
I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my son since my wife had died. Playing video games
reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought
me and my son closer again, and now we actually spend time together outside the house as well.

I used to play this game when I was much younger and much worse at games. I come back today and Paladins is actually pretty fun to play at the moment mechanically. When you're zipping around as a Maeve or Koga it feels really nice, or when you absolutely crush in damage with Drogoz. 
I think where I start getting annoyed is the tanks and broken supports. The game feels the most fun when damage teams are bashing their heads against each other, otherwise characters that are fun to play are forced into a boring playstyle in order to stay alive against crowd control. 
On top of this, because of the role system it's almost impossible to win a game without all roles being filled in some capacity, which results in some people playing the less fun tanks and healers. (Although this is more of an inherent flaw with team shooters and not necessarily Paladins.) At the very least they don't force role queue. *cough*
With new characters, I respect their desire to implement more complicated and more fun characters as time goes on, but it just feels like the newer ones are steadily outclassing the old, making it so that the more linear older characters have to be buffed in their niche to absurdity in order to perform. (Drogoz doing unbelievable damage for example.)

Overall, mechanically I feel like they're going somewhere. There are many other flaws that will most likely keep new players away, like the massive pool of bugs or the questionable balance. Still a very fun casual shooter you can play while your mind wanders.

[b]TL;DR - Not a bad hero shooter. New heroes relatively frequently, but competitive is a bit dead. FOMO cosmetic model.[/b]

[b][u]Pros[/u][/b]
[i]Heroes[/i] - New heroes actually come out, unlike that other popular hero shooter. They don't mind doing things that might seem a bit silly, so most of them are fun to play. Supports and tanks in particular feel like you actually have some agency over what you do and aren't just a glorified babysitter or objective paperweight. There's 56 heroes as of writing this review. 17 damage, 14 flank, 13 tank, and 12 support.

[i]Playstyles[/i] - Paladins has a unique card system, where you can make a 5-card loadout for your heroes from a variety of cards unique to the hero. Most of them are stuff like ability duration or cooldowns, ammo, and health but some help to shape your character around a specific ability. Combine this with the three "talent" choices you get at the start of the match and it can really provide a lot of variety and flexibility. Sure, some builds might be objectively "better" than others, but almost all of them are fun.

[b][u]Cons[/u][/b]
[i]Cosmetics[/i] - FOMO heaven. See a skin, emote, or player avatar you really like? Odds are you'll never get it. Most of the monetization runs on battle-pass style stuff that can't be obtained after they end. There are a few here or there that you can purchase with gold (currency earned by playing matches or doing daily quests, slowly accumulated over time) or crystals (premium currency) but most of them are palette-swaps. 

[i]Lootboxes[/i] - Other than the battle-pass stuff, your only other option for cosmetics is to gamble on some lootboxes. Luckily there's no dupes, but some of them have massive drop pools. The three "standard" lootboxes have 676 (flair), 295 (gold), and 220 (diamond) drops as of writing this review. There's a few other themed ones with only 8-10 drops in them. For some cost analysis, the currency for lootboxes is $100/8000 currency. This is equal to 320 flair boxes, ~106 gold boxes, or a paltry ~26 diamond boxes. The themed ones vary in price, but they're usually 300-400 crystals each.

[i]Bugs[/i] - Typical Hi-Rez charm. Pretty buggy, and the one of the latest makes it so you can't hear a lot of the game sounds. This includes your own weapon sounds and enemy ultimate callouts or their weapon sounds. Can make it pretty unfun, but usually gets fixed by a restart. Usually.

[i]Competitive[/i] - Fairly dead, depending on your rank and region. Average queues are probably anywhere between 5-15 minutes. After waiting for that, there's also a decent probability someone will dodge because they're pissy that their hero of choice got banned, or they were gonna get stuck picking tank or support. Might also be a byproduct that hero pick order is in descending rank. Person in first slot who makes bans and gets to pick their hero first is the highest rank on your team, person who picks last is the lowest rank.

I remember a time when 'free' games were mostly unheard of.  A friend recommended this game to me...

I normally don't play free-to-play games, but I must say, this game gets a big thumbs up from me, even with all the bugs and such...  This game is FREE!  Pretty good quality content I must say and the game runs as smooth as butter on my dated PC.

For those complaining about the 'bugginess' let me tell you; years ago you mostly had to have very specific circumstances to play an online multiplayer game (unless you had a lot of money) and for some its still that way.

And for those complaining about the price of skins (which I agree can be a little high) 'its all in the numbers' and those of you that can't afford it, I'm sorry you weren't the target market for the price value (a company has to make their money somehow).  On the good side; for those of you that cannot afford the skins, you're still getting a quality game for FREE, and you still can unlock some skins and champions just by collecting in-game coins by playing!  That's a fair deal if you ask me!  And who knows maybe the prices will come down later on and the skins and extra content will be more accessible at a lower cost.  And as for me personally, I did spend 7.99 to get some package deal.

As far as the community goes; that's out of the game dev's hands and up to the culture of said player base.  And here's what I have to say to the player base: be fortunate you live in a time where you can get a game like this for free, I would enjoy every minute of it and try to make it as enjoyable as you can for you and your fellow teammates.  Talented people worked hard to provide you a mostly FREE experience.  And if you can't support the dev's via buying their additional content, support them by creating a positive, fun community other players want to play in.  All the best to you!

Hi all!

Don't play this game. Suck it up and pay for Overwatch.

Having played 300+ hours, this game has gotten no attention in term of fixing its fundamental flaws. This game crashes, has audio bugs which greatly inhibit the ability to respond to the situations in game, and worst of all the developers put all of their effort into new skins and collabs.

About the crashes: No F-ing idea why they happen, but more often than not, they cost the game as it can take minutes to reboot off a hard drive.

About the audio bugs: Don't you love knowing when champions are using their most powerful moves based on an audio cue? Well, be prepared because sometimes the audio cue just won't play. You will be blindsided by an ability, which on lower health champions, can actually just kill you outright. Additionally, sometimes you will load into the game and have this quirky little thing happen where your gun just doesn't have audio. Doesn't sound too bad, but it is jarring and wrecks the experience. If you want to avoid this issue, play the game with no audio from the moment you pick it up, that way you don't have to worry about it.

Finally, the skins: Some of the skins from the collaborations and events look exactly like another champion's base skin. Having played this game off and on for years, I came to identify champions quickly by their appearance. This company is greedy, and as a result it costs around $7 for a skin. Not just any skin though. You have to buy a loot crate with 7+ other skins in it meaning the skin you actually want can cost over $42. Come on!

All in all, I would say I have given this game more than a fair chance. Some of the more glaring bugs have been around for years. I bought a champion pack when I first reinstalled the game for $15. If I hadn't, I would have maybe 20 champions out of the 40+.
Find a different game, I will update this once they update their game to a more playable state.

Overwatch is an incredible achievement in multiplayer shooter design. It bobs and weaves almost perfectly between being the quick-fix adrenaline hit you might want after a long day of work, and the thoughtful, strategic multiplayer experience that becomes the center of evening-long binges with friends. It might not have the most exhaustive list of maps and modes, but it provides nearly endless opportunities for exhilarating, coordinated play, and when you’re the one at the center of it, it feels like nothing else.

Score: 9.4

Overwatch’s gameplay has remained almost entirely unchanged since launch and centres around taking and controlling points on the map or escorting payloads from one end of them to the other, all at the expense of the enemy team’s health bars. It’s a simple setup and not an altogether original one, but it’s the nuance found in how you go about winning each match that makes Overwatch so brilliant.
Each team of six can be stitched together from the current pool of 32 heroes. Not only does each play differently and bring their own tricks to the party, but they also affect the other heroes on the ever-expanding roster with each new addition. Overwatch is a game bursting with character, not least displayed in the characters themselves. Blizzard has created a world where anything goes and everything flourishes.
To call Overwatch a “shooter” almost seems reductive at this point. Yes, it’s firmly grounded in solid first-person shooting mechanics, but there’s a vast arsenal of weaponry on display, ranging from the clunkingly medieval to the clinically futuristic and even beyond science, stepping into the fantastical. At times these worlds combine to create heroes that feel like they could only be conceived in the Overwatch arena. This is exemplified best in some of the characters introduced since launch. Brigitte, with her centuries-old mace that’s partnered with an energy shield that feels airlifted from a different era of existence. The geneticist, Moira, who can summon biotic orbs from her palms and then evade all incoming damage by fading onto an ethereal plane. Then there’s Wrecking Ball, a maniacal hamster that rolls around in a spherical mech of death flanked by two chattering machine guns.

So, I've played this game a lot and for a long, long time. It's by no means a bad game, or an unplayable mess, but it's getting close. 

Let's get the basics out of the way. Paladins is a first-person hero shooter with base character builds and a simple item system, using a 5v5 objective-based format. There are four roles: Damage (deals damage, typically from the backline), Flank (confirms kills, often at much closer ranges), Frontline (holds space, for the objective or for pressure in a side lane) and Support (heals people, but often also has additional utility such as CC). Gameplay focuses a bit more on ability use and strategy over raw accuracy given the forgiving use of hit cylinders rather that hit boxes. The time to kill is relatively low for a FPS.

Now I can talk about why I can't really recommend this game:

The game's a spaghetti code mess resulting from a revolving door of devs during its early years. At the time of writing, it is almost a guarantee that game audio will completely break for one or more characters in a given match, rendering everything related to that character silent. This is by no means the reason I don't recommend Paladins, but it's a symptom. Every patch, something major breaks. The team works on it and it gets fixed almost always by next patch, but then something else breaks. I can only imagine the frustration that must cause for the people who have to try to sort this game out. As time goes on and more is added to the game, more and more larger and larger issues may come up. There are also quite often major issues with the game's servers.

I'm a firm believer in avoiding saying things like "the game is dying" because that sort of thing can feed into itself and actually increase a game's decline. What I will say is that the playerbase is small enough to cause inconsistent matchmaking at high levels (ranked and casual both). The pro scene is long gone, the competitive scene has also nearly evaporated, and what little is left (Ultra League primarily) is on hiatus due to the sound bug. Hopefully UL's back and everything's fixed when you're reading this.

Added onto this, is the general design trend for new champions: The complexity of kits is steadily increasing. Not every champion suffers from a bloated kit, but there are several who do. I like that Evil Mojo are willing to push the envelope, but it causes a lot of balancing headaches for several patches after release and a ton of frustrated headaches from the players who have to play until the patches are released. 

For example, one champion had a ~70% winrate in casuals when released, was delayed from being available in ranked by a patch due to imbalance, and had to be nerfed in three successive patches before he was in line with others in his role. Even still, he has mobility far above average for his role, excellent range for his role, solid area control options, excellent self-sustain, and passable hard CC. With all the changes (and some changes to the game itself), he is a mid-tier pick, but my point is that his position is very fragile due to the number of factors involved. Small changes to the game could drastically alter how he performs, and many other champions as well. I do actually like how they try to balance new champs to be on the stronger side to get players interested. The issue is that many of these new characters do too many things at once. Too much mobility, poke, area denial, burst, CC, etc. This includes, more frequently than before, utilities outside of a role's typical kit and abilities with no reasonable counterplay. Sometimes both at the same time.

If you're new and just want to give this game a try or you're just playing casually, go for it. This review is nitpicking pedantic garbage for the majority of players. There's definitely an uphill battle to enjoying Paladins with all the character-specific mechanics of the game and the bugs, but there is a fun game buried under all that. Sometimes it shines through, but for me that's been with increasing rarity.

I recommend this game with a pinch of salt. The gameplay is very fun, Yeah, it's a lot like overwatch, but Mojo isn't anything like Blizzard. Blizzard likes to force players into certain roles or to leap through certain hoops in the name of game balance. Mojo, on the other hand, allows more freedom- You can have teams of full healers if you like. No problem.

No role queue is a bit depressing, but it doesn't really matter. Most champs are fun to play, but unfortunately, the strongest ones are usually a bit boring, like Tyra.

The biggest issue in the game, ignoring Mojo's occasional screwups, (like currently, the sounds are bugged. Sometimes an enemy will just be totally silent. Very unfortunate.) is that the average Paladins player has room temp IQ. You will frequently match up with utterly incompetent players on your team. I don't know why. I don't know where they come from. I sometimes wonder if they're just bots. It's a huge roll of the dice, and makes some matches utterly unfun to play. You can sometimes just steamroll and be bored as you capture whatever objective, or have even less fun and get your ass kicked for ten ish minutes because you have an Androxus and Viktor who can't aim and like to run directly into the enemy.

There is a separate skill-based matchmaking, but it's a lot sweatier, and much more toxic. For simple fun, casual is just better.

Play Paladins for like, two hours. If you like it, stick to it. If you don't like it, trust me, you won't EVER like it.

Also, remember to take breaks now and then. Cheers.

As much as I love this game, the developers approach to things genuinely hurts the game.

The game is currently facing one of the worst game breaking bugs related to audio not playing on tons of abilities, ultimate voice lines, sound effects and so on.

The only thing we've got is a post on the Discord about the issue, the next patch isn't getting any delay despite the fact that releasing a new champion and skins will only add to the problem.

It feels like they're trying to brush any negativity to the game under the rug, I completely get avoiding genuine hate but this is just ridiculous that something so wide spread is being treated almost as if it's just another every day bug.

I just can't recommend the game with the current approach on handling game breaking issues like this, it shines a light on certain areas of development of this game that I don't think is positive.

The game is terrible and has been terrible since it first came out. 

The matchmaking has never been improved since its launch. I was a returning player entering from a new account, so I basically had minimal hours in the game (with that new account). Turns out, in casual mode (since ranked is stupidly locked behind a minimum requirement of 16 champions, like ok) I get matched with people carrying 500+ hours, all them high cosmetics and stuff who sometimes queue with others. They basically get put against me and other people who have just started. Don't know if Bye-Rez takes into account steam hours, but that is pretty sad.

The game is still and will probably always be a toxic hub to this day. People complaining about other players literally in the lowest of casual queues (i'm talking profiles level 5). This will unfortunately never be fixed, and the reporting function is basically useless.

Hackers. Hackers have been an issue since the first batch of them have been seen in the game. There are aimbotters, wallhackers, booters (match DDoS), you name it. They start from casual profile level 5 matches upwards to when I was in 3000 ELO back in my old account. Btw, I will add that I was part of the problem in ranked as I always played with 1 other friend and we grinded hard as a duo to get up the ranks.

Then I took a long break before recently trying it out again. I try to push myself to enjoy the game still by playing Drogoz and other fun old champions, but I just can't. I'm probably writing this because of the usual losing streaks and lack of teamplay (from my part as well since I know I cannot rely on it at this low rank), but I know others are in my position too. I would suggest just playing a different competitive game.

My name is Walter Hartwell White. I live at 308 Negra Arroyo Lane, Albuquerque, New Mexico, 87104. This is my confession. If you're watching this tape, I'm probably dead, murdered by my brother-in-law Hank Schrader. Hank has been building a meth empire for over a year now and using me as his chemist. Shortly after my 50th birthday, Hank came to me with a rather, shocking proposition. He asked that I use my chemistry knowledge to cook methamphetamine, which he would then sell using his connections in the drug world. Connections that he made through his career with the DEA. I was... astounded, I... I always thought that Hank was a very moral man and I was... thrown, confused, but I was also particularly vulnerable at the time, something he knew and took advantage of. I was reeling from a cancer diagnosis that was poised to bankrupt my family. Hank took me on a ride along, and showed me just how much money even a small meth operation could make. And I was weak. I didn't want my family to go into financial ruin so I agreed. Every day, I think back at that moment with regret. I quickly realized that I was in way over my head, and Hank had a partner, a man named Gustavo Fring, a businessman. Hank essentially sold me into servitude to this man, and when I tried to quit, Fring threatened my family. I didn't know where to turn.
Eventually, Hank and Fring had a falling out. From what I can gather, Hank was always pushing for a greater share of the business, to which Fring flatly refused to give him, and things escalated. Fring was able to arrange, uh I guess I guess you call it a "hit" on my brother-in-law, and failed, but Hank was seriously injured, and I wound up paying his medical bills which amounted to a little over $177,000. Upon recovery, Hank was bent on revenge, working with a man named Hector Salamanca, he plotted to kill Fring, and did so. In fact, the bomb that he used was built by me, and he gave me no option in it. I have often contemplated suicide, but I'm a coward. I wanted to go to the police, but I was frightened. Hank had risen in the ranks to become the head of the Albuquerque DEA, and about that time, to keep me in line, he took my children from me. For 3 months he kept them. My wife, who up until that point, had no idea of my criminal activities, was horrified to learn what I had done, why Hank had taken our children. We were scared. I was in Hell, I hated myself for what I had brought upon my family. Recently, I tried once again to quit, to end this nightmare, and in response, he gave me this. I can't take this anymore. I live in fear every day that Hank will kill me, or worse, hurt my family. I... All I could think to do was to make this video in hope that the world will finally see this man, for what he really is

FOR THE RED VELVET CAKE:
2 and 2/3 cups (295 grams) cake flour (spooned & leveled)
1/4 cup (22 grams) natural unsweetened cocoa powder
1 teaspoon baking soda
1/2 teaspoon salt
1/2 cup (115 grams) unsalted butter softened to room temperature
1 and 3/4 cups (350 grams) granulated sugar
2 large eggs room temperature
1/2 cup (120 ml) canola or vegetable oil
1 (1-ounce) bottle liquid red food color
2 teaspoons pure vanilla extract
1 teaspoon distilled white vinegar
1 and 1/3 cups (320 ml) buttermilk room temperature
FOR THE CREAM CHEESE FROSTING:
12 ounces brick-style cream cheese softened
3/4 cup (175 grams) unsalted butter softened to room temperature
3 cups (360 grams) powdered sugar
1 and 1/2 teaspoons pure vanilla extract
INSTRUCTIONS
 
TO MAKE THE RED VELVET CAKE:
Preheat oven to 350°F (177°C). Spray two 9-inch cake pans well with nonstick cooking spray, line the bottoms of the pans with parchment paper, and set aside.
In a large mixing bowl, whisk together the cake flour, cocoa powder, baking soda, and salt. Then sift the dry ingredients to remove any lumps of cocoa powder. Set aside.
In the bowl of a stand mixer fitted with the paddle attachment, or in a large mixing bowl using an electric mixer, cream together the butter and sugar on medium speed for 4-5 minutes. Add the eggs and mix until fully combined, then mix in the oil, red food color, vanilla extract, and vinegar stopping to scrape down the sides of the bowl as needed.
Mix in the dry ingredients in three additions alternating with the buttermilk, starting and ending with the dry ingredients. Make sure to mix each addition until just combined and be careful not to over mix the batter.
Evenly distribute the cake batter between the two prepared cake pans and spread the batter around into one even layer. Tap the pans on the counter 2-3 times to remove any air bubbles from the cakes.
Bake at 350°F (177°C) for 28-32 minutes or until a toothpick inserted into the center of the cakes comes out clean. Carefully remove from the oven and place on a wire rack to cool in the pans for 15-20 minutes. Then, carefully remove the cakes from the cake pans and place on the wire rack to cool completely. 
TO MAKE THE CREAM CHEESE FROSTING:
In the bowl of a stand mixer fitted with the paddle attachment, or in a large mixing bowl using an electric mixer, beat the cream cheese until smooth. Add the butter and mix for about 30 seconds-1 minute until well combined and smooth. 
Mix in the powdered sugar and vanilla extract and continue mixing until fully combined, scraping down the sides of the bowl as needed.
TO ASSEMBLE THE CAKE:
Level the tops of each cake with a knife or cake leveler. Place one of the cake layers on a cake stand or plate, top with a layer of frosting, and smooth it out into one even layer. Place the second layer on top, then use the remaining frosting to frost the top and sides of the cake.
NOTES
Store leftover red velvet cake in an airtight container in the refrigerator for up to 3 days.
Freezing instructions: Cake will freeze well for up to 3 months, thaw overnight in the refrigerator, then bring to room temperature. Frosting will also freeze for up to three months, thaw overnight in the refrigerator, then bring to room temperature and mix well before frosting the cake.
Buttermilk Substitute: If you don't have any buttermilk on hand, you can use my homemade buttermilk substitute. 
To make a 9x13 cake: Spray a 9x13 pan well with nonstick cooking spray. Pour the batter into the prepared baking pan and spread it around into one even layer, then bake for 35-40 minutes or until a toothpick inserted into the center comes out clean.
To make cupcakes: Line 30-32 cavities in muffin pans with cupcake liners, evenly divide the batter between all of the liners. Bake for 15-18 minute or until a toothpick inserted into the center of the cupcakes comes out clean. If you prefer fewer cupcakes, you can cut this recipe in half to make 15-16.

A nice alternative to Overwatch, mainly because Overwatch is in a terrible state balance wise, but this game isn't exactly doing as good as we could wish either. 

The graphics are ugly, the music is forgetable, the character's voiceline and personality are generic ,and the game have an identity crisis because the devs keep adding skins that don't looks like the character at all or fit the game's artstyle in the first place. But this isn't much of a problem, for while the game's art is lame, what makes this game shines is it gameplay. 

The game is suprisingly balanced despite it enormous rooster of 56 characters, and you have enormous customisation possibilities for each characters thanks to the shopping system and most importantly the card loadout system. There are many characters that are easy to pick up and hard to master, which make them very interesting to play. As for the game's sound effect, while it is not the best, it's decent enough.

A typical paladin's round is also very dynamic, switching between assault and defense frequently enough, and a Paladin's casual game is usually fairly well balanced. All of this make this game very fun to play and you will easily enjoy this game for many hours. 

However, despite all of this, the game is certainly at it worst right now. The majority of the updates add nothing but dumb skin that will always only really appeal to a niche audience of the community, and they are expensive to get. They also add a load of characters per year, however I noticed that these characters get less and less original and I rarely see people ever picking them up after a couple of weeks after their release. They have not added a single new fresh map for a good year, and the map's pool is very limited at the moment. 

Additionally, competitive mode, is garbage, despite the fact that this is a competitive shooter game. You have to wait an atrocious amount of time for each teams to "ban" a character from the rooster one by one, and even then an average competitive game tends to be pretty unbalanced. 

So to conclude this, TL;DR gameplay is really fun, but the updates are lackluster and the art is really not good.

Here we go. A review of Paladins. Let me preface this by saying I have played Paladins for multiple years. I also took a hiatus during the Pay To Win period.

Would I recommend Paladins: 11%

Yes the game is not perfect and has many, many flaws. But for all of those flaws Paladins still comes out as personally one of the best, if not the best, Free to play game.

Lets start with the champion pool. There are over 56 champions at the time of writing and are all unique to one another. (yes there are assests from other characters in some of these champions but what game/media doesn't take inspiration!). My personal favourites being Mal Damba, a support witch doctor type character with a snake as a weapon and Moji, a flank rabbit character that rides on a two headed lizard creature which shoots fire and projectile spit. That sounds awesome! And trust me. It is awesome!

The maps are varied and all have their benefits, each with their own concepts. The maps are pretty and have many points of attack for tactical takeovers.

The modes in Paladins include, Siege, TDM and Onslaught. Siege is a capture the point and push the payload mix, TDM is TDM lol and Onslaught is Capture and Hold the Point. These modes are very fun and can be enjoyed by many different types of people. The only competitive mode is Siege which makes sense as that is the most tactical and fleshed out mode as it was the base concept for the game.

I could go on for much longer but its wasting valuable time for you to be playing this game. Go and download it. Its freaking amazing. :)

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

good game, but I have a few nitpicks, for reference: I played this for about 600 hours or so on the switch, played every event, and have made it to Platinum in ranked several times:
- some matchs lag an unbearable amount (for example sake, I have a multi router setup for blazing speeds, meaning it's 100% bad netcode, or just people with badwifi either or, it does make it annoying to play sometimes, this is more noticeable on console, it runs far better on pc, but the spikes are still seen every now and again)
- the battle pass's take a extraordinary long time, reason for this is so you feel like spending money, but god I feel as if it was taken too far, mind you I'm the type of person who loves a good grind, but this? it's approximately 4-6 matchs with boosters and all wins, to level up once... the time it takes to level up is downright annoying without the boosters, leading to the player not feel like they want to play anymore. I recommend playing in a party to get that slight boost as it makes it far more bearable. it's always a long grueling crawl either way. dont get me wrong, this could be rectified if the rewards at each level were something good, and made the player feel like it's something worth grinding for, but most of them from every battle pass have not been anything worth while to keep someone invested, other then a few profile pictures, and the skins.

Other then the two nitpicks, games not bad, worth a try if you haven't played before, I mean it's free nothings stopping you from trying it at least. a hero is added almost every update, and are decently balanced usually etc.

Amazing Free to Play game with lots of characters, events, play styles and more! It is a 5v5 team battle with different game modes like king of the hill, team death match, push the payload, and other event game modes, the game does allow you to collect premium currency over time so you can dress your favorite heroes in the coolest skins. With this game, you get what you pay for. As you can tell, this game is free, therefore I leave plenty of room for leniency, but that does not mean that it cannot be criticized fairly. The game feels like it is still in its Beta version, yet you can find yourself spending upwards of $100 or more, which I find inoffensively inappropriate. There are multiple instances of imperfections that should not be in a years-old, active game, especially in such a competitive space for this genre; minor visual and audio bugs that are too clear to ignore, and overall lack of polish in graphics and gameplay are the biggest flaws this game ought to fix (some were not even present in the Beta!). These things, combined with several out-of-place design choices and some other poor aspects of the game, make it seem like there is a lack of passion and care put in this otherwise fun and unique experience. All in all, I would still recommend this game because it is free and I have enjoyed it quite a bit through the years. I wish the game and its creator a bright and prosper future :)

Paladins is a game that you don't play. It. Plays. You. You should be honored that such a game as great as this exists within our timeline. With its global "Glorious Ascension" patch that the game is set to receive, players will be able to transform the game into a true sports simulation. Who knows? They may even get creative and get you to play in the annual North American Paladins Hoops Tournament. But the real prizes are for the creators of the game to create a reality show around Paladins that has some of the best players in the world competing. How could anyone say no to that?

The game is owned by Hi-Rez Studios, who recently celebrated their 10th birthday. One of the originators of the Smite franchise, Hi-Rez have some solid hits under their belt, including the free-to-play team-based shooter Warframe. However, Paladins has been Hi-Rez Studios' biggest hit to date, with its sequel League of Legends style roster system and the frenetic movement of its world creating a kind of free-flow of destruction. I personally am a big fan of this game, and it's a one-two punch of creativity for Hi-Rez Studios. While Warframe does have it's fair share of fans, Paladins has many more players and has received several high-profile partnerships that could potentially help it grow in the coming months.

Well, I've only played for a fair amount of time, but it's fun. I like most character designs and love the idea of having a certain build to improve the characters.

There are some games in which you can pull ahead of your team and still dominate for a time, especially if you are good at said game. For example, CSGO and COD were games where you could pull of these stunts. Paladins, however, is not one of those games! This is truly a team-based FPS and coordination wins every time. I have played with my bros as a squad and I have played with randoms, the difference in how the matches turned out were night and day in comparison. The squads we faced seemed like premade squads, as their movement and hero choices were balanced and effective. You will find yourself in matches that are difficult more often than not, which is a good thing......if you also have a coordinated squad. I can't tell you how frustrating it is to watch your teammates race ahead and split off, each thinking they can take the entire enemy squad alone. This mentality must come from those previously mentioned FPS games where that might work, but all it results in here is almost certain defeat. 

Having said all that, this game is fun to play and offers a large list of heroes to play, each with their own unique abilities and weapons. I like the choices given to you and at the time when I bought it, the battle pass that unlocked the entire roster of heroes was much cheaper than other games would rob you for. Levels were good and offered multiple angles of attack, modes were challenging and interesting too. I don't really have much bad things to say about this game except that in some rare cases I experienced server issues (not sure if they are better or worse now) and solo queue in this game can be a nightmare if you have a squad that doesn't communicate, but this isn't all the time. So all in all, I recommend this game.

What is Paladins? Excellent question random voice in my head formed by schizophrenia. Paladins is a 5v5 fps game which draws heavy inspiration from similar titles such as Overwatch. Some characters feel very similar to the original and some are basically a straight copy, but the game has a lot more characters making it some what more enjoyable and the introduction of new characters every couple months is a big upgrade to that of overwatch. There's not much story here, its mostly just about getting your team mates together and then having fun with them in PvP mode or the PvE missions, though there will be plenty of options for those who wish to get into the storyline as well Paladins Review – A New Challenger My first impressions were somewhat positive but the negatives overshadowed that fact that this title was quite different than anything I have played before so far, even the other shooter titles like Halo or Call of Duty games didn't come close to comparing to the level of detail that Paladins had on display. The game is an MMOFPS and it shows, with every new map we saw and more in-game screens than we can count at this point the developers are getting more and more polish into their title, and we are all very much for it! I am personally a fan of the new graphics, but I'm not really happy with how they handle the armor models and weapons, since they're just so bad in my opinion; they look like some of them are made out of cardboard. Also, there's this "shiny" effect on the guns, making it seem very cheap and plastic-y to me... Also, this is not really the first time that this game has had this problem (as far as I know), so I think that it'd be good if they could fix it because right now it seems like they're not really trying hard at all to fix it... I think that the weapons should be better modeled too, though I do prefer the "old" way of modeling them, while I can understand why they decided to go with the new ones, I still think that they need to make a few tweaks here and there to get the best result, especially when we're talking about such a big change like this... They are using something called "Voxel" technology, which means they are literally making each element of the weapon/armor/thingie out of thousands upon thousands of tiny cubes. This gives it a very organic and realistic feel in terms of how it would actually look when you were holding it or looking at it with your eyes up close (in game). It is also being done to get around the fact that this game is on console and not PC/PC-like, where everything would have to be modeled individually, scaled, textured etc, so it makes sense that they used the voxel tech here because it allows them to create an entire weapon/armor/thingie in one go, instead of having to model each part individually.  It was cool but I’m not so sure I like the way the character looks – he has a weird head shape and seems too short for his size (if you look at the picture above). I think the legs are too skinny compared to how big the rest of him is, and the torso is just too long, making him seem even shorter than he already is (which would be understandable if the body were wider). And then the arms look really weird and stiff, almost like rubber limbs.

A 5 year old unreal engine 3 game with 3 game modes and about 8 or 9 maps in total, with graphics that are in the PS1.5-PS3 range, with glitches that kill the game back when it was released 5 years ago, and not only those persist today, more and more glitches arise and the developers do nothing about it, sending them countless emails for getting banned multiple times for merely being matched to a game, and they just keep asking me for the same information and files over and over again, until I give up. It used to be playable, but right now they're just focusing on selling new skins as if they were brand new champions when they're just skins, not fixing anything, not making graphics less dated and not making new maps. Such a good concept but with the worst execution possible. Matchmaking is also clearly manipulated so that people who don't pay for the battle pass constantly lose, this is a 5 VS 5 player game and I have had lose streaks of 7 or 8 games in a row, with "random" people. In addittion the Spanish translation, up to a few days ago, has always been done via translator. Now all of a sudden the translation makes sense (after 5 years of release), but you cannot hide the Sun with a finger.

An awesome hero shooter with tons variability from the amount of characters, their talents, and the card system. The mid match item shop and the other systems I mentioned do take a little figuring out but the game is way more rewarding than others in the genre because of this. The game has always had a diverse cast of characters and the expansion of the roster continues at a pretty good pace with 3-4 characters a year. The last couple years they have really landed on a consistent art style for the game and it really has a much better sense of cohesiveness because of this. With that the quality of character skins have really increased as well. A good chunk of this game is building a character to the way you like to play them and/or making them efficient as possible. This aspect may not be for everybody but I find it quite enjoyable, being able to tinker with a character and solve a puzzle of how to get this character to play the way I want. 

It is not without it flaws with it being essentially a AA release there comes a little bit of jank and bugs and some quality of life issues. The game feel could be a bit tighter but I think overall its good, the characters function well but some do encounter bugs or strangeness more than others. Most of the time these bugs are sound related. With it being a team driven game when somebody leaves its pretty much game over as a crappy bot will take over. This isn't a fault of the game but more so the genre of game. People leaving or disconnecting happens a little too frequently at times and it can be frustrating. 

In conclusion, this game is amazing when you have a full five people working together against another team working with each other. If all the people in the game know how the game works and its systems the high you get from this is something you don't get in most other games. But you will encounter some bumps in the road when trying to chase this high. But be patient with it and you will be rewarded with a truly unique and satisfying experience. Paladins is a diamond in the rough, a flawed gem.
it is a very good game, and I recommend it to competitive players.

Fun Game. Casual play is quite competitive though. As a new-ish player, i'm against players way above my skill level. That's a bit unfair for players who are new to paladins and cannot play in a fair ranked environment. I enjoy playing alone against A.I where i can practice champions. I Love the variety of cosmetics  available so every player always seems to be using a different variance of skin to make the game feel less consistent and repetitive but they're so expensive. Right now, it would cost me more than £70 to claim all 20 cosmetics from battle pass 2020, that's crazy money only for 20 skins and it's still RNG so if you wanted one specific character from the 2020 bundle, you can either gamble and hope you get it for 400 crystals per open or pay double the amount (800 crystals) to get it straight away. One fun way to 'earn' skins could to add very challenging quotas to achieve for every character, not something that takes a few hours to complete like the current trials in the game. One example could be like how you earn a golden variant cosmetic option once your champion gets level 50 (even though you still have to pay a lot to actually unlock the skin).

Phew, I play now :)

Paladins is a solid "hero-shooter" game. Yes you can have fun playing this.

It has a fast pace which turns its experience pretty exciting. Even thought it has a low map diversity, when it comes to Champions it has a decent roster and the graphics are pretty okay.

Each character has its own play style, strengths, and weaknesses, and they can be customized with loadouts (cards that provide a wide variety of effects).

Game Community used to be friendly back in the old days and during the long Beta phase, at the moment it's pretty toxic just like most of today's games. But just disable Voice Chat and avoid it. You can also play with your friends since the game has Crossplay (something that took longer for OW to get).

This is a fantastic First-Person Hero shooter. I would say it's better than Overwatch. It may not be as pretty graphically, but the gameplay is much better imo. The game is constantly being updated to add new cosmetics, balance changes, and new heroes. Not to mention it has Cross-Save, cross-play and it's free to play. You can earn new heroes by playing pretty easily. The game also has full controller support. I have wrist pain, and that feature has been a godsend. Controller is much more comfortable than playing on Keyboard & Mouse for my wrists. The only negative thing I have to say is that sometimes the menus can be a little glitchy on controller, and after a big update, the game launches in a messed up resolution, both of these have easy workarounds.

Paladins is one of my fav games, the devs are very nice, respond very quickly to problems (on the Hi-Rez website) and the game is all around super enjoyable.

My good buddy with autism (Wolfpack360) plays this game almost daily and seems to talk about nothing but paladins!

The game is hard at first, but after you play for a bit and get a bit better the game is super super fun to play, especially if you have a good friend like wolfpack360 to play with!

The character designs are nice, and team composition really matters! You actually have to work like a team in order to succeed, not like overwatch (yuck!) where no one even cooperates.

Paladins will forever be in my tops! Thank you for making such a great game.

So, they advertise this RWBY crossover, and it seemed awesome, so I decided to try it.  After looking around the client for 20m I realized they did not in fact put those characters in the game.  They added RWBY skins. Shitty bait advertising, but whatever, may as well try the game.

First, the game wont launch as it failed to install the redistributable correctly.  Repair doesn't work.  Had to google the fix.

Finally get it. So I play a game.  It seems really suspiciously easy.  Then I realized the entire game was bots.  Nothing to terll me that, no option to queue for a game with real people.  What a shitty new player experience. Absolutely no respect for anyone who is not playing a FPS for the first time. No indication whatsoever when or how to play against real players, but a google search says I get to actually play the game at level 5. Yikes.

Then I decide I want to try and unlock a new hero.  I see a quest to get a free reward by watching an ad.  Seems mega tacky for  a decently big studio, but ok.  Turn on ad and tab out.  When I tab back into the game it gets stuck on the accept reward screen. SMH.  Havent even played a real match and I already hate the game.  Shame. FWIW IO seemed really fun.


Edit: played a couple more matches against real players.  The in game scoreboard is absolutely awful compared to OW.  You also cant remap keyboard controls??? Like what?  Still not sure if the game has a melee button, since I couldnt find it in the nonexistant keyboard layout settings.  Gameplay is decent, everything else seems to suck super hard.  Also, the game is basically not free to play.  Like smite, you're getting a shitty user experience if you dont buy the all heroes bundle.  Still better than LoL MTX I guess.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing

Game is super fun, you've got so many choices of how to play, be it a character or loadouts for said characters, and even in game items you can buy per game. Its also cross-platform so you can play with your plebeian console friends! (Joke aside, its super easy to find your friends and play with them.) Its a solid game and I would recommend it to anyone who likes hero games like Overwatch. Plus like Smite this game has crossovers with shows and movies! At the time of writing this review theres currently a crossover with RWBY!

The game isn’t bad.

It’s an odd game that is heavily inspired by other class based shooters especially Overwatch, but that doesn’t mean it’s not fun. The champions all unique playstyles with abilities and weapons that are fun to use. Additionally, you can edit these with cards to help you excel in a certain playstyles. I found the card system to be a pretty neat system.

However, the game is more buggy than some of the more popular alternatives. There still active updates to this game, but there still a lot of bugs at the end.

To call this an Overwatch clone is sorta true, but at the same time it has a lot of things that Overwatch doesn't.
The cards and talents system adds a bit of spice to the game that Overwatch doesn't have, as there's more than one way to play a champion. It doesn't feel like the same game every time, whereas the aforementioned one gets a bit repetitive.

As a standalone game too, it's pretty solid as well. Frequent content, lots of action (there's very little downtime in fights), rotating game modes, a plethora of champions with unique and fun-to-play kits. No two champions feel alike.

Overall, a pretty great game, doesn't get as much attention as it deserves.

dont waste your time. This game might be cool for the first few games, or days playing but you will soon realize what makes this game such a joke. From the devs only caring about money and the lack of interest in making the game good. Let me start off with the maps. the same maps you are going to see have been the same maps since 2019. the maps suck are old and the design of them are horrendous. you will come to realize the invisible walls that with randomly stop you from using willo's flitter, drogoz rocket boost and even when trying to throw someone off the map with khan. Another issues is how "heavy" the walls are. the walls stop your movement. this is not the game for walls to be messing with your movement. the maps (even though need major improvement) arent the biggest issues tho... its the champions, Hirez only cares about adding new champions in the game and skins to try and get people to spend money. Though its not pay to win it doesnt even matter because the champions are still broken. (or atleast some) Skyes damage and invisibility, Lians autoaim, seris (a healer) also being a flank and damage, (Vivian. Viktor, Tyra and Octavia) all being boring cov/valorant inspired characters broken in their own way, and some healers having more damage output than flanks and other damages. all in all alot if not most of the characters in this game are broken and need reworks and some of them needed them 2 years ago. to put it simply this game has a bunch of issues and bugs and is only worth playing if you dont care about winning. the devs dont care about what the community wants and only cares about pumping new characters and skins. their are better games to be wasting your time on than this broken, buggy, dying game.

As of right now I would not recommend this game, When I first started to play this game me and my friends had tons of fun, close games, ridiculous matches it was fun, but in atleast this past year the game has took a turn for the worse. From its in game ads, to more microtransactions, yes for mostly cosmetics and quicker character unlocks, to releasing characters that are completely broken and nerfing characters that should not be nerfed or not supporting characters at all. The biggest change they have done done that, in my opinion, has ruined the game is the global cauterize, anti-heal. Starting any given match as a support is almost a detriment to your team when you do not even heal them for the full value but 30% LESS value starting off. As well as the followed insane damage from quite a few champions make it ridiculously hard for a support player to make it absurdly hard to heal your teammates. This game has definitely went from a game you could pick up by yourself to a game where you NEED a team of 5 that perfectly strategizes to play in its skilled based matchmaking system, and even then there is no guarantee you won't be put up against the god mode enemies.
TLDR: as of now with its many issues I would not recommend but I hope it gets fixed in the future for me and my friends to have fun with

While not perfect, Paladins continues to bring me back with new content, features, updates and an awesome community of dedicated players. 

I find Paladins very fun in its diverse list of champions and playstyles available with the cards system. For someone reading this who has no idea of what I'm talking about, you can basically create a loadout of cards that increase certain stats of yours e.g. reload speed or damage reduction while a certain ability is activated. You have points you can invest in 5 cards from the total of 16. This system is wonderful in customising your playing to fit certain situations, change your role entirely (DPS healers are awesome) or testing out some wacky builds. 

Paladins is frequently updated with balance changes, bug fixes, new skins, map reworks, champions and new gamemodes, most notably a recent addition, Siege: Beyond which aims to experiment with new gameplay elements that won't affect the main gamemodes, but if the community loves it, it may be added!

Speaking of the community, the Paladins fanbase is very active and a good place to experience the game together. There's a lot of art, guides, tutorials, memes, discussions etc. The community is listened to as well and the devs are asking feedback for things every now and then!


While Paladins has a lot of great features, it's not completely polished, like UI bugs, getting stuck on a loading screen and audio bugs, like the audio of your own character disappearing. Sometimes champions are way too powerful or way too weak, but the devs take action on that. 


All in all, wherever this game goes, I'll be here to see it. I still enjoy it after years of playing this on and off and more actively in the last couple years. Give it a try, it's truly a fun experience.

Came in as an exile from TF2 after its bot death looking for some casual shootin'.
Is this budget Overwatch? Sorta. But also kinda better in a way

+ the gunplay feels more satisfying than OW actually
+ item and cards system adds some playstyle options to the already huge list of champs
+ haven't really encountered cheaters at all, know they exist but at least it seems somewhat under control
+ movement doesn't have the depth of arena shooters or even TF2, but at least feels faster than OW
- shields and stuns, tanks seem to dominate games
- anti-healing makes supports really frustrating to play sometimes (I do like Grohk tho)
- I have 120 hours and haven't unlocked even half of champs. Progression system is really slow if you don't spend real money. Good thing I'm patient.

Disclaimer: I haven't tried ranked and don't intend to. The casual experience is good enough for me. Still miss TF2 but this is enough to scratch the shooter itch for now. Decent game if you don't take it too seriously, and it's free.

I may have very few hours in this game according to steam compared to the other platforms i may not be so good at this game but i love it. it features cross progressions between the two other platorms with this version of paladins (not going to say the one other major platform this game is featured in that isn't cross progression) it's annoying that they have very few featured modes compared to another game but i have noticed that they added a sort of hardpoint domination version that you may end up with when you pick onslaught instead of just capturing one point you may have to move to capture a teleporting ring. it's really nice that this is first and foremost f2p but unlike many other games despite how it has battle passes (yes it's a game that has season and battle passes that you have to pay for) that have cosmetics that once it's gone you can no longer attempt to earn them but in this game they kind of do it right (to some extent) where you can have a chance to get said cosmetics from loot chests that are paid with in premium currency/crystals  (i'm not a fan of loot boxes but it beats not being able to get certain cosmetics that you missed out on) though you'll have to look at the many pieces of items you can get within certain loot chests because they have different loot chests that features different themes and such or types of rarity of the cosmetics. i'm not entirely a fan of how much crystals cost compared to some cosmetics but from what i remember you can gift crystals in game to another friend and i do like how they sometimes feature new/unusual modes for events like back then they had this one mode where you have to knock a ball into the opposing teams goal though i haven't seen anything that different after i stopped playing. they have added a mode variant related to siege where the payload/cart does take damage but i haven't played that yet so they are at least trying to give us something new to play with and i'm liking how many characters they have given us to choose from and sometimes they let us use the new/old characters  in a sort of trial that cycles every now and then for different set of characters that we haven't bought with in game gold or premium currency or the bundle you can buy in that includes majority of the champions so far (time of this review). or you can buy seasons passes for certain cosmetics and the newer champions that'll come out during the yearly cycle that it states it's for. some of the cosmetics that you can get from the battle pass/event pass i like but they seemed a bit too grindy back then but with less tiers and decent amount of days it's not so bad these days. they do collabs at times thankfully so you can get some out of place stuff that may fit in with the world or maybe not (this game has a weird but satisfying theme with some modern like weapons and fantasy creatures that some might of not thought of exist or barely heard of) overall i think it's a similar but fun game like another popular hero shooter you may have heard of but this one plays differently but this game sometimes feels a bit slower i'd rate 8.5/10 it's something worth coming back to now and then but it's best to not get addicted to it and put a lot of money into. 
Extra notes/edit :They once had third person perspective but it's gone now  i don't know why but it was a good feature back then especially for cosmetics but you can still see you champion from time to time in third person but only with certain actions or at least while your riding your mount and i'm not sure why the one platform doesn't feature cross progression (at least with my account)
