Introduction

Hi, my in-game name is CzeMarek and I spent about 1500 hours with this game. In every season I played, I managed to obtain the rank of Master. I love the pace and mechanics of the game, however I could not recommend it to anyone.

The Developer's Approach

From the early beginning when Paladins was still in beta, it suffered from a lot of bugs. Hi-Rez studios didn't seem to have a need of fixing the bugs as the first priority. This way, the list of present bugs grew with every update. Some bugs have literally lasted in the game for YEARS and are still there! Let me talk about one as an example. Sha Lin is a damage class champion with a bow, that he uses every second of a match. Since the day I started playing the game (which was in the autumn of 2016), there has been a big problem with the champion - everybody has had huge FPS drops when drawing the bow. Now just imagine, there are dozens of bugs that have, just like this one, been in the game for years and haven't been fixed yet! In the present, Hi-Rez are still focusing on new content instead of bug fixes and with every patch the number of bugs is growing; there are even champions that cannot be played in e-sports because of how much they are bugged.

The Beta

Paladins was in beta for years. Many times, the developers made drastic changes to the mechanics of the game; they even reverted some patches in OB67 (which was probably the best update in the history of Paladins)! Now don't get me wrong, the long beta was perhaps the best thing Hi-Rez ever came with. During the beta, Hi-Rez released a new champion every odd patch and a new map every even. This would be great, if they also put effort into fixing bugs. In may of 2018, they decided to release the game from beta with the patch 1.0, due to lack of finances. This was the worst thing that could have happened - the game was in a bad state, unpolished and full of bugs. Even now, almost a year after the patch 1.0, I don't think the game is in a state, in which it could be released. In my opinion, this move bought Paladins a one-way ticket to oblivion and extinction.

The Matchmaking and Ranking System

The ranking system is basically pointless - it records your personal rating in the team based game, while it doesn't take into account your personal performance! That means it doesn't matter how well you do; if you spend the whole game afk in a spawnroom, you will lose the same amount of points as a person, who unsuccesfully tried to carry your team and ended up with the best numbers in the game. Now you might think that's fine, but it is really not. Wait times for ranked are awful. You have to wait usually about 10 minutes for the match (if you have a decent ELO), then you pick champions for another 3, then someone crashes, then you wait again and when you finally get to play, you get queued with smurfs and people who have much lower ELO than you, so the game lasts for about 7 minutes anyway and it's just not fun. So in the end, you spend way more time waiting for your games to find than actually playing. Also, let's mention the leaderboards. The list of grandmasters, who are supposed to be the top players in the game is just a joke. Everyone who has thousands of hours to play can get there. There is only a few people in GM that have a good W/L ratio, you can go check for yourself. So to sum up, the rewards and ranks are just an index of how much you play and how long you grind.

The Bots and Reconnecting

A bot, character controled by AI, is a definition of evil in this game. In higher ELO matches, when a player crashes or leaves the game due to any other reason, it basically means a lost game - bots are very likely going to spin in the spawnroom or, if they decide to join the fight, just blindly rush and die. Now you technically play a 4v5 game. In other scenarios, the bots get inhuman skills and reflexes and thus you have a 6v5 game. Due to the bugs and bad servers, you are going to have at least one bot in 25% of your games. The bot is even allowed to buy items for you, which is a problem when you have a limit of 4 various items to purchase. Your teammates will probably become afk too, because, seriously, who wants to play a 4v5 game? The afk players will not receive a ban anyway, because Hi-Rez probably ignores all the reports. Of course, a disconnected player can reconnect and continue playing (althought there is a bug that makes you unable to rejoin the match). The problem is that after your game crashes, you have to wait until the anticheat opens (which takes an eternity), then fill out the the crash report or close it and after all that you can start Paladins again. But that's not all! If the game lets you connect back into the match, your bindings reset so you have to open and close the settings and the textures usually become broken too. When leaving the spawnroom after reconnecting, you teleport when passing the exit, which makes the play around the spawn impossible. What's more, your FPS might get crazy and the whole experience you might have gotten from the game is completely ruined. If you or your teammates decide to give up, there is no way to do so, because the option to surrender was taken out of the game for a reason.

The Balance

Every champion has 3 talents that a player can modify the playstyle with. This sounds interesting, but in the end this is just an illusion of choice. Most of the champions' third talent is just weaker than the others or completely useless. Many times, there is only one good talent for the champion and if you pick another, you are basically throwing. The reason for this is that some champions have a bad base kit. Let me take Ying as an example. Ying is a healer that can heal with illusions she places. She has a talent that makes her able to heal for a straight 800HP with a right click. Now with this talent she is considered one of the best healers in the game. And without the talent? You're throwing! Another problem is Hi-Rez itself - it takes insanely long for them to nerf the overpowered talents. For instance a card that gave you wallhack every 3 seconds was nerfed after more than a year!

The Way Information Is Given to the Player

The game doesn't tell you anything about itself. Only thing it teaches you (in tutorial) is how to walk and shoot, which you can read in the setting. It doesn't say a word about the mechanics of the game. it just doesn't tell you anything! If you are a new player, do you know what does a 'Comback mechanic' mean? I doubt it, even the e-sport casters have to explain it 10 times a day. The game does not even explain loadouts or an item shop!! Only way you learn about it is by noticing an UI prompt that says 'PRESS I TO PURCHASE ITEMS'. And there are more: The killstreaks and their relevance, the effect of silence, cripple and CC... You are not even able to figure it out by yourself at the Shooting range, because the bots there are immune! And I could continue for days. Some mechanics aren't explained at the Wiki either; you seriously have to go and ask a content creator in the chat of his stream or comments under his video!

Other Game Modes

There are also other game modes apart from Siege in Paladins. Let's talk about Team Deathmatch. The maps for this mode are often designed so badly, it's painful to play. A lot of them have very bad spawn points and one team has an advantage over the other. The spawn algorithm is so bad, it sometimes doesn't move your spawn point for the whole match (thus you have to travel a long way to the battle or you just might get easily spawn-camped). All this causes that 75% of the map can remain unused. Furthermore, Hi-Rez is still trying to force you to play it by creating stupid TDM missions and other kinds of content.

Summary

There is much more but let me post a final verdict here. I give this game 2/10 and recommend everyone to stay away from it as far as you can.

TL;DR - Fun game to invest time in but has many bad players and bugs. Core gameplay loop and varied Champions feel amazing. Skill floor to learn champions is very low, skill ceiling is reached by teamplay (that you rarely get to experience) and positioning skills. Bad players will make it hard to enjoy the game if you want to win. Oh and pretty girl skins.

[b]The Paladins Experience[/b]
Most players are bad, you learn to go Damage / Flank to carry most of your games, going Frontline / Support is worthless since you can't carry, enemy team will be better than your team 65% of the time, and you'll carry against bad enemies for 40-50 hours until matchmaking finally gives you competent players. 

Doesn't mean you cant come across good or competent teammates, it's just rarer. Game is best played in queue with friends / pre-made teammates. Like any other multiplayer game. If you're anti-social, g'luck.

Biggest problem is that the enemy team will eventually grow a brain. Carrying when your team is bad will get harder. They'll learn to target you, the only competent player; they'll learn to run away, since your team won't be able to damage them at all; but worst of all, they'll learn to [b]play together.[/b]

Good luck learning the game outside your main champions, you'll lose a majority of your games since you can't carry without Champion experience. Enjoy the slow learning experience.

Gameplay loop itself is great but casual multiplayer is excruciating, play ranked if you want competitive gameplay. And watch videos / guides before starting, you don't want to start at a low rank with the same casual matchmaking experience.

It's not all bad though, lots of great skins, [b]especially for the female Champions.[/b] Though, you'll spend about 800-1000 USD if you want to get every RnG skin / item in the game. Been playing off and on since beta, game is just fun to play sometimes. It's also a royal pain in the ass.

Paladins is a game that used to be great, several years ago. In its current state, all new players should stay away. This game is highly infected with hackers and other toxic players. It is so bad, that EVERY match has AT LEAST one hacker, AFK player, or just toxic player. The "skill based" matchmaking is very poor because of the game's low population. It is very common that new lvl 1 players will be pitted against grandmasters with lvls in the hundreds. The devs are also just releasing champs that are fun to play but not fun to play against, effectively upending the game's balance with each new patch and give very little attention to bug fixing. The core game play of Paladins is fun... if everything aligns just right, which it rarely does. Currently, Paladins feels like it is on life support with Hi-Rez and Evil Mojo just milking what cash they can out of it. Stay away.

This game was fun for quite a while, had a lot of potential and became more unique than playing Overwatch because the characters felt different than the others with their abilities. The Card Based system to improve your play style is also very fun, along with choosing which in-game buffs to buy during the rounds to let everyone choose how they play their Character. Healing felt really good in this game and as a Support Main through many games (This, OW, WoW, etc) - I really enjoyed it. However, they decided to get rid of Cauterize (a buyable healing debuff item to get in the round) and do an Overall Anti-Healing Debuff during games. 90% at 6-Minutes. This was a lazy cop-out to balance healing. It makes healing feel useless, and negated the entire point of Cauterize: A Focus-Fire debuff for team based shooting. It was a horrible decision, and the game was ruined. Some healers in this game are now rendered useless and it's just not fun to play at all. I'm seeing a lot of people drop this game because of it, and I hope HiRez reverses this decision and actually balance healing.

Alright so here's an honest review from fresh eyes (33 hrs of gameplay at time of writing this).
If you're looking for completely polished graphics and gameplay, I would probably start looking elsewhere.
If you're looking for amazing or atleast good solo queues and a bustling community, again, i'd probably look elsewhere.
But if you are looking for a moderately balanced, slightly janky reminiscent of the likes of Team Fortress 2, FPS-style MoBA then boy do I have a treat for you.
Down to brass tacks yes this could be considered another Overwatch doppleganger that once again crumbled under the pressures of 'DLCs' and loot boxes, but personally I see it as a good precursor for where FPS MoBAs should have gone if not should have stayed. Yes I am seeing all the negative reviews from the oldies/day-oners of this game saying things like 'needs rework/balance' or 'I miss the old days' and I can understand where they're coming from being a TF2 Vet myself, but in all honesty stepping into this game without any expectation I've been pleasantly (although disparagingly) surprised. I will say there are some Champions that seem underworked comparatively but good team strat tends to overwhelm all else. 
All in all, at base price of absolutely nothing but your soul, I'm in.

Disclaimer, do not expect solo queuing to work in your favour, most people are either rubbish or insta-lock dmg then proceed to tell you that you are in fact the one throwing the game. ;)

EDIT; Sitting at a steady 200+ hours now and still thoroughly enjoying the game. Frankly quite surprised by the attitude of most of the community in-game, generally seems to be competent enough to have a good chat. Again i'll say specific heroes like Maeve or Skye are pretty OP and there's zero ranked servers. Still good game

It's Overwatch but fun (Like TF2!), and the characters are unashamedly attractive.  Characters play *very* differently from each other, with abilities changing things up pretty dramatically - though it *is* still a shooter at its core (well, for most characters anyway).  No hard counter is ever a hard-walled rock-paper-scissors I-win-you-lose game changer, unlike in [COMPETITOR] - which is especially nice since you don't swap characters mid-match (though you *can* spec differently on the fly to adapt to the situation on the ground).

Much more focus on abilities than in [COMPETITOR] - you get to spam a lot of wild stuff, depending on who you are.  Plenty of ways to customize your gameplay to carve new playstyles which they won't see coming.  Devs take a lot more risks than most other large games you'll see today.  I continually see new, super out-there things I'd never have expected or imagined, and my first thought is always "that's super cool - they'd never dream of doing that in [COMPETITOR]".

Wildly well-supported.  If you played it way back when, the bugs have been squashed, it's nicely polished now, and the cast is getting pretty big.  We're up to like 55+ champions now, and each champ can be specced so many different ways that you'll craft new playstyles you've never seen before, on the regular.  Can't remember the last bug I encountered, & I've crashed maybe... once every 40h of game time?  Doesn't matter anyway since it pops you right back into the same game when you relaunch.  Skins are wild and very out there - not at all conservative like [COMPETITOR].  They completely change characters' looks, voice commands, weapons, weapon/ability particle effects, all in really fun ways.  It's worth learning the buttons to communicate stuff in your characters' own voices - even if you aren't being tactical with it, they're fun and have a lot of charm on a per-skin basis.

You can earn all the characters without ever paying a dime, but if you find you like it well enough for long enough, it's like $20 for every champion all at once, forever, which is a steal - with the game refunding you the in-game gold you spent to acquire each character before you paid for all of them at once.  Community's a lot more positive & fun to play with than they used to be.  Just don't play ranked.  It's containment.

Oh and there's a dude who plays like Call of Duty, if you just wanna stomp all the losers with their fancy-fangled abilities and such.  "Viktor".  His abilities are literally Sprint, ADS, Fire, (none of which have cooldowns) and he can throw a grenade every once in a while.  Rather different from most else, but familiar if you need a jumping-off point before you go down the rabbit hole of WHAT ON EAR-

Sadly, however, took a pretty interesting concept of a battle royale gamemode with the characters that are in THIS game (which I genuinely wanted to play) and turned it into a pretty shoddy spin-off game that is very generic and by this point long dead, for (imo) good reason. Keep in mind that I'm not the kind of person to actually be interested in battle royales, aside from ones that are special and unique enough to catch my eye (Spellbreak, you deserved better).

But regardless, the game itself in its current state is definitely worth playing in its own right, and is still consistently and reliably getting updated to this day after years. Definitely worth at least trying if you're interested, and stopping if you don't enjoy. (Oh, and I am an entirely free-to-play player. The only DLC I got was a really cool free DLC that they did during an event a while ago, which is still very appreciated even if its not still running)

This is by far the most mixed feelings I've ever had on a game. On the one hand, it's a broken, buggy mess. It regularly crashes, glitches out, and breaks. The balancing is way off to the point where some characters and comps feel near impossible to play against. Its artstyle is off-putting and some of the characters range from ugly to kinda problematic. 

But my word. Get past all of that, and you have one of the most fun video games i've ever played. The gameplay feels fluid and fun without being that overwhelming, and each of the roles feel pronounced and have their own important job. While people tend to point out a lot of similarities between this game and overwatch, the character designs still feel very unique. You have a goblin in a flying wooden mech, a man that can stop and rewind time, an army commander that can launch people in the sky with an arm cannon, and a universe-devouring worm. And that's just the tanks. But i think the best part about this game is the customisation. Each character has 3 talents, and 16 cards that alter the way they play. Some of them do feel either redundant or downright useless, but most of the time, it means that 2 people can play the same character in completely diffrent ways. For example, my main, Ruckus, is a tank with booster jets and the ability to generate a shield for himself. One loadout I have for him includes a talent that increases the shield's health to give him some of the highest HP in the game, and a card that lets me activate that shield again after just 5 seconds. This makes him very hard to take down without a co-ordinated attack, and makes holding down the point a lot easier. Another build I have lets his booster jets take him directly upwards, as well as forwards at a much greater distance. This means that, with enough practice, you can get to wherever you want on the map, flank around geometry, and be one of the most mobile characters in the game while still having tank levels of defence. That's just one example from one of the simpler characters in the game. With around 50 characters in the game, each with their own customizability, plus in-game items similar to a MOBA, no 2 people are going to be playing a character the exact same way. 

I could write an entire essay about this game (and maybe I will some day), but for now i'll leave it at this:

Paladins is one of the most fun, creative, and unique ideas for an FPS i've ever seen. But it's an absolute mess. Part of me really hopes we see a complete rework from the ground up, letting everyone see just how good of a game it really is. But for now, give it a chance. I almost want to say it's worth it.

Eh, Its a really nice PVP Team shooter but its ruined by poor maps and a even poorer anti-cheat that they wont even spend the time enforcing. The developers have all but every once in a blue moon abandoned. But they're known for that so it's not really that big of a surprise.

There are a lot of things to take from Paladins. 

The champions vary and the gameplay is fine to an extent. They are unique and most of their abilities are fun. The biggest problem is that there are too many counters to certain champions which makes them unable to come out, ever. Great examples for this are Vivian, Sha Lin, Skye, etc. They are still played from time to time but they don't perform well most of the time.

As a competitive player, the ranked scene is kind of a joke and isn't taken very seriously. Players are very toxic in Paladins and the finding hackers is quite rare and if you do and go on to report them, there isn't a direct option like "Cheating" or "Hacking" which I find extremely odd. 

This is not the only little flaw you will find in Paladins. There is a tornado of small bugs and glitches which don't get fixed ever. The developers lead us to believe that they are merely trying to profit from the former glory of a promising title. 

It is sad to enter after a new update has dropped and all that is added are new counters to your favorite champion, a few overly sexualized skins and a few annoying adjustments which help "Improve" the game.

I started playing around November 2021 and I managed to climb to Diamond within my playtime which is evidence that the competitive scene is not that serious. I could easily climb to Master and eventually Grandmaster if I invest a little more time. I've watched Paladins competitive and it looks extremely fun and I wish I could perform like that but at the same time there is so much time needed to invest for seemingly no reward.

In general, Paladins is fine to play casually and temporarily. It's got a lot of flaws and the developers don't seem to focus on fixing them. There are almost no maps being added, there is a lot of problems with character selection, etc., though in the end, not everyone cares about that and Paladins offers a large variety of fun characters for every playstyle.

7/10

Interestingly I have found this game to be a breath of fresh air after jumping between so many games. Personally if I had to think of problems I've run into it would only be that the start up can be a little finicky at times and that the cosmetics in the game can be kind of a hassle. P.S. If you really want a skin stick to the lootboxes with a small prize pool or wait for bundles. Bundles give you plenty of cosmetics plus lootboxes at a fraction of the cost. It's way more worth it to grind out cosmetics with that. Also theoretically the deal of the day is always unique to you and will give you a chance at cosmetics you don't own so eventually it will show up there too. Outside of that the gameplay has been very enjoyable it's pretty quick paced and the matches don't take that long which I like. It's small doses that don't feel like they drag which was a problem in Overwatch for those who might be comparing the two. I would say if you enjoyed Overwatch or TF2 or really any team shooter you will enjoy this as well. Plus for those who crave a little more from their shooter this game delivers on customizing your champions. Unlike in Overwatch you can specialize your champions to be particularly potent in their roll which is kinda like a game within a game, at least if you like trying new builds and seeing how they perform to compliment your playstyle. I find that part in particular to be the best selling point for this game. You can really get creative or just meme with your characters meaning even if both teams have the exact same comp they will hardly ever be playing it the exact same way. With all the little things you can do with your character it can keep the game feeling much more fresh even if you're like me who sticks mainly to one character. Personally despite all my hours in Overwatch I must say that I prefer this game in almost every way. It may not be as pretty and it does lack a certain polish that Overwatch had but honestly that doesn't bother me in the least. It is easily a game I know I will sink many more hours into and if you're fine with a semi-serious but also free spirited team shooter that is actually fun then I am certain you will too if you give the game a chance.

It's still a great game to play casually, but it is rapidly losing players because of the way balance is handled these days. There used to be minor tweaks and adjustments to certain aspects of the game that would either subtly improve the game or make it worse to a small degree. 

     Now it appears that they longstanding balance issues that caused serious strife in the community, such as the problem with anti heal being a requirement at higher levels, and just drastically change it in ways that have remarkably profound impacts on the game. They recently added global anti-heal that scales with in game time, to replace anti-heal as a purchasable item in game. I can't speak for how it impacted the meta, but these changes seriously impacted the games total player count and it continues to drop. 

     Instead of reverting or altering these changes in any way, they instead seem to be interested in implementing radical changes to their core game mode that has been rarely changed for years. I respect that they want to innovate with their content, but changing foundational things about a game that has been standing strong for years is not the way to go about it. Especially when these changes are causing a mass exodus from the game.

     You can see my playtime and look up my stats in the game. I've played a long time and I haven't played at the highest level of play at any point, but I have done well in the game and have understood the game pretty well for years, and it is clear to me that the game is just not worth investing significant time into as a game to play at a high level. I still think fun can be had, but for me the fun has been dwindling over the past year or so, and I uninstalled the game earlier this year. I hope to see a time when the game is something that I can get back into with my friends, but for now I have to wait and post this review to warn anyone about the ridiculous changes that have been happening, and are continuing to happen to this game.

Paladins is a wonderful game, once you get over the matchmaking algorithm. The system's built-in need to keep your win rate around 50% will put you against some ridiculous opponents, but the game itself is quite amazing! The customizablity of the individual champions, on both asthethic and in-game use, is otherworldly! One can change your champions passives from cards in so many different ways, the combinations reach well within the hundreds of thousands, if not millions of different loadouts. Then, you can change the skin of your champion, the weapon, emotes, sprays, and mounts! The aiming system is easy to get used to, changeable in the options menu for your weapon cursor. My only 2 other big complaints to warn new players of is the passive anti-healing that is in each match (mind you, it's quite high as of May 23rd, 2022) and the amount of money some of the chests to earn cosmetics is a little high.. 
Other than that, this game is a better version of Overwatch, in my opinion, and anyone who plays games in the genre of Overwatch should definitely try Paladins! You won't regret it, I can almost guarantee it!

A game that gets a lot of negativity for being "too much like Overwatch".  A ton of potential ran by a shoddy dev team, it gives an alternative to players looking to escape Overwatch for the time being.  Constant character releases leading to constant balance issues, no maps or new modes, and a stale ranked queue.  And at the same time, bombarding you with MTX in a poorly designed UI.  Looking past all of the issues the talent/loadout system for all characters can make your gameplay unique but there are definitely meta builds per patch that could be better than any other combo.  And a playerbase, when coming from more "competitive" games, that can make you look like a god when you're up against them.

Is it fun?  Sure.  But it is wasted potential in its own way and a damn shame.

Looks like despite the years Hi-Rez still has no idea what they want to do with this game. Which isn't bad at all as it means they're still adding and changing things. As of the game itself: All of their games have this feeling of perfect mediocrity - they're not amazing but also aren't bad at all in the attempt to take their own slice out of the cake that was a popular multiplayer genre at the time.

Their own idea on hero shooter is pretty good. We have multiple very distinct champions both gameplay and theme wise. Playstyle is customizable with the card-loadout system and even in-game with an item shop so you can adapt to the situation on the map. Maps are diverse in both length and verticality which has to be taken into account when picking champions as some will not feel as good on certain maps. Multiple game modes from standard capture and push cart to just a deathmatch...overall there is stuff to do, try out, learn or tinker with combining into quite complex but accessible experience if you wish to get the bottom of it. Of course mind you it's all PvP and it comes with all its innate quirks. No direct solo play although match-made AI games and shooting range are available.
This game [i]has[/i] a universe and lore, however, the game is not very good at showing it or directing to sources of it...unless champion Bio and trailers is all there is.

While I truly cannot put my claw on what prevents this game from being truly amazing or making me want to stay for longer than a few days before another longer break I do can point a one major flaw I can see. This would be its business model. It's not P2W, you can't buy power here and the cosmetic customization is greatly developed (announcer packs, death cards, login screens, mounts and so much more aside regular skins) not even mentioning them not being afraid to try all the themes and tastes (even furries, yes :3). The problem is how it's all organized. There are very few items you can get by a direct purchase. A lot of things are limited/exclusive, bound to battle passes and majority of the other cosmetic content is packed into multiple RNG chests so you have to buy multiple chests and hope you will roll the right skin out of 10 within it. 
It becomes a real problem if you only want 1 item and would mind rolling any other and the fact that you can't have duplicates therefore being able to "milk" the loot pool doesn't really help matters. Similar issue is with payed bundles - they contain lots of things but you may be interested in only 1. I swear I'd spend more if I could directly get things I'd like to possess to have my little ultimate profile and/or a preferred skin for each champion I like to play...but then I had say "meh" and not waste my budget on spinning the wheel...IF I could spin the wheel for certain items because as mentioned some are very scarcely available for no good reason. I can only think of impulse buying because "you will lose the opportunity" (and thus all that dragon/furry-bait goes to waste, your loss Hi-Rez :p).

Alright, that took a little too long. If cosmetics matter is irrelevant to you and you seek something different from Overwatch or TF2 you sure should see if it's up your alley. It's pretty good and enjoyable even if not that spectacular feeling overall...how do you call things like this... good/fine wood? It's not stiff though :3

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

Paladins is one of those games I wish we had a Maybe option for.

It's fun. It's a lot like overwatch (which has better maps tbh) but matchmaking is so much faster so you're always able to find a game, and when you get a balanced game its a lot of fun, and the optimization is top notch. Like I've seen less graphically intense games demand more CPU and GPU power than this, so yeah this thing will probably run on a potato too which is a point above overwatch.

Ignoring the F2P bullshit microtransactions (thankfully all cosmetic sans heroes) this game is riddled with matchmaking problems. You will almost never have a match you look back on and say "both teams were evenly balanced" you'll either be slaughtering everyone like a pro gamer in a pub stomp with a high coordinated team, or getting pub stomped by pro gamers as your team of nooblets rage quits around you leaving you with bots. OH and you can't just leave a match without fully closing the game... It's like they know rage quits are gonna happen and chose to make leaving a match require you to close the game as the solution instead of fixing the matchmaking, but its still more convient to close the damn game and relaunch it than it is to put up with awful unbalanced matchmaking that gives me flashbacks of high school jocks v nerds dodgeball. But if you can put up with that (I can some days) this game is a lot of fun. If you can't put up with bad match making you're gonna end up speed balling your controller or mouse through your TV/monitor.

about the only game i play at this point, game is consistently updated, new characters,  mechanic reworks, and so on. You got competitive modes and casual, it's a chill game and matches are relativity quick if you just want to burn some time.

It's clunky. It doesn't feel rewarding to get a kill or even to land a shot. Yeah it's free to play but there's  just a lot of small details they could fix to make the game better. Balancing isn't great either.

Overall Review - 9/10
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
Review...
I first got this game because I was tired of playing Overwatch with the same hero's and same maps every game. I got this expecting a trash Overwatch knock off but was actually surprised to find out the opposite. This game is arguably better than Overwatch in a lot of ways. I feel like a lot of the characters are more fun to play than Overwatch this game gets way more updates than Overwatch and also siege mode (payload) is better made than Overwatch. Siege really highlights what makes this game better than Overwatch. With payload spawning in the middle of a mirrored map and teams fighting over control to be able to push it into their spawn feels a lot more balanced and fun than Overwatch. Also 5 v 5 feels a lot better than 6 v 6 and the card system and in game shop add enough verity to have a different experience when you want it
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
Downfalls...
Graphically this game is not as good as Overwatch it feels a little less polished than it with some textures looking a little worse than I would like. Also because its free to play you are gonna spend a lot of time saving up the in game currency to buy champions. They will take you a while to grind out which isn't very fun but the game is free to play so hard to complain about that.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
You Wont Like This Game If...
You don't like learning new more complex systems compared to Overwatch. Its much more difficult to play ranked because it takes a long time to get the required amount of champions in order to be eligible for ranked.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
Value: 9/10
This game is free so give it a try as for how well the game is made its definitely worth a play. The only things that take away from the value is the in game grind for some of the champions is annoying but they are all purchasable for free.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
Final Thoughts...
Paladins is a great game and its free to play so there really isn't a reason to give it a try. As long as you can look past the minor imperfections with the textures and graphics, don't mind learning some of the card system and the in match shop and don't mind grinding for champions you'll have a great time playing it.

I'm sad this game is judged so harshly by it's distant cousin from Blizzard. It's not as polished, as Overwatch, sure. But it is updated WAY more, than Overwatch. The champions are diverse and KEEP COMING!

By my example: As healer main I fail to see such creativity in supports. And they're not the only ones!

The game evolves as much, as it is allowed to. Tries it's very best. Give it a shot - it's worth it!

Cons? Oh, obviously it's not perfect. Some bugs, problems happen during the game, but where they don't happen? Toxicity? It's a PvP game - toxicity is bound to happen. And it's still less, than some more successful shooters! Way less!

So pull up a chair and try!

Paladins is a free game. So what do you expect? Well, to be honest, Paladins delivers when it comes to being a free game. Diverse champion selection, tons of play styles, a talent and card system to customize, with in-match items to boot.... There's quite a bit here to assess. 

Here's a few positives: For one, the amount of selection allows room to main not just one character, but find multiple that you consider fun. Every category of Champion has a unique cast, where, chances are, you'll find yourself liking at least one character per category. The skins are cool, with the majority being high-quality with unique voice acting. Not all are the best, but many fit themes really well and the game is starting to shine with crossovers, despite the many years of development before. Old features and maps are being re-done and improved, bringing life to boring situations. There's a bunch of out-of-game customization with a profile and the like, so those willing to spend can further adjust their gameplay. But most of all, there are VERY little P2W features, with the only one being certain skins having harder to see or hear ultimates/abilities. Playing (suffering) with friends is a blast, where you actually feel skilled when winning certain matches. The toxicity isn't too high in matches compared to more popular AAA titles. Most recently, Paladins has been giving more to F2P players, lowering the prices of passes and bringing back ways to get free crystals with only partially tedious tasks. The lag isn't too bad, where most encounters don't end in a machine-shotgun Buck who can't damage anyone or anything. I already mentioned the champion customization, but you can truly make something special with certain characters. Healers can play damage, Tanks can play Flank, and so on. Such benefits alone give Paladins strong ground.

But, as there are positives, there are negatives. There is a surplus of bugs every patch, where the patch notes even contradict what was in the game. Certain talent adjustments don't make it past the PTS for months. Patches aren't very spread apart, however, most bugs end of remaining for over a month or two due to there only being a midpatch per major update. Balance is a constant struggle, and certain champions are blatantly better than others, without much being done to fix those problems. (Aegis Fernando is a great example) While some champions get constant attention with skins and balance like Maeve, others get little to no love at all despite low play rates, such as Moji. (This is why picking multiple mains is important) The devs aren't very open with the community or feedback, as previously stated, specific issues and changes don't happen for a solid while. New champions are always either overpowered or underpowered, without much of a between until around 3 updates later. The servers just decide to die from time to time, where the game will be rendered unplayable for a few days. Crashes are random but common, especially on lower-end PCs. The in-game VGS is mostly used for sarcasm or to spam "Push the Payload!" to a 150 health Flank.

Despite so many issues, I still find a ton of fun on Paladins. I genuinely enjoy a large part of the cast and have boatloads of fun with friends. For a free game, I found myself spending more time on it than the majority of AAA games I have played. A must-try for sure, especially if you can invite a friend with you to learn together.

Paladins is a Multiplayer Online Class Based FPS centered around team strategy and item management. Coming out near the time of Overwatch’s release detremented Paladins immensely for its primary years. However, ever since the decline of Overwatch updates in and around late 2019 to early 2020, I’ve been opting to play Paladins instead more often than not. The characters are engaging and unique, each having specific gameplay functions and skills to use against foes. The online modes are mostly fun, yet Siege, the “main” gamemode, falls a little flat and has become boring and repetitive over my time playing the game. Team Deathmatch and Onslaught really highlight the main selling points of this game. Less focused on team play and more focused on individual skill, these modes are the most fun and make me feel less forced into the stereotypical tank and healer roles I normally play.

I love this game. I play it a lot. However, there is a lot about the game that puts a terrible taste in my mouth. I know I probably shouldn't be printing out pictures of Maeve and eating them, but they do taste terrible. On top of that, I have other issues.

- "Give Us Your Money!" - In this game, it'll cost you around $8 to open a chest. Fine, it's a free to play game, you can have microtransactions, but consider this: That $8 gets you enough gems for one cool chest (+ a little extra gems). That one chest could have like a 1 in 193 chance or something like that to get the skin you want. You don't get it, so you buy another. $16. If you are a whale, you could throw in another 8. Adds up to $24. This stacks up incredibly fast, you likely nexer get what you want, and you just sit there, sad, with skins for characters you don't use. The battlepass? $15. The things on the battlepass aren't even worth $15 in my opinion. It's extremely underwhelming, only has 30 levels, most of the content is stickers and boosters, and the amount of gems, the one thing you should be excited to finally get, is microscopic. This game has a worse case of shameless money hungry whale-targeting than Genshin Impact.

- Bugs - This game has an amount of bugs that shouldn't even exist. We've reported them for years, and it feels like nothing is done about them. While I personally have gotten pretty lucky, my friend has struggled with the bugs a lot, and after looking at what other players have to say about them, they seem very common. The bug I hate the most, while it is pretty small, is the fact that notifications are busted. After every match, I don't get notified of how much I earned that game, I get told how much I earned for the entirety of my play session. Or, when I level up on the battlepass, I get notified not only for what I have received (rare because I am free to play), I get notified for every previous tier as well, EVEN THOUGH I DO NOT HAVE THE BATTLEPASS.

- Dev Support - Support for this game seems nonexistent. We get updates, but as I stated before, bugs are often going unfixed, support tickets are ignored, and all in all, the game feels like a husk with no heart poured into it. I love the characters, the skins look great, I'm excited for the next Siege: Beyond, because it genuinely looks cool, but the fact that the devs don't seem to care about problems the playerbase has really taints the game for me. Just some interaction with the playerbase, some communication, some transparency, realness, ANYTHING, would make me feel better about the game. Do something about cheaters. Stop scamming us with absurd prices. Fix the bugs. GIVE ME MY HORSE THAT I AM SUPPOSED TO GET FOR LINKING MY YOUTUBE AND SUBSCRIBING TO YOU? Just do something. Make this game better for us all.

In summary, this game is amazing. I love it and play it every day with at least one of my friends. I have plagued my group with it, and practically begged them to play it with me, and we've had a lot of fun since. I just feel that the game is in the wrong hands. Being free to play seems to also hurt it quite a bit. I mean the in-app purchases are wildly unfair. I want to enjoy this game and be proud of playing it. I would spend SOOO much money on it if I felt like the developers were people I wanted to support. The game is great. Love it. The devs don't make me feel valued as a player. For the same reason I despise a certain mobile gacha game, it's hard for me to recommend this game to others. Hopefully things turn around soon. Excited for Lillith, peace.

I know what you are thinking - isn't this just Overwatch, but ordered from Wish? And yes, you'd be right. But sometimes you actually find a pretty good deal that meets your needs, even if it is rough around the edges.

Paladins has a lot going for it - easy to learn; diverse characters with unique abilities; low tech requirements; and post-game trash talk all at the low price of nothing. As a casual MOBA FPS, it hits the right notes more often than not

Standard F2P model, with in-game currency allowing you to access more characters and some skins. Sadly it's pretty clear that most of the development time is goes towards cosmetics and skins. But that is just Hi-Rez following the trends, like if a Mad-Catz controller became its own publisher. 

The game itself hasn't really evolved much, despite a consistent stream of new characters. Adding more doesn't help the game if you are also not addressing existing balancing or matchmaking concerns.

The loadout system is quite unique and allows for interesting alternative playstyles for each character, but the item system needs a serious rework. Beginners, turn-off autobuy immediately and just read a quick community guide instead for item and loadout builds. It will save you a lot of frustration and grief.

Overall, I think it is good game to play if you are searching for decent MOBA experience. It's fun, and that's all you can hope for really. But given the declining player base, if you'd rather just keep playing TF2, SMITE, or literally any other MOBA, no one would blame you.

This is my review of the game. Copyright goes to me.

While I was HEAVILY steered away from trying out this game by friends, I went ahead and did so anyway. I am an AVID Over Watch player with over hundreds of hours, Mainly focusing on Support. I always heard "Paladins is an Over Watch Ripoff" and, to be fair, I believed it from what I've seen up to the point before I played the game. I first played the game in 2020 on my Xbox, I quickly stopped playing and didn't touch it again. Now fast forward to 2022, I decided to try the game again and installed it on my computer. Now before I start talking about my experience with the game, let me quickly say why I chose to play the game. Now I don't want to be that "guy" who constantly compares this game with another, but that's how I was familiar with this game. I was very tired and worn out "not to mention bored", of playing Over Watch. No new content, no maps, dwindling community, and toxicity. I know very well that a lot of people feel the same way about this game, but to me, this is fresh. The amount of playable characters this game has is OBNOXIOUS. And I LOVE it. It can be very intimidating and confusing to start, but with the help of YouTube videos (shout out to FrostFangs for being my favorite so far, along with PGG", I learned a lot about the champions and their abilities. I was so excited about learning about new champions, what they did, how to do it, when to execute it, how to counter specific champions, and when to run away like crazy. And I love how the game is fun and the developers put fun/weird things in the game. The story is interesting so far, and I like how with the release of a new Champion, they expand on it. I can go ON AND ON about this, but let me wrap this up. While I will always love and play Over Watch. this is an exciting new game and adventure for me. I am not one of those people who nit-pick at things from games, I like to play and enjoy the game, and this brought everything I have been seeking in a game. I apologize if I was all over the place, but the conclusion is... THIS GAME IS FUN. Thanks for anyone who ever reads this :D (Also, why would you read all of this? Loser).

With Peace and Love,
Smug Korra

The little brother to Team Fortress 2.

The poor man’s Overwatch.

Paladins is certainly a lesser version of its more competitive and skill based counterparts.  But it is certainly unique and enjoyable as a hero shooter.

In 2022 the game is already old news.  But if your region still has an active playerbase, give it a try if you’re on the fence.

I’ve been playing since day zero.  Twitchcon 2015 in San Diego, where Paladins had its own booth.  I remember playing as the original Barik.  Who could snipe enemies from across the map with his blunderbuss.

The game modes have shifted greatly over Paladin’s lifespan.  And some heroes have received massive overhauls.

My favorite role, tanks, seem to be in a poor state.  Unable to create space because many of them are non-threatening with severely diminished abilities, no presence, and lackluster damage output.

I still go back once every couple of years to play in Masters and see if anyone I knew is still around.  But the game does get old since matchmaking can be a painful 15-20 minute wait during peak hours and non-existent outside of that.

The game is a tactical hero shooter, there are more than 40 champions which you play on different maps in mostly a 5v5 mode with mostly two Tanks, one Damage Dealer, one Flank and one support. This may sound similar to Overwatch, but as someone who has >1000 hours in both games I can guarantee you it feels totally different, but why is that?

Paladins lets you customize your champions extremly much, not only through skins, each champion has 3 talents which change the way you play the champion. As an example you can have a look at Io. One of the talents Io has allows the champion to not only heal with one of her abilites, now her placable Fox Luna heals allies in a certain radius.
Furthermore there are card who you can use to create different loadouts for each champion. Those loadouts change the playstile extremly much. For example with the right loadout you can play a Support like Jenos like a Damage Dealer.

Recent issues with the game were mostly the developers, who appearently did not care about the game and forgot to fix bugs and laggs. This has changed recently though. Paladins recieved tons of new content  recently, for example map reworks and new heroes, who are really fun to play.

A money pit designed to be a money pit. It's extremely difficult to gain money in game without purchasing it with real money, and it becomes a grind otherwise. Just to CHANGE YOUR NAME, you need to grind out 400 gems. You get 25 if you log on every day for a week. That means you need to log on every day for FOUR MONTHS, just to change your name. Or, you could pay 15 dollars to get that amount of gems. My friend set my profile name to his gamertag because my steam account was logged into his computer, he wanted to try out paladins, and didnt realize he wasnt on his own steam account. My name is permanently now "meowmeowkibble" and I have no way of changing it for the next three months or so (Yes, you can laugh at me, it's pretty damn funny tbh). I'm not even getting into the thirst traps in this game, either. The gameplay is fun, but the practices are so scummy that it isnt worth it if you arent already into the gameplay. Don't get this game.

Let me start by saying that I am quite an hardcore, competitive player and that my review is mostly directed to players wanting to play Ranked. Other than on Steam, I have also played Paladins for more than two years on Xbox One (1600+ hours) and Nintendo Switch. I achieved the highest rank in the game multiple times during Season 4 (Peaked in Top 20 Grandmaster players on EU server, playing Support/Flex) so you can say I quite comprehend the competitive nature of the game.

As of right now, the game is in one of the worst states it has ever been, and it will never change.
There are absolutely 0 reason to starting playing the game in 2022 as it will just continue to get buggier and worse every patch, as it has been for the last 3 years.
I will now go in depth on why I think this, if you have never played Paladins and were thinking about making it your main competitive game, dont do it, its actual garbage.

Good things about Paladins:
-The core gameplay design is unique and objectively functional, at least in theory.
-It is quite easy to run even on budget PCs...

Bad things about Paladins:
-...but it is also incredibly bad optimized with (at least in my case) low GPU and CPU usage and unstable frame rate all around. (I have a Ryzen 5 3500x and a RX 580, Overwatch runs WAY better with also better graphics)
-Servers are garbage. They have always been like this and HiRez doesnt give a fuck about it. Servers often randomly crash and not even the Ping counter works. There are times where playing very mobile champions become a nightmare thanks to incredible delay some matches have.
-The champion balance team clearly doesnt know how the game works.
-Blatant cheaters take literal MONTHS to get banned and more soft aimbotters or wallhackers will never get caught unless some people snitch on them, the anticheat doesnt exist at all.
-Leavers and toxic players are everywhere.
-The monetization system is bad (Chests are pricey gacha and in general skins can cost quite a lot to get)
-The matchmaking feels like its random (both in casual and ranked), Golds get sorted in Grandmaster lobbies and you can often see completely new players in the same match as world champions.
-Lots of the new champions and skins are non other than overly sexualised women with even some soft-porn voicelines.
(For instance, they took a furry character from the game and created a genderbent and incredibly sexualised version of it, which you were forced to see as a "Enemy Death Card" cosmetic every time you died, wtf).
-Public figures representing the game are often in scandals.
-Bugs, the game is bugged, the code is spaghetti, every new patch bugs keep getting worse and worse (with even some game breaking ones being in the game for literal months)
-The Ranked system is actually infuriating: other than the RNG matchmaking, you can easily cheat your way up to the highest ranks and NEVER being banned, and im not joking. The servers have 0 DDOS protection, so you can literally crash the matches you are losing using just a shitty IP stresser you can find online for free, and so achieving any rank with only a very small probability of getting banned. This is what the community calls "drophack" and will NEVER be fixed, its 6 years it is in the game and Hirez never even tries to do anything anymore. My literal $10 minecraft server has better DDOS protection if anyone was interested.
-There are times my game randomly crashes or cant even be opened, resulting in an EasyAnticheat error. Its been years it is like that and even after changing PC it keep happening.

Dont play this garbage, dont support the greedy corporation that destroyed this game trying to monetize more. The game will never get better.

While I was HEAVILY steered away from trying out this game by friends, I went ahead and did so anyway. I am an AVID Overwatch player with over hundreds of hours, Mainly focusing on Support. I always heard "Paladins is an Overwatch Ripoff" and, to be fair, I believed it from what I've seen up to the point before I played the game. I first played the game in 2020 on my Xbox, I quickly stopped playing and didn't touch it again. Now fast forward to 2022, I decided to try the game again and installed it on my computer. Now before I start talking about my experience with the game, let me quickly say why I chose to play the game. Now I don't want to be that "guy" who constantly compares this game with another, but that's how I was familiar with this game. I was very tired and worn out  "not to mention bored", of playing Overwatch. No new content, no maps, dwindling community, and toxicity. I know very well that a lot of people feel the same way about this game, but to me, this is fresh. The amount of playable characters this game has is OBNOXIOUS. And I LOVE it. It can be very intimidating and confusing to start, but with the help of Youtube videos (shout out to FrostFangs for being my favorite so far, along with PGG", I learned a lot about the champions and their abilities. I was so excited about learning about new champions, what they did, how to do it, when to execute it, how to counter specific champions, and when to run away like crazy. And I love how the game is fun and the developers put fun/weird things in the game. The story is interesting so far, and I like how with the release of a new Champion, they expand on it. I can go ON AND ON about this, but let me wrap this up. While I will always love and play Overwatch. this is an exciting new game and adventure for me. I am not one of those people who knick-pick at things from games, I like to play and enjoy the game, and this brought everything I have been seeking in a game. I apologize if I was all over the place, but the conclusion is... THIS GAME IS FUN. Thanks for anyone who ever reads this :D (also why would you read all of this? loser)

This may be the worst game I have played in 12 years

If you are looking for a team based shooter, forget that this title exists. 

I have never seen a game in my entire life, that punishes players who pick support characters.
How come that they include an "anti-healing" mechanic? Before the game even starts, I already have 30% anti-healing and it goes up by time, I do less and less healing it is just frustrating.

My team is not able to contest the objective if my anti-healing reached 90% by the end of the game? Ying's illusions do 8 healing in the late game, 8 healing?! What am I supposed to do with that? It doesnt heal anyone, it keeps my colleagues on life support! I bet in 2 years, they'll put the anti-healing limit to 120%, where my pure presence in the game causes harm to my team.

>You think you can turn the match around by just getting good at this game? Absolutely not, because the more you play the less you heal and that's not even the worst part of that "game".

>There are champions which are completely overpowered, That snake-dragon thing, that rolls like a Droideka
has what? 5000 - 6000 health points and is able to cover the entire are close to the objective in fire? Good luck competing against that. Because I am 100% sure, that it takes reduced damage, like the other tanks. 
Don't even bother to fight it with your team, because you wont receive healing anyway.

>Champs are overpowered? Well, either that or they are completely useless like Furia. What am I supposed to do with a gun, that deals 120 damage? Even the bots in the game will laugh at you. Of course Ying, another support hero deals 500 damage. Seems logical.

>Next annoying aspect is, that they have the worst menu sound design. Everytime I switch menu a different music starts playing. Oh nice, yes I would like to listen to Monstercat everytime I select anything except the title screen.

>Don't even get me started on the skins...

Play Team Fortress 2 or Overwatch, basically anything else has better optimized mechanics than this.

Now, I'm writing this right before I unlock competitive, But I want to just give my review from my 100 hours on casual. 

I feel like this game gets a lot of hate it doesn't deserve. The devs put a lot of hard work into the characters, and it shows. In my time of playing from when I first got it on steam, 2 characters have been released and A third is releasing next Thursday. It's not a lack of development, and It's not bad choices. I have never malded due to pay to win, or seen it at all, and some metas just exist. 

The community, atleast in casual, is great. Usually they're willing to communicate, and the quick chat works great for quick situations and getting people's attention. I've met one toxic person, and they were just having a really bad day (Ended up going 0/7 when everyone else had a kill xd)

I get bored of games quick, but this game keeps having stuff to have come back to. New decks, new champions, new metas, new duo strategies(Play this game with a friend!!!). I'm unable to reminisce about the good old days of paladins, but I can certainly say that this is my favorite game so far in 2022.

This game used to be great! but the devs are slowly trying to weed out everything that made the game fun and unique to fit the broadest demographic possible. They are over saturating the game with champions and refusing to fix the ones that are over powered and broken.

Let's talk about anti heal! The anti heal system that was implemented last year i feel worked rather well, with the price of the card lowered along with the amount of anti heal that is dealt. It was a must have card and was sort of, built into the the game meta but you did not always need it. However, the recent changes have left the anti heal ability to be passive throughout the match for everybody to intentionally make matches artificially shorter. Matches before could go from anywhere between 10-20 minuets but now matches go from 5-10 minuets. 

The game has turned into an absolute spam fest with most of the new champions having obscenely powerful abilities with very few ways to counter them. This game is a mess now and the devs are to blame. 

I honestly cannot recommend the game in it's current state. This is the first time i have uninstalled it from my computer since starting two years ago. If the devs truly care about the game, they will address the issues at hand instead of adding fat, politically correct characters that are awful to look at and fight against.

Edit:

I originally had a lengthy review at a previous time but it was deleted, so I simplified it and made the above. As I see this review has gotten attention recently I have decided to elaborate and condense my original review.  I haven't played the game for many months but I stand by my original thoughts from that time:

The staff responsible for the art, models and character creation are clearly beyond competent and good at their job. The issue is that there had been no gameplay tweaks for over a year at the time, game modes were removed, features were removed with no alternatives in place no new maps and matchmaking was terrible. The inability or unwillingness to address griefing and AFK players ruined the experience of many matches. This combined with a lack of any interest from the development team to address these issues has resulted in a stagnant game that's more concerned with selling cosmetics than doing anything to grow the community which is a true shame because the mechanics are great and the game is genuinely enjoyable. 

So if the devs don't care, why should you?

Edit: I remember playing this game when it was still in beta, and the game has come a long way since then.
Paladins has some great upsides and some obvious downsides. I'm comparing it to Overwatch, as i had over 500 hours in overwatch. The game has a wealth of champions, much more diversity with only a couple champions feeling the same. The loadouts and talents as well as the items you can buy allow you to change certain aspects of a character to fit your playstyle, and i love it. The rigidity of Overwatch characters got stale after enough time, and this game allows you to change things up how you want to. The real problem comes from AFK players and hackers, no real punishment for leaving and in my 100 hours since comeing back i have played against at least 2 hackers in Normal non-competitive gameplay.

I have put entirely too much of my life into this stupid game. 

there's a lot of tangential bullsh*t that comes with the package, like bugs, lag, balance issues, bugs, occasionally braindead dev decisions, and more bugs, but the core gameplay is so darn good that i just can't bring myself to hate it. 

This is a team-based MOBA shooter that gives you a ton of characters, abilities, talents, and customizations to play with. There are oodles of builds, meme strats, and team comps to try, and the gameplay loop never feels like it devolves into the shoot, get instagibbed, respawn, repeat hellhole that games like TF2 and overwatch tend to end up with. 

All of the classes are fun to play too. Tanks are fun, healers are fun, dmg is fun... the skins cosmetics are also top quality, with most skins getting entirely new body models and voice packs.

Download it.

This game has so much potential, but falls flat, because the executives don't want the developers to release new maps or gamemodes. They remove UI elements such as 3rd person, POTG and death replay, because they are "too buggy". Your job as a developer is to fix the bugs not remove the thing that caused the bugs, that means you have failed as a game developer. Unless the thing was gamebreaking, there is no reason to remove it.

But why is the game losing players? Because new champions are not good content, we want good gamemodes like payload and literally anything that isn't siege (siege is hot garbage that gets boring after 2 games). And no, siege unleashed or whatever the fuck it's called, is not good, it's shit and boring, just give us fucking payload. But no, instead, they decide to release new champions constantly to keep the money rolling in, but they could make the game good and get more money in the long run, but Hi-rez has this thing called "The Hi-rez effect" where they don't have faith in the game and abandon it after like a year of development. Prime example is Realm Royale. This shit was getting top charts on twitch and it was amazing, but unfinished. We didn't really care because we had a hot mess called PUBG as a game (and we all know how buggy that game was). Then they went ahead and made absolute dogshit changes that made the game unfun to play and instead of reverting the changes, they decided to go with it while the game was losing players. Then when the game was dying they started adding microtransactions into the game like there's no tomorrow. Now realm royale is just a corpse, dead, literally no one plays it anymore. 
If they don't start taking risks and you know, actually start doing something with their games, Paladins is going to suffer the same fate realm royale did. Don't get me wrong, I love the game, but this is fucking ass. This game could be a serious competitor against tf2 as a class based shooter, but the executives don't care, they only care about money they make right now on the spot, without realizing that hi-rez could become a really big company by just taking a few risks. Smite makes you enough money to fund development for other games, but instead, they are copying Blizzard and adding in more microtransactions and making absolutely no good content (unless it makes them money).

In short: Paladins is dying, Hi-rez is greedy and doesn't care, this game is going to become another realm royale if they don't do anything about the playercount.

Previously I said I like the game, it's still fun to play, but this game has a bug that makes it unplayable and today is the 3rd time ive experienced it.

Basically you load into a match, select a hero and then it loads the game, nobody successful loads, you are taken back to the pick screen, where people can communicate (its especially bad cuase theres one guy who shouts into his mic and you cant mute it because muting doesnt work in the pick screen for whatever reason) but nothing happens, you cant leave, youre just stuck there. If you relaunch the game, it takes you to load the match again and then it takes you to the main menu after like 2 minutes, then you cant do anything in the main menu... like no buttons work, cant exit, everything is unuseable. 

Shit experience, if the gameplay wasnt enjoyable, id drop this game but i have a lot of fun with it. I will gladly change the review once this 2 YEAR OLD BUG has been fixed.

Well, after almost a 1000 hours over the course of 2+ years, and getting a tattoo relating to the game, I should probably recommend Paladins.

Paladins was my first ever FPS, and I fell in love with it. I've met a lot of people through the community, and strengthened already existing friendships. The graphics and character design is enjoyable, and the gameplay itself is also fun. They have slowly started to rework older maps, which is bringing them up to the newer ones visually. But I must also agree that the name ''Bugadins'' is deserved. For a free to play game though, it is still very much playable and enjoyable, even with the hiccups.

This game updates frequently with new champions, so getting bored isn't too much of an issue. Some new character abilities are a bit repetitive, but often make up for it in the big picture of each champion. The balancing works out well in ranked, as each team gets to ban 3 champions. This makes it easier for you make the match adapt to your teams' playstyle. And as each champion comes with 3 talents to choose from, you can really play how you like, even hopping the lines between roles sometimes. The game doesn't put a limit on how a team must be formed (apart from meta), so it's even possibly for the whole team to choose the same role. This kind of freedom isn't seen so often with similar FPS games.

Overall, if you want a fun, free FPS game to try out with your friends, I'd highly recommend Paladins.

As much as I like the characters, the gameplay and some of the maps, I can't recommend it, purely because the overwatch design philosophy is trash. Yes, hero shooters are fun. No, having a second guy healing the guy you should have been able to kill is not fun. And they're aware of that fact because they've changed the anti-heal item to being a permanent addition to the game, instead of, y'know, reworking how anti-fun healers are and how the game should not revolve around someone who kinda isn't playing the game just making everyone else immortal unless you're the most cracked shot you could possibly be. Healers in Smite are actually balanced and fun to play around, because they don'T fucking burst heal an entire healthbar in one button press, they just add sustain to the fight.

Tanks are also not fun, you kinda just don't deal enough damage to kill them. In TF2 the heavy is a fun character to play against because you can actually kill him and he can actually kill you. In Paladins/Overwatch, a tank is just kinda there for you to empty your entire kit and mag on and still not kill him, and he can sometimes kill you but not really, they don't really deal any damage because that would be broken. So you essentially just have a fat kid to bully who happens to make it very hard for you to play the game normally. In Smite the tanks serve a purpose, they pushed the frontline up and bully the backline so your team can deal their damage without getting instaggibed. You can't kill them, they can't kill you, but they don't stop you from playing the game, they just make you play differently. Not at all the case with shield tanks, and especially not the case if they're backed by a healer.

Also the "minor" gripe of the game being filled with tiny characters that keep jumping over your head. It's not that hard to deal with but playing against 5 genjis is not my idea of a good game.

So yeah. Game would be extremely good if it wasn't trying to be overwatch, because the characters are fun to play as, but they're not fun to play against, so fuck this.

If I would listen to myself at the moment I wright that comment, I would give a negative vote, but the fact is that despite seeing the game going down and down updates after updates, I still love it. But I think that if it continues that way I probably won't touch it anymore. What's the problem (in my opinion) ? Well...

 The role of support/healer is hard in that game, not that the champ themselves are hard to play (actually most of them are quite easy to take in hand) but because of the impact of the flanks champ. I mean yeah, killing the supp is one of their job, but do we really need more OPAF flanks right now ? If the enemy team has a good skye for example, 1/2 times the game is over. Some flanks are quite balanced, like some are ridiculously easy to play and have a way too big potential and impact when you compare to how easy to play they are.

Until quite recently, playing tank was IMPOSSIBLE due to people making only dps with healers, and that was caused by a perk that sooo much players were complaining about for years : Anti-heal (I mean the one that you buy while in game, because the few heroes that have anti heal on their spells are not so powerful to me)

 This perk was horrible, I think that a lot of people would agree on that point, and the fact that they removed it from the game could be a proof. So what ? Now that AH is no more, healers are healing ? Yes ! Tanks are surviving and the role is enjoyable ? Yes ! Then everything is okay about that ? Ahahaha, would be too easy, don't you think ?

 Yes, the perk anti heal was removed... Until one day a dev was thinking "Yeah, it´s big brain time !" and decided that now, Anti Heal would be a passive ability FOR EVERY CHARACTERS that increases in strength with the time of the game... I just have a question about that... Seriously ? Healing was not complicated enough that now every champ can ruin your job ? I REALLY hope that it's just a test and that they won't keep it because it's the worst update I've seen since I started to play that game (I have "only" 45 hours on Steam but I also played a lot on PS4)

And you know what's the most painful about that ? It's that I hate talking bad about Paladins because the game is really good, it has a huge potential and you can have so much fun with it. I hoped that some of the skins would be available differently than by paying (some are, but not much) but well it's only cosmetics and the game is free, that's normal that they want to make money somehow. 

So in conclusion, we have here a really good game, I just hope that they will listen to the community about that because at that point, they could also remove the support heroes that would not make much of difference (I overeact a bit, i know)

a wonderful game that I think should be tried by anyone whose played a competitive FPS. 

the characters are very diverse and the game has so much counterplay because of items you can buy mid round. cards are also a way the game introduces ways to tailor a champion the way you want them to be. do you want to maybe invest a lot into this one skill you really like using? you can center your build around that, and I think that is absolutely amazing. the game has so much depth, and I think it's crazy because at the surface it looks like some ugly mobile game.

I do seriously think the game is on a timer though, it doesn't have that big of a playerbase and it's absolutely ridden with bugs, like, an obscene amount. I think that if they stopped releasing a new champion like every month and just worked on the game at it's core, fixing all it's bugs and implementing new features/maps to draw players in would do it some good. and they definitely gotta work on their balancing, which in all honesty is better than most games i've played, but the way they do things is really frustrating, sometimes unneeded nerfs happen that can really devastate a champion.

I really do think evilmojo/Hi-Rez have a goldmine on their hands, and they either don't know it, or just don't care. In the right hands this IP could've come close to rival even something as titanic as valorant. I really hope they open their eyes someday, maybe the games code is too  incoherent at this point for much to be done, and I can accept that to a degree. If Paladins got a clean slate with a sequel, I genuinely do think it could become one of the greats.

Dear Hi-Rez. All players know how much you hate supports. But this time you have outdone yourself. 90% cauterize at 10 minutes, provided that games last on average longer than 15, and scaling starts from standing at the base from the very first second of being in the match. You are dooming support players to a miserable existence for more than half of the game. Why not remove supports altogether? And tanks at the same time. Why add more heals to supports if it will eventually come down to 10% of the total by the middle of the match. 
This game does not need magical abilities and healing, because it's a shooter. Let's go together along the path of becoming the coolest shooter like CS:GO and APEX, because there are very few such games, and there are a great many fantasy and colorful ones based on interesting abilities. (sarcasm)
