Look, this game is fun and all but the devs gave up on this game just like everything else they produced. They gave up trying. The game only reached a few seasons and they couldn't come up with anything new or exciting. This isn't my personal preference, this is what a large amount of the community things as well. 

The new champions were just using abilities from older champions and re-skinning them, the balance for this game is nonexistence, there is a surprising lack of diversity in the champions even though that was a attention grab of this game, you will find some champions unique and interesting until you realize there is another champion just like that and can do it much better. 

Back to the balancing. It was so bad. Someone was either terrible or godlike with no in between, it was so bad that the pros chose the same exact champions every single time. Speaking of pros, you will never believe what happened. They canceled their own esports. Yeah, the thing that what majority of players aim for so they could make a living, gone. It wasn't any good anyways and in the online tournaments you could tell all of them were hacking. 

Point being, the devs gave up on this game and its a shame. It is fun to play and the only game that could compete with Overwatch for this style of game. The devs just gave up, stopped listening to the constructive criticism because all they wanted was praise. They wanted it so bad, they made a council of players who had nothing but good things to say about the game and literally told people to k*ll themselves if they didn't like the game. 

Don't get this game. It is a lost cause.

Do not support these developers, because they won't support you in return.

I had an absolute blast with this game, but the more I played the more I cam into contact with the core players who were some of the saltiest, bitter people this side of League of Legends. The game itself is a lot of fun, the matches are a good length, the pool of characters is diverse and give a variety of fun ways to play. The only criticisms I can give here are a lack of game modes - there's only 3 ways to play and only one in ranked, which is pushing the cart. 

When I say I had a blast, I really mean it - I've been super addicted to this game. A game like this lives on its audio, where every tick of a crit, or boom of a kill, is rewarding - and this game does nearly as good a job as overwatch at this. (I will note on a technical level, there is a slight problem with how combat above you sounds like it's right next to you, making it harder to track vertical attacks) When you're popping off on this game, it feels great. The netcode also seems really solid, possibly due to very sizeable hitboxes - there's a lot of projectile weapons but somehow you never feel like you got cheated by lag or failing hitreg, an almost unheard of technical feat.

The game I'm describing is a pretty solid, fun time, and the first few levels were so fun. But then the game decides 'okay you're good enough to join the general population', and now you're in for it. Prepare for racism, homophobia, sexism, and 'ironic' variants of the above. Get ready for insults and trash talk and harassment because you picked the wrong tank or healer, when you were the last to pick and everyone else instalocked dps assassin types, but YOU'RE the problem. I had a game where I was second healer on a team that constantly said they were getting no healing and threatening to report us, spamming 'good game!' 'cancel that!', saying they're throwing because we're throwing, saying okay cya I don't wanna play with these healers (at the end we had a combined 180k healing, an absurdly high amount, and won). This was on casual quick play. Ranked is considerably worse. I did my 5 placement games on ranked, and 4 of them were extreme stress situations, mostly due to my teammate's harassment. Every decision I made was wrong, and I'm constantly second guessing myself or playing stuff I don't know to appease these terrible people. This is also in part due to the bizarrely wide range in the matchmaking for those games - on my fourth placement match someone in the other team had 'season 3 grandmaster' in their title - in what world does someone on their 4th placement match with I think 5 days of playing the game go against that?

The experience of the general population of the game is.. hostile. No-one is having fun. My advice is to not play the game in the first place, so you don't get the initial addiction, so you don't end up there. I hope these people find some solace.
Over 1k hours later, and I still hate this game, still fun tho.

Game is exceedingly buggy. Promises and expectations are broken constantly. Their support feature is atrocious. They close unresolved tickets constantly. For one, I find the need to submit tickets for problems in this game easily 3x more than any other game I've played. And when you do, you get a "please be patient, we may need extra time to get back to you", and if they don't respond quickly enough. They close the ticket on you. They also close the ticket on you when they feel like it randomly between messages. They don't even always tell you when doing this. They don't always give you the items you paid for. And when following through with support tickets for this, they also will just close them mid conversation before resolved. I can even believe that this level of customer experience exists. I am blown away by their not caring to stabalize their game, and their user account website. And by their treatment to users who would have otherwise been fine dealing with the jankiness if they treated you like a decent human. I can ONLY believe this same lack of polish and treatment of their users translates to ALL HiRez games. What an experience!

OH.... and the matchmaking in terms of being well balanced... Yes the developers really know how to balance for an enjoyful experience. I just started this game and I have never ran into a full team of level 300's ... SAID NO MAN EVER. Yes, if you smelt sarcasm you are right. 
On rainy days when you are trying to master a champion, prepare to have level 300 Fernandos' backed up by a master team taunt and laugh at you as they yeet the objective to victory as your team grasps for a single shot on a sweaty bouncing Maeve. Then the whole esports enemy team will leave objective to come up to your base spawn door ready to farm damage of your wretched corpse... until you finally die a noble hero or live long enough to see yourself become an AFK player on spawn until the suffering is over.
It is a wonderful game though. you will enjoy finding and adjusting to your preferred champions. During daytime when fresh meat is on, you'll have an enjoyful experience. But when it reaches after hours when veterans come to play... hide under a table and pray to the Magistrate for balancing to be fixed or stare into the Abyss for eternity.

As I've thought more and played this game more, the less and less I seem to enjoy it. The characters are very linear and don't have a lot of depth most of the time. There are loads of bugs that make the game not very enjoyable, which when paired with the hard CC (e.g., roots) and light CC (e.g., slows), this game makes me quit out of the actual game every match. Matches are a stomp most of the time, either for your side or the other's side. Overall after a bit more time, the lack of a solid story or campaign (the story within this game may as well not exist for how vapid it is at the moment) makes this game plain boring after some time. The horrendous grind for the characters or skins must be expressed, as if you started recently or are wanting to start, I'd highly recommend against this, due to how slow the current system is. 

Simply put, in my opinion there are better alternatives for this sort of genre out on the market like Overwatch (albeit this does cost money), Team Fortress 2, etc.

Decent game, but gets bogged down by bad design decisions.
 It has good pace, the shooting feels decent in some heroes, and terrible in others. Hero design is a hit and miss, with some having a lot of personality in first person, while others feeling cumbersome. Some feel awesome to play, while others feel like you are only sitting idle clicking. It obviously rips off a lot of Overwatch kits, but actually I wish they had ripped the off a lot more, so they'd be more fun to play.
 The card system is actually one of the good design decisions. It allows you to customize how you play. Sadly that's one of the few things done without issues. Maps are way to big, so they had to implement a garish mount (which of course is monetized heavily), and in the siege mode, you have to travel a lot to get back to the fight, maps also lack any personality, if you play one, you've played them all. 
Matchmaking is broken, either you fight against a really bad team, or you are in the extremely bad team, almost never its a fun, well matched game. You barely get any reward for winning or losing a match, and if you want any specific skin, be ready to dish out a lot of money. Overall, I'd say this is the worst part of it all. I could overlook most of the other bad design decisions if I felt like playing was rewarding, or you had any sort of progression. But they had to lock it out behind and absurdly high pay wall.

I decided to install this game because I saw a Vtuber play it (Hololive EN's Amelia Watson).

I used to play Overwatch a LOT, I mean, I had like several hundred hours in the game, got fairly close to hitting GM in S3 and just gradually fell out of love with that game. The balance was whack, and people just didn't die after the turbo healers came out then that reinvented the 3-3 meta (GOATS) that ruined the game for most people you and I probably know.

Something about this game doesn't scream balanced to me, but playing it has been way more enjoyable for me. I used to think this game was a knock-off OW, but playing it is like, I just take my skills from playing Overwatch and Apex (the latter which I still play) and have a blast on fun DPS-centric champions. I'm not sure what it is I like about the game, but it's definitely way more fun than most people will ever know. 

Champs are fun, different, have build expression (something I hate about League, even tho I play it, but love about Dota 2) and I just like the vibes this game gives off. I don't play Smite, I'm not a Hi-Rez fan and I'm still bitter about Tribes. This game is just well-rounded and unironically more fun than OW for a lapsed OW diehard fan. I play a lot of Apex currently, and I just take the tracing skills I get in that game and go on Skye and absolutely fry lobbies, it's so fun. The progression of this review is completely random but playing this game this past week has felt like how coming to terms with Apex replacing PUBG in my life felt, except now it's Paladins replacing Overwatch. And I've actually sold friends on installing and playing with me too, so that's awesome. 

I thought it would be SUUPER grindy to get new champs, but it's honestly not that bad, I've played way grindier (Siege for instance) and I get a new champ a day if I play for like two hours (which is pretty ez considering all my uni classes are online). 

I'm getting off track but, it's just really good. 

Seris/Skye/Zhin/Khan main btw =).

Glad I checked it out. 
Thank you, Axeson (https://twitter.com/walfieee/status/1382570034455842816). 
The Stream: [https://youtu.be/-OIP3bS2x_g]

Paladins is a free-to-play team-based shooter where utilizing abilities to annihilate your enemy is the core mechanic of the game. Your goal is to capture an objective and push a cart to the enemy base to win. Very similar to several hit games of the genre, Team Fortress and Overwatch.  It's a solid competitor on the market and capable of guaranteeing many hours of fun. Honestly, coming from an older player, it's certainly very interesting to see how the game developed over time. 

---{Aesthetics}---
☐ You forget what reality is
☐ Beautiful
☑Good
☐ Decent
☐ Bad
☐ Paint.exe

From an aesthetics standpoint, over the years Paladins has maintained its cartoon-like graphic style. The colourful characters are eye-catching, they're well modeled and easily distinguishable from the background scenery. The characters, map, GUI all compliment the visual style Hi-Rez was going for. All-in-all Paladins offers solid, consistent and appealing graphics. And honestly, with the new map revamps, the aesthetics are consistently improving.

As a MOBA and FPS junky, i'm really impressed by the gameplay. The best part about the gameplay is that Paladins allows you to truly find and choose your playstyle. Whether it's reducing cooldown times on key abilities or increasing the range or duration of your movement, Paladins really allows you to customize your champion in ways no game has ever done before. The only downside is that the newer champions lack creativity in their abilities and some cards are pretty much useless.

Bugs, Bugs. Bugs. The biggest issue and the biggest source of complaint. This game has a sizeable amount of bugs and it seems as if the devs are consistently patching them. Some updates you get these minor bug fixes when the major bugs are just glaring. The biggest issue i see stems from the introduction of new skins and battle-passes which are seemingly prioritized over bug fixes and polishing. That left the game in a pretty sad state. 

PS there's definitely been an improvement.

To sum this up, the community is dead and the only way to play the game is in a five stack since the match making is terrible. 

The game has lost much of its older player base and retains very little of its new players. If your new you will be placed against a lot of smerfs trying to avoid stacks, therefore many new players get wrecked in the early paladins career. If you mange to stay around you will continuously play against the same players; however the problem here is that many of the more experienced players only play in a stack with other experienced players because they are tired of loosing matches due to being the placed in teams with players that throw or are far less experienced. This makes the game impossible to play and enjoy while solo queuing or partying with at least 4 ppl. 

Meanwhile, the rest game feels like the devs have given up. There are many bugs which likely will never be fixed, rather then fix the bugs hirez removes the content causing the bugs like kill cams.  Additionally new content is rare because the devs tend to just slightly alter old features. For instance, there hasn't been a new map release almost 2 years in siege and even longer
 for any of the other modes.  Additionally, creative different game modes are never introduced anymore.  Champs are released on a regular basis, but they don't fundamentally change the game so you are stuck with the same monogamous gameplay with the unbearably bad match making. To make matters worse there is no longer a pro Paladins game scene or even a grand masters title, so there is nothing to aspire to while playing this game. 


In all, paladins even free is a rip off. You would be better off looking at the other free to play games out there.

ótimo game com muitos problemas internos por conta da empresa que o criou. Voltei a jogar em 2021 e posso dizer que vale muito a pena. 
Pontos positivos:
+Muitos players. Sempre acha partidas em inúmeros modos de game e com maior frequência que Overwatch. 
+Muitos campeões diferentes para selecionar. Cada um com suas particularidades, o que torna o game com uma longevidade absurda se parar para aprender cada campeão. 
+Boa performance para PCs low-end.
+Intuitivo e simples para quem é novo aprender o que cada coisa faz.
 Agora os negativos:
-Muito grind para adquirir novos campeões
-Não me importo com micro-transações de skins, mas a Hi-rez está cobrando uma facada e meia por cada skin de cada champ.
-Bugs e bugs de textura são bem comuns principalmente se mudar configurações de textura.
As vezes os personagens ficam presos dentro do spawn sem poder passar a barreira no modo tradicional do game e etc.
Não acontecem com frequência, mas quando ocorre é bem irritante. 
-Hit-box para cada champ não foi bem trabalhado. Muito das vezes tu acerta e é acertado em locais que não deveriam. 
- Esse provavelmente é o mais grave: a comunidade. A comunidade não é muito boa, muita gente é extremamente tóxica e parece que a grande maioria tá jogando TDM. Não tem interesse de jogar em equipe e ajudar. Não me importo com gente quebrando a comp e pegando 4 champs de damage. Mas se tu for fazer isso ou sup de dmg... tenta tipo.. DAR DAMAGE! A grande maoiria NÃO faz a sua parte e depois fica ofendendo no chat. Normalmente ser tão tóxico quanto eles resolve, mas tem muita gente que fica desmotivada e etc então fica ai essa observação.

Basically what Overwatch wishes it could be in everything except polish (they always have a little kink here and there that needs working out). You can play every champion in a myriad of different ways, with the tools they offer you to fine-tune their kit, sometimes to the point where the champion completely changes their role. And they're absolutely viable!

The players you encounter can sometimes be nerve-wreckingly dense, with some matches hinging on which team has the higher number of chromosomes, but with some friends you meet, it's a sinch, and it's worth it for those few sweaty matches where every single person is absolutely ascended and playing optimally with skills they didn't know they had, fighting toe-to-toe, just waiting for the other to falter, seeing who can stay in the flow longer.

Would recommend to everyone 9/10

Unlike most people, I played the Henry Stickmin Collection with no prior experience with any of the flash games that make up this series. I have never once played one of these games, and my only real exposure to it was watching a YouTuber I like play "Stealing the Diamond" about three years ago. So, I don't have any nostalgia tinted goggles influencing me here.

So, what do I think? The Henry Stickmin Collection is incredible. These games are so much fun, they're wacky, and they make choice based elements and quick time events, two gameplay elements that are usually shoehorned into games as cheap gimmicks, actually fun. And that's all the gameplay that there is!

There are 6 main stories that you go through here. They start off shorter, and get progressively more involved with each entry. If I had to choose one as my favorite, it would definitely be Completing the Mission, which is the last game in the Collection, made exclusively for it, and by far the largest and most passionately created.

There are a ton of achievements, 82 in all, which aren't super challenging to do, but take time, and are random and fun. Bios, information about the random characters, are collectibles that you receive for right-clicking on each character that you come into contact with. I personally enjoyed this aspect of the game, as I like collectibles, and found the bio descriptions hilarious and full of humorous references (which describes the game as a whole.

The only bad thing I have to say about this game would be the bugs. First of all, the game, by default, plays in small window. You can turn on fullscreen, but when you do, you get a warning message that this makes the game unstable, and prone to freezing and crashing. I can confirm that this is definitely the case, as I had my game crash about once every 20 minutes. It's not that big a deal, as you can just restart it, and you don't lose progress, but it's very annoying. That's the most important thing that the developers absolutely NEED to fix!

Second, there are times in the animation where the frame rate just plummets for a couple of seconds for no reason. It's not always in the same spot either, because if you come back later and replay that scene, it will work fine. It appears to just be poor optimization, and should also be addressed.

Other than that, I can't say anything bad about this game. I absolutely loved it, and I think fans of this series, or people who like quirky indie games in general, will get a lot of enjoyment out of this!

I personally don't think $15 is too high a price for this game, as it really is a quality game. Some people seem to think that if you don't get a certain number of hours of entertainment out of a game, that it isn't worth the money. I don't necessarily agree, because I think shorter titles that maintain a high and consistent quality experience for 10 hours are far more worth the money than one where half of the gameplay is busy work for 40 hours. Regardless, if you don't think 10 hours of gameplay is enough to warrant a $15 purchase, then I'd recommend you wait for a sale. I can easily see this going for $5 during a holiday sale.

I hope you found this review helpful! Please leave me a rating, and give me your thoughts in the comments, as I would love to hear feedback, ideas, and what personal experiences you've had with this title.

I also made a video review below. If you'd like more spoiler-free thoughts on the game, check it out:
I hate this game with a burning passion, 279 hrs

Normally I would think people post Pros and Cons for a game and let you decide if you want to play the game or not but I like this game and want you to have the full context If i can fit it in.
First I would like to say that I have played quite a few PvP games in my time (as many as a sweaty hormone filled teenager in his mom's basement you say? oh no no. Just enough to say I have) and despite all the unique mechanics I've seen get backed by million dollar publishers and AAA+ gaming studios, this game stands out as being one of the most well balanced PvP games I have ever played. 
Let's take Overwatch for example (the game Paladins is often compared to). I certainly wouldn't be the only one in saying that Overwatch's balance is horrendous. Blizzard seems to shit themselves at hearing the word "nerf" and will only buff, whereas Hi-Rez understands and hears their community out on what the issues at hand are, nerfing problematic parts of characters as needed. This is SO VERY CRUCIAL when it comes to balancing, looking at the numbers at hand, while still keeping an ear open to the community and what they have to say about something that feels busted. Hi-Rez, to me, has proven (albeit slowly) that they are willing to make educated decisions on balancing solutions, showing care towards the better health and longevity for their game. Ironic considering Hi-Rez provides free to play PvP games, and many gaming studios like that publish AAA+ 60$ games just. Don't. fucking. care. about. the. balancing.
There are also lots of in-game balancing things that is there that is really nice. If a character uses an Ultimate ability, a voice line plays right before across the whole map so everyone knows. And every Ult lasts a max of 5 seconds. The snipers in the game require at least two fully charged sniper rounds to kill enemies, so no-one shot cheap crap like that. Most maps are very similar to each other so characters don't feel anymore powerful on one map then a different map. There are 4 classes: Damage, Flank, Frontline, Healer. If the teams remain even with these classes filled, it will feel like a rather fair fight for the most part. For the most part.....
Now for the balance problem this game faces and will most likely continue to face. The hitboxes are pillshaped, and in no way accurate to the character model it follows. And there are hitscan characters in this game. Many, many hitscan characters. These characters with hitboxes that large don't exactly require that much accuracy, making them feel rather braindead to play, and frustrating to play against. DPS is also EXTREMELY valued in this game, as many characters suffer with high consistent DPS issues (this relates to the hitscan problem, but many burstfire/projectile characters also have this issue). You will see players damage stacking characters before they pick a frontline to tank damage, despite the fact that regular formation betters the odds of winning. This is common in just about any PvP game however, because why have fun with a fair back and forth fight when you can bring a braindead amount of damage and nuke the other team like douchebags?
Regardless, the community for this game is relatively quieter then a decent amount of PvP games i've played, but you'll hear some toxic crap, it's inevitable, people get sweaty and salty and they start cussing your mom out with the N-word, you know how it goes. But there is a report system in the game, just report em and hope they get banned. It's a decent community otherwise, I wouldn't let the community be the deciding factor in playing this game. There are dozens of characters, you are bound to find a few you like to play, there are some REALLY nice creative skins, and the types of ways for playing each character are endless because of the decks you can make and the perks you can buy in-match. Want to play a Tank but would rather flank? No problem, just grab the "Nimble" perk and away you go! 
To shorten things up, this is the game Overwatch should have been. It's off the rails with it's characters but the train still manages to chug along with its ability to correctly time and balance all of its insanity.
It's not perfect, but hey, it's free. Don't like it? Uninstall.

Introduction

There is nothing quite as satisfying as blasting the entire enemy team off the stage with Torvald’s hyper beam. Reanimating after you die as Terminus and vaporizing any opponents too slow to get away never gets old, and seeing Willo’s multiplying seedling attack come your way inspires horror. But the greatest achievement is that Paladins: Champions of the Realm allows you to dictate your playstyle.Paladins empowers experimentation and true customization. Amid the thrilling battles is a diverse five-on-five hero shooter that puts the power of choice front and centre. Whether it’s the wonderfully imagined characters, the in-depth card and item customization systems, or the inoffensive free-to-play model, there are plenty of options that make Paladins a worthy competitor for Overwatch.

The Game

There are 36 Champions in the game, few are unlocked when you start playing the game for first time and rest you have to unlock yourself. There are several types of characters. I found Seris to be a very interesting character given her abilities are too addictive that I always want to play her. I also liked the Bomb King , as the name suggest it is a living bomb that throws explosives to stun the enemies. 
It is a team shooter with three main game modes and a wide range of quirky heroes to choose from. Initially, you have access to a limited range of heroes (more unlock as players gain experience), each with a unique set of skills which can be amplified before the match by a customizable “loadout” of ability cards. There are 36 Champions in the game, few are unlocked when you start playing the game for first time and rest you have to unlock yourself. There are several types of characters. I found Seris to be a very interesting character given her abilities are too addictive that I always want to play her. I also liked the Bomb King , as the name suggest it is a living bomb that throws explosives to stun the enemies Players join a team with four other squamates to make a balanced team of damage-dealers, defenders, front-liners, flankers, and support units to take on an opposing team of heroes. The game offers three modes: Siege, (payload capture and movement) Onslaught, (point capture and kill count) and Deathmatch (first to forty kills wins.) Heroes earn currency during matches, which can be spent on useful powerup items during the match.  Post-match, players earn experience points and in-game currency, and unlock additional heroes and skill cards. Once players unlock twelve heroes and raise their player profile to level fifteen, they unlock Competitive mode, which lets them join ranked battles and grants them leader board status 
Every player picks five out of 16 cards to create a pre-set loadout tailored to the champion you choose that enhances stats and moves during a match. Beyond that, every match begins with yet another set of options, allowing you to pick one out of four champion-specific Talents that will dramatically change the way that character plays. Cassie, for instance, is a damage champion who wields a crossbow and generally works great from a farther distance, but this can all swiftly change with the swap of a Talent.
Cards and Talents are picked and locked in at the start of each match, but Paladins continues to let customization dominate the playing field even when the action is in full swing. Credits earned throughout a battle let you buy items to further boost stats and influence your abilities.
Each mode is able to stay fresh and interesting thanks to the 16 maps that are tactically compatible with their assigned game mode. My favourite is Jaguar’s Falls.

My Favourite Features of this Game

This fun team-based shooter uses a cute visual style and emphasizes competition over gore, which keeps players coming back round after round. Paladins: Champions of the Realm has a Disney-like art style that slightly lessens the fear of competition with fun, attractive heroes, a quick tutorial, and practice matches against forgiving AI opponents. Gameplay is immediately fun, even when you're still learning the game and getting accustomed to each character's abilities. See, there are lots of options for heroes, weapons, skills, and items, and players who know how to combine them become extremely powerful. The more experience you have, the cooler heroes you unlock. Still, even when you're just starting, out you can have a blast.
Cool themed maps give you plenty of strategic options, and the quirky heroes have powerful, often hilarious weapons. An almost-instant respawn when you die makes the pace of the game crazy-fast, and a wide range of unique hero powers keeps fights unpredictable. If buying item upgrades during matches confuses you, a convenient "auto-purchase" button solves that problem, and if your teammates get too bossy or rude, you can disable voice chat in the Options menu. Playing matches levels up your player profile, which means access to more modes, heroes, items, and skill cards, and special events occur periodically so you can earn even more unique items like character skins and emotes. The sound in Paladins: Champions of the Realm is nice, with upbeat music and funny character quips, and aside from the occasional busty beauty, the art and bloodless effects are colourful and kid-friendly. Player chat and voice add-ons remain a concern of course, when it comes to language, bullying, and potential predators, and the in-game shop is likely to be a constant temptation. But in terms of gameplay though, Paladins: Champions of the Realm is a quality team shooter -- one competitive kids are bound to enjoy.
As a free-to-play game, it’s always a concern that microtransactions could cause a pay to win, but Paladins keeps things on the level by not offering any competitive advantage for sale. Gold currency is earned by playing matches and completing quests, and using it to buy locked champions gives you a decent window of time to master a character as you save up for the next purchase. The entire selection of characters is available for purchase in a pack, and many cool outfits and other cosmetics can be purchased individually so you’re not left waiting for the item you want to drop from a loot box – though you can buy a loot box for a cheaper price if you don’t mind going through a handful of emotes and sprays. The Battle Pass costs 500 crystals ($10, more or less) and is a nice way to continue unlocking skins and chests.

Final Verdict

Personally, I feel  Paladins’ scope for experimentation is its greatest strength. The Developers have done an excellent job to make this competitive game filled with fun and creativity. The sound , graphics and characters , all are on spot. Whether it’s the main mode that encapsulates the teamwork aspect or the character designs that immediately flow with creativity, Paladins: Champions of the Realm clearly stands out in the midst of competitive multiplayer shooter games.

このビデオでは、第2章シーズン6で8時間連続でアリーナをプレイしています。最近、アリーナポイントが大幅に不足しているので、チャンピオン部門に参加してビデオに変えてみませんか。私はこの旅をコンテンダーリーグで約4.7kポイントから始めました。私の目標は、8時間でディビジョンを制覇することでした。私は自分の最高のゲームをすべて含めようとしましたが、いくつかの間違いや死も含めました。また、午後12時に開始し、PCでのチャンピオンズリーグの旅を少しわかりやすくするための更新を行いました。したがって、チャンピオンズリーグのアリーナグラインドや、アリーナを8時間連続でプレイするnoobコンテンツクリエーターを探しているなら、これは間違いなくあなたにぴったりのビデオです。その上、このビデオはチャンピオンリーグアリーナのゲームプレイを示し、Fortnite第2章シーズン6でより良くなるのに役立ちます。

いつものように、あなたがビデオを楽しんだなら、ビデオにいいねを残して、私のコンテンツを最新に保つためにチャンネルを購読してください。動画、チャンネル、または私自身について質問がある場合は、コメントを残してください。必ずご連絡いたします。私をサポートしたい場合は、アイテムショップでクリエイターコード「ジェリアン」を使用してください！ Epic Games Storeで私のクリエイターコードまたはリンクを使用すると、それらの購入からお金を受け取ります。

Greetings Champions!

As we begin another week we’ll be making sure to keep you busy throughout it with our new update but also with some fun coming on the weekend as well.

PC Hotfix
We will be taking the servers down briefly on Tuesday morning (the 6th) for a hotfix addressing a PC only issue where players could not use the equip button for their Skins/MVP/or Emotes. Make sure to pay attention to notifications from our official social accounts for when this goes live.
Who’s Got the Mojo?
Everyone’s going to be given another chance to get the “Got the Mojo” title in the game yet again. This event will take place on the Paladins Twitch channel coming Thursday at 11 AM EST. To participate just be ready in the Twitch chat to drop your gamertag for an invite and if you’re lucky the developers playing may choose you to join!
Ramadan Early Celebration
Stay tuned for a blog post on Thursday afternoon giving you the details for an in-game bonus all weekend long to kick off Ramadan (begins on the 12th) early. This bonus will start on Friday so you can all participate if you’d like on the weekend!
We’ll see you in the Realm!

Skill balance, as i have said its a dead game and so for the people that are playing consistently have gotten to a point where learning the game is either a chore or not even worth the effort, when you first play the game you will be matched up with other people new to the game as such you aren't dealing with anything too crazy but after about 2-4 hours in i started running into teams which were either a full team who have hundreds of hours into it or a single player that could completely hold a team back. As such it was hard to even get into the game at that point as most of the games at that point were awfully one sided to the point where leaving your base was a death sentence.

Legends, the actual playable character are something that i have mixed feelings on as some of the were very fun to play, though a lot of the characters did feel like they were inferior copies of characters from other games and that was not even the worst point.
Now there are a lo of games which have characters that are over-tuned or just over-powered but in Paladins there are multiply characters which are just game breaking to the point where you cannot really play against them or they can walk through your team as if it was a walk in the park, i'm not sure if there are plans to balance the game or if they have just given up on anything like that but looking at the game and its style i don't think there could be any major changes without changing the game itself.

All in all i would not recommend the game unless you are looking for a mindless time grind that will probably not evolve into anything satisfying, rewarding or something that most people will enjoy. 
I know i might get some comments saying oh you haven't played enough or maybe you were just bad but in the end these are my thoughts and opinions and people are welcome to voices their's and people are welcome to try the game for themselves.

MARCH 2022 UPDATE: To actually make a serious review here: I am not going on 5 whole years of playing Paladins. At this point in time, can I recommend the game? 

To new players: No. Absolutely not. 
To older players: Yes* but there's a lot to learn coming back to the game even in the past year alone. 
Matchmaking often makes no sense. Casual games you get put against stacks, GM duos, etc. Ranked games don't fare much better with lower ranked players being boosted up to higher MMR lobbies. 

The game has potential to be fun, but it's unpolished and most of the devs have left and been replaced time and time again, so we're at a point where cosmetics are now the main focus of the game instead of actual content like maps, balance, gamemodes, etc. You get a new champion every 3 months or so, which is frankly a bit too much at this point. With over 50 champions, that's extremely overwhelming to most players, especially if you're a purely F2P player. With no good options to get all champions, past/present/future anymore you're left grinding or shelling out the cost of a brand new AAA game. There's a lot of customization which is great, but again it comes at the expense of being too much at this point. When Paladins had <40 champions it wasn't too bad, but adding more and more champions just increases the amount of *STUFF* in the game. Each champion has 3 talents with 6 loadout slots (3 being default) so you have enough to at least play, but making your own loadouts will take literal hours for someone who doesn't already play the game. 

Until the new player/free player experience is fixed, and the devs stop focusing on champions and cosmetics I absolutely cannot recommend Paladins in its current state.

A very fun title overall, as long as you stay away from anything competitive. As someone who traditionally avoids ranked and other competitive game modes that suck out the fun from the game, Paladins is overall an enjoyable and well-produced experience.

The gameplay of Paladins isn't anything groundbreaking, but that's not necessarily a bad thing. While it can be a little rough around the edges, the core game loop of Paladins is fun and engaging. Among the three game modes available, you will most likely play Siege the most, which is for the better as the game was clearly designed with this game mode in mind. However, the occasional TDM and Onslaught matches are also a fun way to break the routine.
I appreciate the fact that matches are shorter in nature, which is perfect if you're looking to kill some time without having to commit for too long. It's uncommon for a match to go over the 15 minutes mark, unless there is a serious stalemate between the two sides.

I'm a person who appreciates good character design and artistic value, and Paladins does an excellent job in this area. HiRez have a proven track record of producing highly engaging characters and designs, and Paladins is no different. Their art division knows what they're doing and it shows. From the characters themselves to their various skins and customizations, there's something for everyone.
I will say, however, that a lot of the designs are overly sexualized, and can be quite over the top sometimes. This doesn't disturb me personally but I'm aware that some may find it distasteful. If you're looking for a more 'tame' style, Paladins may not be your cup of tea.

I'm writing this review as a strictly casual-only player. I avoid competitive games and modes like the plague; they take out a lot of the fun and turn what is supposed to be a fun and somewhat careless skrimish between strangers into a 'do-or-die' situation. I know that some people are looking solely for this side in games, but this has never been my thing and usually ended up degrading my experience rather than improve it. When your mindset is focused solely on winning, it becomes difficult to appreciate the areas where Paladins shines. If you are coming freshly new into this game, I implore you to avoid ranked so that you can enjoy it to its fullest.

Mind you, the game is not free of issues. Balancing a complex game with so many moving parts is never an easy job, but unfortunately HiRez are notorious for being weak in this area. Much like their other title SMITE, Paladins suffers from questionable balance choices and a strong sense of powercreeping. While not usually game-breaking, it can be quite frustrating to deal with some of this. I don't see myself as anything close to an expert in game balancing, but even as a mainly casual player I sometimes feel there's more to be desired.

Another issue is how limited are your customization options are if you choose not to spend real money on cosmetics and such. While there are some options that can be unlocked without paying, they are few and require an insane amount of grinding, and usually fall very short of their premium counterpart in terms of quality. The vast majority of cosmetics and customizations are locked behind paywalls and MTX, and especially frustrating is HiRez's infamous chests system, where you can only get certain items by opening chests (bought with real money) and hoping you roll the right thing out of what's in it. You can't just pick a skin you like and buy it, you are forced to play this dumb chest roulette and hope luck is on your side. Also, a lot of content is released as limited-time, so if you missed the time window to get it, it's gone forever. Joined the game late and found a skin that you really like? Too bad! You can't get it anymore, despite being teased with it over and over again.

Other key points:
 - Sound design is a bit of a hit-or-miss in Paladins. While fine in most places, there are some cases where critical audio cues (like character ultimates) cannot be heard properly or at all. Perhaps this is more of a technical issue, but the result is still the same.
 - Voice acting quality can greatly differ between different characters: most character voices are very well made and conviencing, but some sound ridiculously lazy or lackluster. I can safely say, however, that the majority of newer characters don't suffer from this.
 - In terms of technical performance, the game runs fine and dandy for me. I did not encounter any sort of crashes or serious bugs. Even lag isn't very common, which is a pleasant surprise considering the abysmal server status of HiRez's bigger title SMITE.
 - I have not met many toxic or unpleasant players in the game, but keep in mind I stick solely to casual. Maybe the case is different in ranked.

To summarize: Paladins is a fun game which I enjoy passing the time with as a casual-only player. The core gameplay is enjoyable and engaging, the characters are lively and well made, and the overall state of the game is good. There are, however, some noticable issues when it comes to balance, and the game is filled to the brim with cosmetic MTX and paywalls with some questionable practices. For the average player who doesn't mind either of these too much, however, Paladins is an overall solid choice that hits most of its marks.

And hey, it's free! Give it a try and see for yourself.

Bueno, sobre este juego, tengo varias cosas que decir. Vamos a empezar por lo bueno.
Cosas piolas 
-Optimización, siempre te va a ir a 60 fps estables, con su configuracion adecuada
-Graficos
-Mecanicas, no son nada originales ni creativas, pero son divertidas de usar las habilidades, y como cada personaje es unico, es más divertido aún.
Cosas malas:
-El Matchmaking es una verdadera basura, y no me refiero a campeones de nivel 120, porque el nivel da bastante igual, me refiero al nivel de los jugadores.

-El balanceo de los campeones es una verdadera bosta, hay campeones que ya nadie usa porque son caros, dificiles de usar, y apenas les podes sacar utilidad, en cambio hay otros que aunque valen 60000, hacen harto daño y están rotísimos, tal como es el caso de Raum y de Talus, que no es imposible ganar partidas con ellos con enemigos, pero si es bastante complicado, más todavía porque son campeones bien faciles de usar.

-Ultimamente los desarrolladores no le dan bola a los aspectos malos del juego, solo a lo que les da algo de plata para el bolsillo, como lo son las skins, campeones, pases de batalla, eventos, etc, mientras hay un montón de bugs (recién hace poco quitaron un bug de Evie que estuvo desde hace casi un año, que era lo más game-breaking que ví) no hay un mapa nuevo desde hace 2 AÑOS, quitaron funciones que estaban buenas, como la mejor partida, la tercera persona, los puntos de misiones, etc. 
En fin, los desarrolladores de verdad hicieron que yo odie este juego en ciertos aspectos, nunca me enojo en videojuegos, como cs:go o Rainbow six, pero con este, me quema un montón, porque este tipo de cosas están desde hace pila de tiempo, y no parece que se vayan a reparar nunca.
Lamento, pero no lo recomiendo.

Let me start off by saying I really do love this game. It has a lot of fun character designs and feels super free flow gameplay. Being able to experiment with many different builds is a super fun mechanic and leaves room for a lot of creativity. Anyone that said this game is an Overwatch ripoff clearly never actually played this game and could see how much better it is in terms of gameplay.

That's where the positives end.

There are so many things wrong with actually playing the game. Paladins is a buggy mess, especially on consoles. Constant crashing, random frozen screens, sounds not loading, the terrible bounty shop that was recently closed from how buggy that was, there's just so much of it that ruins this game for me. On consoles it's even worse. When a match just starts it'll force close or take forever to load. It's just poorly optimized and Hi-Rez doesn't want to admit it.

Then there's the matchmaking. It's so unbearable. Sometimes you queue up with people who have thousands of hours in this game and have previously reached grandmaster, or you get someone who just started playing and refuses to take any form of advice. One match you'll be able to wipe the other team in minutes, other times it happens to you. There is rarely any even matches from the major skill gap in everyone on both teams. It gets even worse when you play ranked and you can't queue with more than a single friend with similar skill which completely diminishes coordination in a team based game. Making it so you need 2 groups of 2 people and 1 person alone to do qualifications for ranked takes away some of the team aspects of a ranked mode. Other games that do this are also just as bad for this. I will never understand limiting queue with friends. Even for the higher ranks (Diamond and above) can only queue with one other person. This doesn't affect casuals which is fine, but it shouldn't affect ranked. That is the majority of the time that you need to queue with friends or a competitive group. It's so hard to avoid bad matchmaking in this game and Hi-Rez refuses to do anything about it. 

All of these problems could easily be solved if the devs decided to just put money into fixing the game instead of adding new skins every day. Start putting the budget into making the game playable and this would be a much more positive review. I doubt they'll take any input into consideration much like a lot of game devs do. 

Only play this game if you really need something to do with your friends, otherwise play a different shooter. 



Overall Paladins in its current state gets a 5/10, needs a lot of improvement.



Also stop making skins limited, it's a shitty business tactic that literally gives you less money.

A really great game and better than Overwatch in many regards. For one, there is no roll queue, which means if you don't want to tank/heal you don't have to wait more than 10 minutes to find a match. And because tanks and healers are actually fun to play, you tend to end up with balanced champion selections regardless. It's just a blast to play, especially with friends; matches are short and fun, without becoming heated and stressful. There's a good variety of maps as well, both in terms of the numbers and in terms of their stylistic and layout variety. It's got a very nice cartoon-ish art style, and is extremely well optimised even for low-end systems. There's a huge variety of champions to choose from, and its free-to-play mechanics are fair and reasonably priced - you get a free pool of champions to choose from, and can easily earn in-game currency to unlock more without paying real money. And you can try them before you buy them by using the shooting range mode. I don't like comparing it to Overwatch given that Paladins invented the genre first, but basically if you like that game and want something a little different (or if you have problems with how Overwatch plays these days), I highly recommend this game. It leans more heavily into MOBA mechanics than Overwatch - especially because you can use premade or custom loadouts per champion which totally change how each champion plays, and there's an in-game shop/item mechanic much like you'd find in League or Dota 2, though it's usually set to automatically purchase.
Hit Boxes are sometimes stupid, but the game is pretty balanced and fun.

Awesome game that is hero/champion based, like Overwatch. It mixes FPS and fantasy. I used to only play hack'n'slash MMORPGs, as a healer. I love the amount of different playstyles and characters you can choose from. The game is heavily influenced by SMITE, the publisher's previous game. All in all, it was instant love for me, I love this game so much! Super fun, especially with friends. Of course some people are toxic and salty, but you rather see that in competitive matches, casual is normally pretty chill. Great way to physically relax, while working out with my brain, after work! Only could recommend it!
My only issue is how you can't get old battle pass/event pass skins anymore. I'm in love with the Radiant Stars Battle Pass items,especially the skins, and I wish I could buy them, but there's no option for it. I didn't even know of this game when that was live. Some say, that it takes 7-8 months for them to put these items into loot boxes. Loot boxes aren't bad in this game. You actually save crystals! There's no crap items, it's usually all skins, sometimes a special mount too. 
In conclusion: come chill. It's a great game! :)

I have to admit, at one point I really enjoyed this game. It was my first fps shooter (unfortunately) and I found that the game had an overly passionate community, and so was I. I've played since beta and dunked nearly 3k hours into it. Paladins has an ok meta but is ultimately held back by Hi rez. Patch notes don't mean shit, and it feels like the developers don't actually know whats problematic with some characters as they constantly buff perfectly balanced characters in one department and then the following patch nerf their entire kit making them ultimately not viable for competitive play, regardless of how fun they are. Or they would completely revert the nerf / buff entirely making no progress in actually developing a more fun meta. I could swear that they're doing this on purpose to give the illusion that they're working on the game when the same 10 characters get changed every other patch. Because of this aside from new characters this game doesn't get a lot of actual content, its generally only skins to look forward too, the new maps are dogshit and characters have a reputation of being super broken, and even if they were not they're reasonably locked out of competitive play until the next patch which is on a monthly cycle now. Regarding balancing - actual fun play-styles get taken away or brutally nerfed and are never replaced with anything as unique or creative. I wouldn't say this game has the same problem as Overwatch where 1 team comp is a must pick, even though the community likes to think of it like that sometimes, but what seemed like a player expressive game quickly turned into same-y play-styles across different characters because too many loadouts are the same. The main gimmick of this game is it's card system that allows for champions to change their play-styles to fit their needs and specifically counter some team comps. This was true very early on and it shows when you look at older characters but generally 70% of the cards in this game are pure number buffs which I recognize CAN influence your play-style in subtle ways but are so un-optimal and underutilized. It feels very lazy seeing a card that increases your mag size by 4 when there are no doubt infinitely more ways to make things interesting. I have to blame this laziness on the implementation of Talents, which used to be Legendary cards in loadouts. Before Talents didn't exist so there were a lot more extreme cards that you would put into your loadouts, and although they still exist in the form of a talent they ultimately bottleneck future characters by not giving them zany cards that used to be a staple in the game's beta. I complained earlier about the devs never actually making any progress with anything as they make changes they quickly take them back in the following patch, this wouldn't be such an issue since it kinda makes the game fresh in a way where characters could slowly rotate out the meta and the slept on ones would slowly crawl forward as people experimented. I find this an issue though because there are actual problems with the game that need to be addressed first. I wouldn't say the game needs to be as polished as Overwatch but it doesnt fulfill the basic needs of a functioning game. There are way too many game breaking bugs and inconsistency issues, and while a portion of them has been fixed, its been a slow climb. Features of the game have been taken out to fix bugs in promise of it returning in a cleaner more polished setting but those have never been fulfilled and is even realized to never really fix main bugs. It's hard to even blame the current devs on this one because the game was built with so much spaghetti code and because the staff has been double Thanos snapped out of the company because of a huge money issue it had in its late beta. Hi rez left the mostly new  and small development team with a dying game filled with impossible to understand code and 3 Mount Everests worth of bugs. You will definitely see bugs being fixed but they're so minute and unnoticeable that it becomes a waste of resources. Its unfortunate because the dev team is so small for this game and they've even admitted to not being able to recover from the shitty engine its running on. As a veteran player I wished this game would get a remake or a sequel because Hi rez's modern games have way more polish than paladins but I know it will never happen. This game theoretically had the capability of being a 10/10 but I don't see a future for it anymore especially since its esports was cut off by the company. 

Oh and the matchmaking literally makes no sense you could actually be gold and on a level 20 account and get matched with the #1 world champion as no joke it happened to me. Despite this hi rez reduces your party to 2 once you reach diamond and makes it so that low elo players cant queue with hi elo friends, even though you could queue snipe each-other with like 50% accuracy regardless of your rank. The devs even admitted to having a system that auto fills the queue after like 7 minutes, which it gets up to consistently in high elo, - scratch that - plat players get queues of like 7+ mins daily.

Coming from a consistent Diamond player who never really tried getting farther from that.

- Awesomenauts-like midmatch shop to get stat boosts
- Playerbase isn't full of toxic crybabies as far as I can tell

Paladins: Champions of the Realm is a team-based shooter where players select between a variety of heroes and fight to capture objectives. Brawl it out in 5v5 matches as one of a colorful cast of characters, each imbued with their own abilities. Players can further customize their characters by enhancing some abilities over others through an extensive card system. Work together to secure the objective and then escort a cart to the opposing team's base to win the round. The first team to secure 4 points wins the game. Further customize your hero by purchasing items with currency earned during a match. Rank up your heroes and enter competitive play to test your skills and ability to work with other players to make split decisions that will either win or lose you the game.

as a seasoned Paladins player i can't help but disagree with almost everything said in this video. I felt like you guys didn't take this game seriously even though it is very in depth and very competitive as well as all the champions are really balanced. Also there is not really a cheating problem, cheaters are very rare in Paladins. There is an item called Illuminate in the game which directly counters your invisibility so that's why the Androxus was able to see you while you were invisible, no cheats needed for that...

There is a huge amount of variation in how you can play each different champion, which is awesome. You have healers that can be played as damage dealers with the right loadout cards. In Overwatch you pick a character and are stuck playing that playstyle, in Paladins you can customize the living hell out of your champion's build and there is way more variation in playstyles. And btw, the game is not "Chill" at all, it is super competitive, way more competitive than Overwatch. Overwatch is way more casual than Paladins. If you think you can play Paladins in a "Chill", "Casual", "Braindead" way (just quoting you guys), you will be in for some nice flaming in Ranked, your teammates will probably all report you for feeding.

The main differences between Overwatch and Paladins is the artstyle, and in Paladins you have more freedom when picking champions for your team versus the more balanced queing system that Overwatch has where you are forced to play 2 tank 2 heal 2 damage. Also Paladins has a bit more competitive player base than the Overwatch player base which is more casual.

This is a very cool and well thought out game. I originally strayed away because of the claims it is an Overwatch clone. I disagree with dismissing it like that. It has more depth to it than Overwatch due to the ability to customize your character via the card decks and the fact you buy "items" to modify your character during the game. There are no healing packs strewn about the map, either. I dont miss them and neither will you. The Champions are interesting and well thought out, as well.  As for the maps, they are well designed, have a dynamic flow to them and allow for different approaches to how they are played.

If you like team base, objective driven FPS games, you should definitely give this a try. I definitely dont regret going against the popular (and incorrect) characterization of it being Overwatch if you bought it on Wish. Im certainly you wont either.

I met my wife on this game. She was the most beautiful woman I’ve ever met.
After dating on and off for 4 years, we decided to get married.

We eventually decided to adopt a child because she couldn’t get pregnant,
his name was Jamie. But then things changed for the worst, she started getting sick.

I started to panic, I became angry and confused, but she told me everything is going to be fine, that’s just how she was. She started getting worse and worse everyday, but she kept a brave and positive attitude, I don’t know how she did it.

After she died I was lost for a long time, my son also stopped paying attention at school.
The teachers understood, at first. But after a while they got more and more angry, they called me many times, but I was wrapped up in my own sadness to do anything about it.

As soon as he turned 18 he decided to drop out of school, I understood why he did it, although I encouraged him to stay. At this point I had quite a bit of money saved, so I decided to travel the world with him for a year, It was what we needed both.
He now lives in London with his boyfriend, and I couldn't be more proud.

I haven’t booted up this game in a long time, but after sitting in my apartment without really doing anything since I retired I decided to play it one more time.
And then the tears came rolling, they just couldn't stop coming. My father always told me that crying is for the weak, so I never really let it all out. But I am so glad I did.

She was an Angel. I never fell in love with anyone after her death, because I didn’t need to.

Thank you for creating this game Chris Shanas, it defined my life and who I am as a person.

I started playing Paladins somewhere around update 9 or so. This game has evolved and grown and changed so much since I started playing it that I can hardly believe how much fun it is.

It often gets compared to the competition, but honestly I find I spend more time with this game than the other one.

The pace is more hectic and frantic, playing support roles or tank roles don't feel like a drag because their skill sets and the card/buy systems allow you to pitch your roles into a direction that better suits your play styles.

The art, character design, their kits & skills, and misc other balance changes have come light years since I first played.

If you're still on the fence on this one or you avoid it because you "heard it was a knock off" of OW, then you're cheating yourself out of one of the most fun competitive multi-player games on the market right now.

Is it an overwatch clone? Kinda. Sure, the hero abilities are overwatch hero abilities that are ramshackled together, but the loadout system allows you to play whatever character you want without having to follow a specific team comp/meta (though this is not an incentive to just ignore the warnings of "No healer" or "No front line"). I'm having fun with it, just don't get your hopes up when you're crushing in the first 5 matches cause those are bots.

[b] [h1] I'm conflicted on this review and heres why! [/h1] [/b]


[h1] First the bad ugly truth [/h1]

Honestly i didnt want to start with the bad but it needs to be pointed out first so people get the general idea.
In my 215+ hours (at review time) it has become very apparent that the devs base the updates and fixes off of console play more than they do for PC.  At first i didnt see it after my friend mentioned it but after the huge update where they buffed everyone that really didnt need it it was so in your face saying "hey the meta is different on console than it is on PC because we buffed koga and seris" after that i was hit with confusion and just had to at that point come to terms with the idea that they base the changes on console play exclusively.

With that being said its still playable even with the buffs and changes but still there are people that need a nerf on PC and possibly console.

Another huge issue i have with Paladins is it seems they havent really given it the attention it needs/deserves with bug fixes. i know they addressed that they were going to update more often recently so it does give me more hope on this matter. but still there are a lot of small graphical issues and bugs that are minor and not game breaking that should have been scrubbed out months ago like At match end when you level up a season pass and click "close" and it replays the audio and pops the screen up again or like the small void/hole in the default Seris skin in her chest or my favorite when you earn rewards in a pop up screen for you to equip and nothing you do works so you have to sometimes close out of the game and restart it.

The Bounty tokens never worked for me so i reached out to them via twitter and got no response but instead was shocked to see they instead made an event for tokens a couple days after i reached out. On their twitter update everyone complained saying it doesnt work for them and if it does work the skins they bought just get taken away randomly. I recently was able to finally get tokens but now they are revamping it which is good. However they seem to not be aware it never really worked because they think everyone loves it when it never really worked on PC to begin with for me or a few friends. 

Proof other people had my issues and some worse like losing all acquired bounty tokens: https://twitter.com/PaladinsGame/status/1344674801793835012


[h1] The Good! [/h1]

Honestly i do like Paladins i really do. Paladins has a lot of potential and a really nice range of different characters. I see this game only getting better with more updates/changes. i personally prefer this instead of its "competitor" and will continue playing this often. im really looking forward to see what kind of direction Paladins will take.

I installed this game in March of 2017 on PS4 but it is basically the same nothing changes apart from the controls of course. I've had tons of fun and i must say that it is NOT an Overwatch clone. I have played both games for a decent amount of time especially Paladins (800+ hours). This is in my opinion a more ''casual'' game than Overwatch which is/was among the most popular games in the e-sports industry. Now, let's not drift away from the topic of review and actually talk about Paladins itself. Where can I start from? It gives players unlimited possibilities i.e. creating your card loadout and that is what makes this game WAY different from OW. There are literally so many ways to play a certain Champion by playing a bit with their cards. You can have 5 unique cards per loadout and each prioritize one aspect of a champion's arsenal (cooldown reduction, shields, health, crowd control). For instance you can play a Tank that is supposed to capture and stay at the point as a FLANKER. Let's take for example Fernando and his flamethrower. He has a huge ass shield that can absorb a lot of damage and that obviously makes him ideal for holding enemies off the capture point. However, some people prefer to play him as a flanker and rather focus on kills than being the actual frontline of the team. This applies to every champion of course and there are unlimited ways to play around them. This aspect of the game is what made me fall in love with it and play non-stop for a whole year. This was until OB64 came out and absolutely ruined the card system we all loved. I'm not gonna get into detail of what it did as it happened 3 years ago and I have a very long time to play Paladins (you can find about the infamous OB64 with a simple search). Anyways, I've had a shit ton of good memories playing this title with my buddies. Eventhough its may be seen as a less-polished version of OW with a card system to some peoples' eyes it will definitely spark your interest if you at least give it a try :)

As a supporter of this title since the Closed Alpha, I've loved this game. Before I ever was able to play Overwatch and sink too much time into it, I spent so much time on Paladins as a Founder. It has grown and changed a lot since then, but one thing always rings true; The Devs are Persistent in constantly making this game greater and greater. About every champion feels unique, and those that don't are normally a combination of your favourite abilities from multiple heroes from other games (like combining two Overwatch Heroes for example). Bugs aren't too common, and the gameplay loop in enjoyable.

IF I had to state any negatives, it's that the Anti-Cheat could use a little more work. It gets the job done, but every 50 or so matches, you may find someone who is blatantly using aimbot on someone like Viktor. Another downside would be the fact that there can be quite a long bootup time with that EasyAntiCheat. And Finally? Just not enough people use Comms. The Best way to play and enjoy this game is with Friends, and that is fairly easy with the Devs dedication to Cross-play and Cross-Progression (Thank god for my old Xbox One Founders Pass :P)

If you enjoy Team Based Hero Shooters, Paladins is a great and free entry point which you can easily pick up and play with friends, no matter their platform (and I really mean that, the Switch, PS4 and Xbox One versions of the game all run smoothly, and boot faster lol). If you enjoy a character who is on the free rotation, a lil' grinding and bam, go unlock them. But if you choose to support the devs and get the Founders Pack, all current AND future Champions are yours to keep and enjoy, and honestly, if you enjoy the game enough, it's cheaper than buying Overwatch and Worth It. But hey, I play and Enjoy both, and I hope you do too!~ <3

**UPDATE** After even more time, Cheating is seen alot less and the Bootup time with Anti-Cheat is alot faster now :3 New champions are really dynamic and alot of Fun, and even between Overwatch and Halo Infinite, I still find myself coming back to Paladins when I want to change it up a little. Still a high recommendation!

Don't get me wrong, I love paladins. The maps are unique and there is a wide variety of playable champions. Not to mention its great concept that is pulled of quit well. However there are a number of serious flaws to the game. Some champions are stupidly unbalanced such as Lian with all of her abilities that deal damage and can easily be used to barrage and destroy single targets in a single second (unless its a front line), the new Lex rework allows players to melt enemies more easily than before and Zhin is just plain OP as a champion. There are also other problems with the game such as server lags and crashes where players may have to close and re-open the game while attempting to join a match. there are bugs even after the game has finished, where the game black screens and requires a restart once the match is over. I believe that the game devs should balance certian champs and fix these bugs before releasing more content. Since the release of the new (slightly unbalanced) champion, yagorath, they have already worked on and almost finished the next champion, Octavia, and another battle pass. The devs need to fix bugs with the current version of the game before adding more potential problems to the game.
This review isn't intended to come across as a hate comment, I have simply written this to provide constructive criticism for the developers.
if the developers can fix these bugs and balance the champions that require balancing, then i would totally recommend this game to others.

I can't in all honesty recommend this game, I have some time in the game and the content, matchmaking, bugs, none of it is getting improved or fixed. It could be a great game but its just getting stale and ignored in place for whatever else they're working on.

Are there broken champions? Yes, a lot of them, however I think a good amount of this game's balance comes from the fact that are a lot of broken champions and compositions, allowing players to counter each other not by technicality but instead by skill and character power. Is the community toxic? Besides spamming quickchat, I don't really think so. Not a lot of people stop playing after 1 minute and start just harassing their team like in Overwatch, where you have a quitter every game. I will say the biggest glaring issue is probably the lack of skill based matchmaking. Yeah quickmatch is quickmatch but occasionally in ranked it'll throw a Gold 2 with a Silver 5, against a team with A Bronze 1 and a Silver 1, but 2 Gold 3's. I think players who consistently get high numbers per minute should be matched with players who do the same. Then people will pick characters that the haven't used before, which is fine in principal but there is no switching during matches. like don't pick a healer if you are only gonna get 5k healing in 12 minutes (this game deals in thousands not hundreds so that is inexcusably bad) especially when the dps have 90k dmg. Or vice versa people will quick lock dps roles and only deal 35k dmg in 12 mins.

Paladins can definitely be fun, but also frustrating for sure. Some things are definitely unbalanced in this game, and the players aren't really the nicest either. But there are definitely good moments too. It's a game I got addicted too quickly because of the diverse roster of champions, and I've grown a liking to a lot of them. They are definitely working on making their game much better, but one thing that also bugs me are the chests in-game. I swear, everytime I want a certain skin from a chest it's always the last skin I get, and I don't know if that's just bad luck, or if the game just knows, but it always ends in me spending more money to get crystals just for the skin I want. Bugs are also a problem in this game, but for a while I'm not really experiencing them that much so they're not a problem for me. Other than that, the game is fine. :)

So, you want my honest review of paladins?
Well ive been here for a while and followed this game through good times and bad times.
Ive known Paladins since 2016, and 5 years later i still love this game.
But this game is not flawless, so if you plan on playing the game im not going to advice you, or not.
Instead ill give you the good points and bad points about this game so you can formulate your own opinions.

Good Points:
[list]
    [*]This game provides a ranged variaty of play styles so you can change your role in game even if you are using only 1 character
    [*]All characters played effectively can either control the battlefield or have the biggest impact in game, so it dosent matter who you main, it will always have an impact
    [*]Useless characters is something this game knows very little about, since all characters lack a playstyle, giving YOU, the player, the option to play it as you want
    [*]All characters feel smooth when playing them, and most importantly all ultimates are FAIR. Since after you ult, the enemy has 2 seconds to react to your ultimate making escapes easier and not feel like a "win the game button" 
    [*]The Game rewards gameplay mechanics over lone wolfers, since you only have 5 players in a team and there are 4 class's in the game, eventually you'll realize that if you want to win you need to adapt making the game feel way to third dimensional and open to different playstyles
    [*]All Maps are perfectly symetrical so the player can guarrentee a free push if they know the map well enough, making counterplays easier since all of the map works as a single point with a payload
    [*]The System of cards Unbound is by far the biggest and most important part of the gameplay, a system that allows, you the player, to costumize your character with a hide spectrum of choices making you able to play the game as you want, not as you are told
    [*]Playing the game and getting better at it its crucial to more wins, but for the low average player the game has you squared, the game queues you in bot matchs for you learn the mechanics, but even after that if you feel like you want to learn more characters, the game still gives you the option to go for bot matchs until you are ready for the main game, making the game EXTREMELY GOOD for new-commers
    [*]The Game offers you a spectrum of champions to fill your every desire, and every 3 months a new char comes along.

Bad Points:
[/list]
[list]
    [*]This game's servers are a mess, usually you'll have your internet completly ok and be sliding in and out of combat.
    [*]The Hitboxes are squared much like unreal tournament and quake's, and the game offers you auto aiming abilities, and its pretty annoying some times
    [*]Remember how i said "The game dosent know useless characters?" well but it does know overpowered characters, and depending on your skill you might disagree with me, but arguably Vivian and Moji will most likely be your biggest problems since both have way to busted kits making them killing machines at basicly any range.   
    [*]This game suffers from microtransactions, since you can technically buy your way into a primed account with barelly any effort and getting in 50$ what you would normaly need 500+ hours of gameplay to get.
    [*]Some systems that the game provides you are incredibly flawed sometimes, and this is specially true when it comes to AI. When your teammates leave the player will get replaced by an AI but the AI, is coded that if it hits a wall it will still move against the wall until 5 seconds later it changes to a new wall acomplishing nothing in the process
    [*]The Entire Ranked System has a huge flaw that makes ranked grinding tedious and really unfunny, since you can be a platnium player trying to have fun and getting queued against a duo of grandmasters and get demolished
    [*]Yes, skins, the problem isnt actually the skins, is the amount of skins each character recieves compared to anothers, Let's look at Maeve for example, she owns more than 12 skins while characters like Evie have 3 tops, so the devs clearly have biased opinions towards which champs deserve more than others.
    [*]90% of the community tent on giving this very bad feeling in game, mostly for the toxicity.
    [*]This game is a mess when it comes down to player skill levels, since there isnt an Match Making lvl it can pair you up with people that have been playing for 2 days with people that have been playing since Alpha.
[/list]

Now i do have to mention the elephant in the room, YES it is a f2p game, but because of the micro-transactions i cant fully acknowledge it as a F2P Game.
Now about my honest opinion in the long term.
Yes the game does become very stale after a couple of weeks/months HOWEVER, the game lets you choose how to handle the gameplay through Cards Unbound System.

So? What do i, Syrex think of this game? 8/10 for new players and then a 6/10 for old players or veterens. but what do you think? let me know in the comments.
