Paladins is truly a game i would forever remember:

Some matches you would win easy while other matches you could loose hard its really a 50/50 change winrate tipe of game. If your the tipe who is looking for a shooter game to enjoy i'll recomment this game. Yes it has its pro and cons but at the end all games has its own problem. they struggle with bugs every patch but they work hard into fixing it as fast as they can. Ive been playing this game for years and ive never seen a hacker on this game ever only really skilled people. No one plays  the characters the same that keeps the game unique your either really good balanced or bad at a character  so you would have characters you love playing and some you never play. 

Its that tipe of game that every match is not played the same. How this game works is you have a point to capture (circle in the middle) which you have to contest for to earn the payload (a cart full of explosives) that you must push to the enemies team point circle near there spawn. First one to 4 points win the match wins and its called Siege.

There are 3 other game modes Tmd,Onslaught where Onslaught have two modes a 
King of the hill: where the point stays one place
Normal Onslaught: where the point change potition every few minutes to be recaptured. 
Team Death Match aka Tdm is just a deathmatch where the winning team wins after they get 40 kills first but Onslaught uses point up to 400 you can get points by killing an apponent or by just capturing the point.

There are 4 tiers of character groups:
Tank
Dmg
Flank
Healer

its very important to have a character in each tier on your team to have a balance team and have a high winrate chance. there are 5 in each team so you can have all the tiers in your team and have a second slot for a exstra tier like if you want 2 healers to keep your team viable or in most casses 2 tanks for one on point and one off point to help other tiers to defeat there opponent. 

There servers are always stable and works good internationally so if you have good wifi it will feel like a breeze. Always a fun game and have its funny moments its only rank where people get toxic so i recommend finding friends to party up with that you know how they play and what they're are good at and what not.

Game is alright and fun, or at least it would be if certain characters weren't horribly unbalanced. These OP characters are the meta that you will see in almost every match and so the game gets boring since you will only really be fighting the same few characters such as Lex, Io, and Kinessa. Io is a huge offender in being unbalanced with DPS that rivals damage classes and a healing summon that is way too durable, on top of that, Io can use the summon as an extra life to negate any attack, including ults. 

Imbalances like this just make the game feel unfun as most deaths you get aren't even because of something you did. It is usually just you get random insta-killed by a character you can't even react to.

And that isn't even getting to the amount of hackers in the game. People who (after doing calculations) were doing more than 4 times the DPS their character was capable of.

All of this boils down to a half-assed competitive game that whilst fun at times, Leaves very little room for skill or fun when played. Even with friends, most matches just come down to a halt of "Well great, they are using THAT character, guess we lose"

And to top it off, Half of the teammates you get stuck with are just bots or trolls that sit at spawn, purchase no items, and do nothing to help the team.

Honest Review from someone whose clocked thousands of hours on FPS Games over the past 17 years.

The only thing this game has in common with Overwatch is that they both brought about a new Category of First Person Shooter. The closest you'd get to this once upon a time was on CS:S on the Surf RPG Maps.

I like Paladin's, its characters are fun and the mechanics are interesting.

But I cant recommend it because to fully enjoy the game with Battle Passes you need to spend €60 as most of the characters are hidden behind that big Pay Wall. Now, I'm an adult whose had his own company, I get it. You need to make money but the reason company's charged €60 in the first place was because you were getting a physical Cartridge/disc, a case, a manual and sometimes a map or a poster too.

Overwatch is similar and costs a fraction of the price to enjoy fully.

You do the math.

I would recommend this game since it is fun to play a lot of the characters. However, if you plan on playing ranked I strongly recommend playing in a full squad since 90% of the player base is hard to queue with and the match making is not skill based. This means that you have a higher chance of queuing against higher ranking people or lower ranking team mates that should not be in your game. From personal experience, I was grinding out of platinum and my team's average in terms of ranking is gold since we had 1 person in bronze and 1 person in silver. TLDR; I lost that game and it caused me to stick to casuals due to that kind of match making.  Overall, a good alteration to OverWatch with a lot more strategic approach to payload.

Just a little FYI, do not unlink your steam account for paladins since you run the risk of losing your account and starting over again.

Welcome to the game where you're expected to fill in the tank or healer spots, all the dps have instantly locked in their choice and are spamming you to tank/heal.
Enjoy the next few hours of this on repeat, watching as your dps don't even know what end of their weapon to point at the enemy.
Eventually you'll get a match, both teams are even, no one has chosen any of the bullshit overpowered premium champions. You'll have fun, lots of it. And now you'll need to slog through the next several hours of unbalanced teams and 5 man automatic doomstacks. to chase that high again.
Don't do this to yourself, go play something more fun.

Came out long after Overwatch and there are MANY similarities between the two. I mean even half the characters are practically direct copies of all the skill-sets. There is more than one character that you could say "inspiration from Overwatch" would be a massive understatement. So, you wouldn't be totally wrong in thinking that this game is a ripoff of Overwatch. However, as a veteran of Overwatch with hundreds of hours, I can comfortably say that Overwatch largely pales in comparison to how fun Paladins is. Granted, there is an abundance of 12 year olds that just wanna run around an shoot stuff and that's terribly annoying when they cost you the match, but it's worth it since it is so much more fun. Overwatch is built in a way where you NEED to find that character you're compatible with. There is no scraping by with a character, there is no just playing as Genji in Overwatch to just fool around. In Paladins, you can choose any character and after a brief period of learning their skills, you should be able to adapt and play as that character, have some fun and not die every 30 seconds. Paladins is more fun, with more characters, better commentary, better skins, wider variety of characters and character types. In short, uninstall Overwatch, play Paladins!

I'd like to recommend this game to people after 400 hours on steam and another 1000+ back when the game used it's own client to launch.

But I just cant.  The gameplay it self is good.  *When it works* which it often doesn't.

Over half a decade old and the game is still severely bogged down by bugs, some of them can be gamebreaking.  Particularly this game's habit of dropping matches and massive plethora of cheaters.  I could overlook this all and not bat an eyelash.

But where the game truly suffers is the community it self.  This is where the game suffers.  Sure you meet some nice people.  But those instances are quickly buried by the fact that Ranked and Casual lobbies are chalk full of toxic people constantly false reporting players, Afking, dropping matches via lagging the lobbies out and just general constant crying about non essential game mechanics. Screaming into mics and other nonsense of that nature.   And this is what truly leads to me not recommending the game.  And this is coming from somebody who's poured thousands of hours into GMOD

I want this game to succeed, I really do.  It has a much more unique feel than Overwatch does and allows more freedom of playstyles while still letting you maintain your roles.  But the playerbase is it's biggest issue.  The same issue that plagues DOTA 2 and League of Legends.

Cons:
- Hitboxes are the actual size of mountains.
- Heroes are unbalanced.
- Maps are too small.
- Objectives get captured too fast.
- There is little to no counter play.
- Flanking is way too easy.
- Somehow they thought it was a good idea to have an item in the game to counter barriers, but not an item for the other types of tanks. Therefore removing barrier tanks from the actual meta.
- Skins are bad and overpriced.
- Constant bugs and animation breaking.
- Matchmaking is the worst I have ever seen.
- You either roll the enemy team for an easy win or get rolled. There is rarely ever a close game.

Pros:
- The card system is kinda cool.

 I would suggest only playing this game if you are broke and/or bad at shooters.

Working on top of the strong and fairly balanced foundation of a free-to-play hero shooter, Paladins’ capacity for experimentation is its greatest strength. Even after over 100 hours of exhilarating battles and strategic planning, champions continue to find a way to offer new gameplay experiences. Whether it’s the main mode that encapsulates the teamwork aspect or the character designs that immediately flow with creativity, Paladins: Champions of the Realm clearly stands out in the midst of competition.

There are a few odd bugs and graphical problems that appear from time to time. Sometimes weapons like Makoa’s anchor or Torvald’s energy beam will stretch out across the entire map or a HUD overlay that should have disappeared will stay longer than needed. At one point the menu background disappeared and left behind a mess of inverted colours, but it was more of an annoyance than anything that affected gameplay.

As a free-to-play game, it’s always a concern that micro transactions could cause a feeling of unfairness, but Paladins keeps things on the level by not offering any competitive advantage for sale. Gold currency is earned by playing matches and completing quests, and using it to buy locked champions gives you a decent window of time to master a character as you save up for the next purchase. Of course, the entire selection of characters is available for purchase in a pack, and many cool outfits and other cosmetics can be purchased individually so you’re not left waiting for the item you want to drop from a loot box – though you can buy a loot box for a cheaper price if you don’t mind sifting through a handful of emotes and sprays. That’s fine, but it’s disappointing that some of the most impressive outfits can’t be purchased outright and are locked behind a chest. 

There’s nothing quite as satisfying as blasting the entire enemy team off the stage with Torvald’s hyper beam. Reanimating after you die as Terminus and vaporising any opponents too slow to get away never gets old, and seeing Willo’s multiplying seedling attack come your way inspires horror. But the greatest achievement is that Paladins: Champions of the Realm allows you to dictate your play style. Whether it's adding to the knock back of weapons or increasing the duration of your shield, Paladins empowers experimentation and true customisation. Amid the thrilling battles is a diverse five-on-five hero shooter that puts the power of choice front and center. Whether it’s the wonderfully imagined characters, the in-depth card and item customisation systems, or the inoffensive free-to-play model, there are plenty of options that make Paladins a worthy competitor for Overwatch.

Legit though Paladins NAILS what Overwatch should have been when it comes to it being a MOBA FPS hybrid. Despite having no hero switching mid match the ways in which you can use heroes are much more versatile and a lot of team comps can work if you're paying attention to what your team can do to get the enemy on edge. Plus building your own loadout is fun, makes it feel like YOUR hero instead of a tool that's restricted to just countering one person. Again sorry for comparing OW to Paladins but I love that the game allows healers to at least hold their own against flankers if they're situationally aware, and tanks FEEL like tanks. 

Anywho on to the negatives, bugs are annoying, due to it being free to play the uuhh community is pretty frustrating. No killcam which sucks hard. REALLLY grindy ways to get even ONE skin and like the bounty store breaks every goddamn two weeks  etc. That and the game takes forever to start, and is really clunky when it comes to alt tabbing in and out of it and random crashes kinda blow. That's about it from me, Great game to play with friends, but please don't spend hours on end playing you'll just frustrate yourself.

As a new player you will find a lot of things interesting as how to mechanics works and stuff in the game and with all the different types of characters u can play as, but once u spend around 200+ hours the game gets a little boring coz u know how everything works and the only thing that separates you from the enemy team is the skills of you and your teammates.

The game developers keep the game alive with plenty of bug fixes as well as introducing new characters to the game but its to one point and then that too will be boring to play with. It was a good game to play at the start with your friends and such but eventually it grows on you and you will get sick of how it is the same thing over and over again. 

Skins are a all Pay 2 Get, it is absolutely hard to earn any form of gems in the game as the devs rely on season pass to make money, so unless u will be active for that whole season, it is completely a waste of money to spend money on it to get that one specific skin that you want. Did i also mention that their servers can be really bad sometimes, mid game disconnections and such. Relogging into your game is alot more of a pain in the ass btw. 

The competitive scene of the game is toxic according to my experiences, they do not have room for mistakes, i constantly got nervous to even try to play a competitive game as i dont want to let anyone down haha. Could just be me  idk

Overall it is a good game for a new player, but it grows overtime for a veteran player..

So, i like this game, and would very nearly recommend it. But it has some problems that will likely never be fixed, and this irks me as loyal player.

First, the battle passes. There's been good ones, but almost every battle pass since the pirate one more than a year ago now has been awful terrible garbage with arguably 1 good skin at best, with the current pass having not even a single good skin.

Second, the modes. This game used to have 3 modes, now it has 1.5. It has siege, the primary mode, then there's Onslaught/king of the hill(Which are merged queues. This is the .5 in my last sentence, king of the hill is so bad of a mode it makes onslaught worse by proxy), and finally, there's team death match. TDM in this game is so bad and so disliked by the community that i strongly wonder why the devs haven't removed or replaced it yet. Back in the day, there used to be pure payload(which TDM replaced) which was AMAZING. It had some of the strongest map design across all maps, and encouraged objective play, which is where hero shooters shine. Also, king of the hill wasn't there, so onslaught got it's other .5 back.

Third, the bugs. I know the devs are working on this hard now, but this game has been mired in a lagoon of bugs and spaghetti code from day 1. The part that i don't think will ever be fixed is that they are okay with just cutting errant pieces they consider buggy rather than trying to fix them, like third person view.

I played this game heavily during quarantine with some friends of mine and it was the most fun I've had in a hero based FPS/OBJ game. I love the insane amount of characters you can choose from, and making specific builds for each of them. 

They have both competitive and casual play, I don't usually do competitive unless it's required for the challenges, I'm more of a laid back person, which is why my friends and I would do bots or quick play instead (but we still like to try our best to win). 

Communication and using combos between players with abilities or ultimates is definitely a must for big pushes or to gain the lead. (Although as a Tank main, using Ash or Inara, I end up messing things up because the enemy gets booped away or walled off.. aha..). 

It's free to play, you just need to buy the champion pack and season pass, which is great because you support the game devs! They deserve it! 

Another thing I love about the game is the stylized art look they went for, in love with it! 

Give it a try

Having played this game for over two years now.
I can say that Paladins is not an Overwatch clone. What separates Paladins from Overwatch is it's unique card system.
The card system is used to alternate different builds on your champions that can consist of either increasing your health pool,increasing your reload speed, or reducing your ability cooldowns to name a few. This can make for 100s of hrs of play time trying different builds and playstyles on 47 champions each with unique passives and abilities. The downside however to this system, Is that it can result in having broken builds that can be part of the 'Meta'. Which tagged with powerful champions make a powerful composition { Meta comp for short}. The game has an impressive 29 maps in its roster. 14 siege maps, 8 onslaught maps, and 7 team deathmatch maps. The only flaw too this though is that Evil Mojo is a small dev team vs. 29 maps that have certain exploits {or 90% of the time you getting stuck on walls} on top of trying to keep balance over 47 champions. Now the game has 4 main game modes that I'll describe in a short description Siege {lose 1 round and your teammate afks the rest of the match}, Team Deathmatch {Warming up just so that you can get your butt handed to you in siege mode}, Onslaught {10 min queue time}, and Ranked mode {xxxplayerxxx has not made a selection enjoy another 15 min queue time lols}. In short when you start playing this game expect to carry your teammates cuz they wont carry you. Or else you get blamed for the loss. But there are reasons to play this game. For one, if both of your teams are evenly skilled it can lead to some really fun and intense matches that even on a win or loss you still feel like you got a dopamine rush out of it. And playing with trolls decks can be a blast with friends.{recommended for siege mode not ranked just don't blame me if your team spam reports your account to no end and be dmed privately for about 20 mins}. The bugs in this game are so immense it's a surprise that the game servers are still functioning. Although little by little they do fix some of the bugs eventually while others are there permamently due to "spaghetti code they cant mess with or else it breaks the game even more". Despite all these problems I do believe this game has a chance to make a better name for itself. And has long has you treat this has a more casual experience. You will ensure you'll have more fun with the game. Anyway, I'll head outta here now. If you read this all the way through thank you for taking your time to do so. Catch ya later

This game was great at one point, about two years ago when getting gold did not take weeks to be able to buy champions. I have been playing this game since beta on ps4 and recently swapped to pc. Not only do they not allow you to transfer your account, the pack to get all past future and present champions is no longer available. Hi-Rez has prioritized money over the quality of the game, they force you into a situation where if you don't spend weeks grinding you can't buy a few characters and made them purchasable by gems. The saddest part about the fact that they have made the game so micro-transaction there has still not been any significant performance change. The game still runs like ass but they want you to spend 20 plus dollars on a few characters. The core fun aspects of the game have been tainted by the fact that you can only play a handful of characters before you have to open up your wallet. Until I can transfer my data from ps4, and the characters don't take weeks to get then I don't think I will ever play this game again. For example the characters cost 60,000 coins, and you make around 100 average a game if you win, 200 sometimes if your lucky. That is 600 to 300  matches to acquire one character, that is truly abhorrent. They have killed this once great game, and I truly believe that this game is no longer worth the time. Fix this game so people can actually play without drying out their wallets, fix the micro-transactions and then this game can start on the path to be good again.

If you enjoy hero-shooters in the vein of TF2 and Overwatch, you'll immediately enjoy Paladins! If you haven't or are on the fence about this style of team-oriented hero-based FPS, you should still give it a try because its FREE! What's not to like about that??

While this is a bold statement, I make it on purpose and with full confidence: [b]Paladins is a better game than Overwatch![/b] Here are a few reasons why:

[b][u]Hero Diversity:[/u][/b]
With 50 heroes (or champions) to choose from there's a very good chance you'll end up really enjoying at least a dozen of them. While some are your typical archetypes like "Old man with an AR" or "Little person inside a mech suit", there is a large amount that are unique to Paladins and make the game really fun!

[b][u]Actual Character Builds:[/u][/b]
Unlike Overwatch, there is a 2-part system in Paladins that allows you to tweak how you play your champion. Talents and Loadouts can majorly change how a support plays, possibly turning them into a DPS hybrid, or making a Tank champion into an off-support, etc. In the beginning of a match you get to pick a Talent and a Loadout for your champion. Talents work as a large playstyle change while Loadouts act more as small changes further honing in on that exact way you want to play. You can create your own custom Loadouts for a champion via a neat card deck system.

[b][u]In-Match Items:[/u][/b]
To offset the fact that you're locked into a champion the whole match once you choose (choices have weight, a plus in my book!), you can buy items while in spawn that can further affect your playstyle. These temporary items can be bought with credits that are awarded for doing things in a match. Getting kills/eliminations, playing the objective, performing role-based tasks like healing, absorbing damage, etc, are all methods to earn them. The items vary in scope from things like life steal, resistance to crowd control, faster movement speed, ability to see cloaked/invisible enemies and everything in between.

Here are a few more pluses that I enjoy about Paladins:

CROSSPLAY
Dedicated servers
Anti-cheat
Ways to earn skins/cosmetics for free
Fair and rewarding seasonal battle pass
Regular updates and balance changes
Bot/Practice matches, Casuals, Ranked modes
Firing/Practice Range

Hopefully something I said above has piqued your interest because you'll quickly discover there's a  surprisingly deep game to be had in Paladins. It's criminally underrated! I know I've been nothing but positive so far, so let me share just a few cons from my personal experience.  I've had random crashes and bugs that can be as harmless as a visual glitch or serious like an ability just plain not working at all.

Playing solo is totally fine, but this game, as with many, is MUCH MUCH more fun with friends, so grab a buddy (or 4) and head on into Paladins and see if you end up enjoying this game as much as I have come to in my 100+ hours so far. I look forward to my next 100 and hopefully beyond!

I didn't want to write this, in first place but I just feel like it needs to be heard. There's a lot of positive feedback for Paladins on Steam. But they are from people who have like 2-50 hours in the game and let me tell you, it's not enough to get a basic understanding of this game. 
Starting with something not really important, there are many visual bugs that are with us since the beta. There are even new ones, so I'll give you some quick examples. You often get blank messages from the game that you can't close. You can not see the avatars in the queue. Some legendary cards are bugged and you can not see them without moving the mouse. But do not fear, some have been fixed. After 2 years. I understand that visual bugs are not that game breaking, but they are still disgusting for me and can be to some new players.
Next up, we have new/reworked maps. They are really beautiful but the main problem is optimization. While on an old maps you can have around 100fps on baazar you get 20-40fps. After this, there come hitboxes. The best example of this is Frozen Guards, where the hitboxes are bigger than the textures and you often get stuck on them, dying for no reason. Also, there are places where you can hit but not get hitted, or you can stay under the map for the whole round. Skyboxes are non-existent and some textures are too short, making them just unpleasant to look at. New timber mill is no better than this one. You can also kill yourself on spawn too.
Time for something serious. Matchmaking. The worst thing in this whole game. Mostly when you join the casual queue, you pretty much do not care about ranks or levels on the opposing team, and I can totally understand that. But when you start playing ranked games, you often see unbalanced teams. As a master player, I can tell you that season 3 was the worst I have seen. Masters/diamonds playing with golds/platinums in the lobby. It was very stressful for both sides. Masters were mad at the low elo players and the golds were stressed because they just didn't know what to do yet. They should have been studying the game at their level and not being carried by better players. But season 4 got me. Evil Mojo announced bigger reset for the new season and guess what. Ex masters/diamonds with 2-3, sometimes even 0-5, qualifiers got diamonds. That's not what the reset was supposed to be about and it's so wrong in every way. Most master/diamond players are boosted, throwing other matches and making game experience horrible. They are not banned from the game or matched up with weaker players.
The game servers are no joke - lags are everywhere. And they can even say that's your fault. I have a ping of over 15 in every single game, yet Paladins is the only one where I have lags with a ping like that. I get kicked out of matches more often than I get into them. Sometimes the game even crashes on its own or I get disconnected in the middle of a match for no reason. Even delay is back. It's like you need a computer from NASA, to play it, even on low graphics.
And that's where we go to Paladins dead-sport. Evil Mojo has informed us that there will be no e-sport for Paladins in 2021. The devs are killing their own child with this. Without a competitive scene, most long-term players will just move to new games where they can actually achieve something and use their skills. And without it, there will most likely be no streamers and no new viewers interested in the game to try it out for themselves. Casual players can not make this game come alive. They have nothing to make them stick around longer, as the pro players they favour will just disappear. They will get bored and move on to something new.
And as for casual players, parties are also bugged so you have to restart the game to invite someone again. And even if you get in queue, there is a high chance that only one of u will get into the lobby and the other one will get desertered.
Also, Evil Mojo does not care about hackers or drop hackers. The game has no valid way to prevent cheating, and the developers do not try to ban them. Even after emails or tickets, most players are free to roam around the game.
As for balance, it's not perfect and the devs clearly do not understand their game and way they should operate with legendaries, cards, and cooldowns. They nerf things that are perfectly fine the way they are, but leave overpowered things untouched.
To make everything clear, this game gets worse every year. But thanks to it, I have met amazing people and made some pretty good friends. Over time, I feel like I need to move on from it. It stresses me out too often and I can not watch devs destroy my good memories. I definitely do not recommend playing it, alone or with friends. Try other games instead.
PS. Fk u Mojo Jojo

Hi. An old paladins' player here and I want to type few words to people who think about starting adventure in this game.
DON'T DO THAT.
Game is outdated. Customs and training room lacks features (in custom game you can practically play only 1 vs 1, 2 vs 2 etc.)
Game also has really small player base. In ranked (in casual too) you can be queued with top100 gms or masters while being new player. In higher ranks you will play with practically the same people all the time.
Players are often toxic (leaving, huge ego, in ranked mode troll picks).
Servers has less than 30 tickrate and are hardly secured, a lot of matches ends with player drophacking.
Game is also very bugged, you can get a crash for no reason, you can end up in infinity loop after getting a new skin. And it's only beginning of list...
Hi-rez also resigned from e-sport scene, which is a bad signal for a game.
Respect yourself  and your time guys. Don't play that game.

Hi there, i am a sea player having close to 1.5k hours gameplay on paladins. I will be focusing more on the bad side  / the unfun side of this game instead of going for the positive ones, and believe me, this game is hella fun and is a must play in the genre of free to play steam games. There are 47 champions in this game as of 01/21. And balancing every champion is really hard.  So there might be a unbalanced champ everytime one major update goes off. But we can ban that particular champ while we are going for ranked match. This game has potential, really fun to play with friends and runs easily on most of the low end gpus. The match making sometimes can make you question urself why did you even install this game. The MM is horrible sometimes. So you wont be having a pleasant game every game even if you are a grandmaster. The amount of hackers arent that bad. I haven't encountered myself one for a couple of days. Ratio of getting a hacker is probably like 20:1 for me. Note that im playing on sea server, i dont know what's going on in the other servers. The server lags are the worst thing to happen, the game will not be playable at all, even tho the ping is fine. But the game is constantly getting updates and fixes. The game is getting better and better. To end the summary, you wont be getting bored anytime soon because of the amount of champions and amount of talents and the amount of styles you can play with a particular champ.

While compared to Overwatch many times in the past, there has been a wide divergence from the game it was once in beta and the game it came out to be now. 
A strategic hero-shooter updated frequently with new champions (over 50 at the time of this review), each with select sets of abilities that are easy to understand and fun to master. The gameplay is quick, yet methodical as the time to kill for each champion varies, but this allows for a chance to react to getting shot at most of the time.
While cover certainly helps, you won't find yourself stuck under it the whole game as it plays a lot like a run and gun. As stated before, there are over 50 champions to unlock, with a select amount on rotation at a given time and some given at the start. The champions pack is available to purchase for a limited time, so if you're interested in the whole game experience then I would pick it up ASAP.
With customization options ranging from loadouts to change the nuances of the abilities, to highly detailed skins with custom voice actors, there is a lot of freedom of expression to be found in this game that is not found in others.
If you are still wondering if this is a game worth sinking time (and/or money into), just look at my hours. This is a fun one for sure.

Bugsnax is a light-lifting puzzle adventure that is elevated by its strong story and characters that I enjoyed until the very end. Despite some simple mechanics, the laughs outnumbered the groans significantly as I found myself surprisingly invested in the events of the island and its inhabitants. With over 100 Bugsnax to discover and catch there’s plenty here to entertain the completionists, alongside those just looking for a well-told six-hour mystery that will keep you guessing until after the credits roll. All of this while making you feel emotionally connected to the characters, something you previously might have thought sounded impossible. Until you saw a carrot crawl, that is.

Well as someone who has sunk a solid chunk of time into both Overwatch and Paladins, I feel i can safely say this game is no Overwatch clones as some might say.  Paladins is a fun game with frequent updates and is for certain worth the price of free. What it is not how ever is balanced or simple. I've never read the patch notes nor seen them for that matter so i have no way of knowing if any nerfs or buffs have ever occurred, but in the time ive played it certainly doesnt feel like it. It does feel like the devs just made some characters op and some not and pitched them against each other anyway. BUT this isn't always a bad thing because it can make for some interesting and sometimes satisfying moments in game I.e. using a weaker character and just wrecking someone who should've melted you. So in that way the game is unbalanced. Paladins is NOT simple due to character loadouts you have to create before game, this however is NOT a bad thing. It allows each player to create unique and individualized loadouts for EVERY character with 6 slots for SIX different loadouts for EACH character. This Overwatch does not have. Paladins also has items to purchase mid match to increase or decrease different things for your character i.e. ability cool downs, movement speed, and more. Overwatch DOES NOT have this and those things alone separate the two games to me.

My only real complaints about Paladins are some characters and some maps. Some characters are blatant rip offs of Overwatch characters Khan and Rein being the most obvious. A few characters have even been changed because of this. Next there are a few maps that are simply poorly designed. For example there is a winter map (i cant remember the name) that is god awfully long, if you have to push the point to the end of this map and die near the end point it takes so damn long to get to the other side you could lose if you only have a short amount of time left. Those are my biggest complaints about Paladins. New players may have complaints about having to unlock Champions but at the time of writing this there is a Champions pack to unlock all present and future Champions. I did this and I recommend that you do too.

On the subject of in game transactions Paladins has those as well, there are cosmetics ranging from emotes, character skins, mount skins, voice lines, and more that can be purchased or unlocked through loot boxes. Some loots boxes are holiday/season based and rotate through the year some cosmetics are limited and earned through events/challenges or through the battle pass(es). There are also skins based on character mastery.

All in all Paladins can be a very fun game and you cannot beat the price of free its also nothing like Overwatch so if the claims that it was a clone made you hesitant dont let it lead you astray this game only shares minor likeness with Overwatch and is worth playing. 8/10 because its not perfect.

Don't. Every Paladins player secretly hates it. Just don't.
Okay now that we have that aside, heres an actual review:
The game is very fun but also very toxic. I personally think it's only fun when playing with a friend. Alone the game isn't that great 'cause you just get shit-talked by every teammate. Of course you can just mute them but it still affects you/the person who gets shit-talked. For example when playing healer (coming from a support main) you get flamed for 'not healing enough' and it just affects the way you play. Some people might be able to ignore it but other people (myself included) feel bad and try to heal that person more but that results in the other teammates dying. Fact is: the community is trash. 
The game itsself is a joke. There's bugs everywhere and sometimes you literally just slide through the ground or walls which then results in death. Also hirez doesnt do anything about it. Many bugs get reported but they either make skins instead of fixing bugs or they answer with "I'm sorry, but it's a wifi problem, not a game problem" (This happened to many people, for example itsAdrix.)
Another big issue is the tutorial. Personally after first playing the tutorial I still didn't understand. 1. They only show you Viktor and they literally don't show you how to play different classes (Frontline, damage, flank, support) 2. It doesn't show a lot of things, just how to cap and push. I didn't know how to buy items for a long time because I didn't get what they're for. (This is just my personal opinion)
A problem that always accurs is the bad matchmaking. I mean, level 50 and 30 playing against 200 and 300+? That's a joke. Sometimes I can't even enjoy the game because I have level 100 people in my team and we are playing against level 500-900 players. Big yikes.
It's a great game for people who don't care what others think and who just play for fun. If you get affected by what others say or if you play to win then you shouldnt get it.

If you love games like overwatch but you stopped playing because it had gotten too competitive or just couldn't keep up with the meta then you will love this game, since it is the same kind of concept as overwatch however it isn't as competitive or that hard of a game to keep up with the meta, id also recommend this to those are interested in overwatch but didn't get into it for it's competitiveness.

I really was into this game some years ago and I'm having a great time playing it again. I actually have much more hours than the amount that steam says because I was used to play on the launcher, which could be found from the game's site and which had nothing to do with Steam. Then the launcher was deleted and the only way to play was with steam (now it's on Epic Games store too) and I couldn't have steam on my pc, so I stopped playing Paladins (also I had bought Overwatch). I'm happy to see that the game it's still being updated with new characters and events.
Now let's talk about the game. It's fun! The characters (even if some are very... let's say "inspired" by Overwatch characters) have all unique and memorable designs and voice lines and the maps are well designed and different from each other. The powers are fun to use and well balanced. The card system is very interesting and can really change the gameplay of a champion, letting players that have different styles of playing to make the champion more comfortable and easier to play. The item moba style system is very interesting too and, like in mobas, buying the right items is very important. 
When I started playing years ago I had bought the champions pack and I don't regret my decision at all, because having all the roster of characters just makes the experience more fun and less repetitive.
The major negative things that I don't like are the loot boxes (I'm always against them, even if it's only about cosmetics, as this game since it's not a pay to win) and the fact that you have to pay a lot of in-game currency (I don't remember how it's called, but let's say it's like the CoD points) to change the name.
Oh and thanks for the horses.

[h1]Tagging this review an overall negative one is extremely difficult to do, because I really love this game at its core.[/h1]

To get it out of the way, no. It's not a clone of you-know-what and I hate that I even have to mention that. There are similarities between any game and any other one. This one just happened to come out in a similar time frame as a AAA title of the same genre.
Paladins is a class-based FPS "hero shooter" that is influenced highly by MOBA style games. There's an in-game item shop, for example, where you can purchase upgrades throughout the match. Another feature that sets this game apart from most is the champion loadout creator, which can either make or break a champion and allows for customization ranging from specialized builds, to hybrids, to flat-out memes. These features make the gameplay interactive not only in a match, but in the menu between games where you can hone them to suit your needs. The game features a huge cast of playable characters (pushing 50 at the time of writing) and has everything from unbreakable tanks to high-octane glass cannons. There are unique aesthetics and themes featured in every character and map, with plenty of skins, emotes, and more depending on your taste. 

I've played this game since the beta in 2016, though, and it's had the same problems all this time. Firstly and perhaps most obviously, [b]bugs.[/b] The amount of glitches, crashes, and exploits that have been in the game since launch makes it feel like it never should have escaped beta. There have been multiple champions actually banned in competitive and ranked just because of how unpredictably buggy they are. The spaghetti code that the developers at Evil Mojo have inherited has only snowballed, and I don't entirely blame them for not being able to keep up.
Secondly, the community is extremely polarizing. There are some players who are only here to have fun and are truly pleasant to play with. Unfortunately, it usually only takes one negative person to spoil the whole attitude of the match with their ego. Once that happens, it contaminates the rest of the team and only perpetuates itself more. This can sometimes get to the point where people will actively throw or AFK in matches ([strike]including[/strike] - [i]specifically[/i] in ranked) or even wrongfully report other players out of spite. This whole situation makes the game fatiguing at times, even if you do your best to mute and ignore them. 
The last major problem is balance. There are characters that are picked in almost every match, even in casual, and others that are rarely seen. Of course, this is natural for any game, but the big problem here is that the top-tier champs tend to also be the most annoying to play against. Indestructible shields, permanent reveals, and nigh unavoidable burst damage, just to name a few. These can make the game really annoying to play. Another balance issue is the matchmaking. Ironically, the matchmaking in casual tends to be a bit better than ranked. ELO scores seem arbitrary and can often make it borderline impossible to climb ranks regardless of your performance. I personally had close to a 60% winrate in ranked near the end of Season 1, and was still losing twice as much rank for a loss as I was gaining for a win (still salty I didn't get Masters that season). 
There are other minor problems as well. The store can be money-hungry at times, there are content droughts now and then, and so on. But these are the major points.

However, with all the negative feedback this game receives, I still come back to it. Is it sunk cost? Can I not bear to abandon my waifus? I really don't think so. Again, at its core and while functioning as intended, Paladins is an amazing game. It has a very tight-knit cult following and a group of loving devs (although some might disagree with me on that one). I can tell this game has improved since I started playing, but it simply hasn't gotten to the point where I can recommend it yet. I'm critical of it because I love it and want to see it grow. If you're willing to push through the flaws for an experience that'll have you coming back for the highs, then by all means try it out. Otherwise, pass.

I'm going to start off this review by saying Paladins is not a bad game, it is simply extremely flawed. (From a free to play player's perspective)

The game itself is fun to play with friends but is really testing at times. Why you ask? Allow me to elaborate. 

It is definitely NOT an Overwatch clone as most people claim however in the developers quest to make this game unique as possible they have spiralled the overall structure of the game out of control.

The matchmaking is really luck based as the game sometimes puts you with people who have no experience in the game, or put with people who have hundreds of hours and the best Champions. 

Now the Champions, to put it simply, this games meta revolves around the Champions, more than other similar games. This is not a positive. You could go into the game, grind up some coins, get the character you like but oh no the enemy team is running Maeve,Skye, Atlas, Khan and Io. Simple answer: you are fucked unless you have a similarly broken team comp on your end. Sure you can buy all characters and resolve this problem but keep in mind this is based off a free to play player's perspective. By doing this the developers have essentially given you a task, not to get your favourite character but essentially a good character who granted you may enjoy but that ruins the freedom of the game does it not? Say you get thrown into a match with 5 Skye mains, how will you go about it then?

In summary: in exchange for a higher skill requirement, the game has become completely unbalanced. 

The maps are quite horrendous too, they give so many options for the broken characters to wreak havoc. 

I know this game's target has been to be casual friendly however it honestly is the opposite of what it strived to be. You need to get wiped and thrown into the dumpster time and time again in order to truly get a grasp of how to play tactfully and how to counter said top tiers. 


This could all be solved by lots of balance patches towards all characters, revamping of the maps and removal of bugs. Also the game should NOT be free to play. This will remove your false sense of promise, I'm going to use Overwatch as an example. Overwatch is quite expensive however has a far more balanced and polished system. Paladins let's you play a base roster and a free rotation, these could be good but you're not going to get the same satisfaction as having access to all of them, by going through this process it eliminates your thought of purchasing the full game. 

"This ladies and gentlemen is what we call S T O N K S marketing!" - a Paladins dev, maybe. 


This game has so much potential, however as I said at the start, it is extremely flawed.

I'm going to give it a 6/10 rating. 

(Steam really needs to add the option for a mixed review since my thoughts really aren't heavily negative or positive.)

Thx for reading my rant novel. Have a good day.

Surprisingly fun team shooter game with roles like damage, healing, tank and sniper. Each character has unique moves they can do, with common control buttons between all characters in any role. I play this game weekly as a team with two friends on voice chat, and am really enjoying the replay value. 

The additional character skins you can unlock are also high quality, often with different voice packs and weapon effects. Some are just fun and silly, like the beach outfits with squirt guns instead of real ones, the monstery champions that turn into big plushies with a custom skin, the mermaid and merman skins, etc. 

If you don't usually play PvP games, this one might be a good one to start with because you get a team of four people to fight alongside you as well. Haven't run into any toxic players yet, the worst has been when teammates have no idea how to play their role (and all newbies don't know 'til they do!) 

Finally, it's free to play with whatever rotation of champions they have for free currently, so you can try it out before committing to buying a pack of champions. I was lucky enough to get the full champions pack as a gift, and it's pretty awesome. Dozens of characters and play styles to choose from. Recommended game. ♥

First thing I ought to say is that my hours are way off. I played this game a ton on the old launcher, especially during the Closed Beta. Now, with that out of the way:

This game is awful. If you're looking for a game that requires some semblance of skill, then you should look elsewhere. if you're looking for a fun, unique experience, you should also look elsewhere. They've stripped this game of most of it's unique, defining features (e.g. Old Siege and Mounting at any point)to bring you a bootleg Overwatch with what seems like slightly better balance (Though that is a very, very low bar). 

This game is fundamentally broken, and is too forgiving to players. Auto aim abilities should not exist, period. You should not be able to completely miss your shot with a sniper rifle and still have it counted. If you think that's an exaggeration, go try someone like Strix in training mode. You can completely miss by a fairly wide margin and still get credit for the shot. In addition, there should never be hard CC. Like Grover can completely shut down a flank member for about a second or two, and it's an instant death sentence. There is very little counterplay to it, unless you want to waste credits on CC resist or avoid trying to target Grover entirely.

The last thing to say, is that there is one reason to play this game in my estimation. And that is simply for the really, really silly builds you can make for some of the characters. Dodge roll Cassie where you leap like 15 ft or -90% gravity IO can be pretty entertaining. Unfortunately, I'm not sure that makes it worth playing though. If they brought back interesting mechanics like mounting at will, or what to me seemed like a huge selling point originally, the Original Siege game mode where you had to lay siege to a building to break down several barricades to get into the vault, then it might be worth playing again. But alas, I think that is that is gone for good and we are stuck with a low-skill, generic game for the rest of eternity.

[h1] Paladins - 7.2 / 10 [/h1]


Paladins is a hero shooter, much in the likes of Overwatch, but with more pronounced MOBA elements. The cast of numerous characters is colorful and they all have their own personality, even though some of them come off as rushed or not very well thought out. The graphics are serviceable, which means they are not the best but not the worst either; they are colorful and get the job done, allowing the game to run on numerous machines, including the Nintendo Switch, which has become my favorite way to play the game, especially in portable mode.

What makes Paladins special is its unique Card system, which allows you to customize each and every hero with your personal play style. It’s rare that you’ll see two players using a certain hero the same way, and this makes the game less stale overtime than other similar offerings. Because of this, each and every game ends up playing differently, and this is exactly what I love about the game.

The in game economy is based on cosmetic only loot boxes, which means that despite being free to play and not counting individual skill, no player will ever be stronger than another.

The game receives updates, events and new heroes extremely frequently. Even though some bugs and glitches tend to stay longer than necessary at times, they rarely become game breaking or end up taking away from the enjoyment of the game.

Paladins is a free to play title that simply doesn’t feel like one, and this balance is very difficult to achieve nowadays. A well crafted card system, colorful heroes and good shooting mechanics make this game a joy to play, allowing it to stand out among the crowd of otherwise stale titles offered by much more renowned names in the industry.

This game...
I started playing in November of 2020. I stopped playing shortly after (~10 hours of playing) because no friends of mine were playing. I picked it back up in late December and launched into a paladins frenzy/addiction, I was hitting 90 hours per two weeks. (Thanks covid!) I burned out of this in mid-may where I slowed down quite a bit, by then I didn't like the event pass (beach bash) nor had any reason to play. When the Gen:lock update show premired I was dragged into the game again. I now have around 15 hours per two weeks (likely to change) (AS of August-November I average about 4 hours)
Now onto the actual game.
Paladins is a hero shooter. If you don't like the aspect of shooter games this game is not for you. The two month gap between update can be troubling since there's not much torwards the end for regular players. (Lack of late update content) If you like grinding games and are willing to put a lot of time into the game this IS the game for you, heres why:
1. Grind gold for champ
2. Put in 40 hours for a golden skin
3. Long battlepass/eventpass
4.Weekly Pull-out-your-hair Trails
If you truly want to become "the best" there is competitive play. The climb can be quite vicious (be prepared)
Be ready to play flex (any role), Play meta (best champs/stats), and aimless toxicity.
So why play this game?
If you want a free multiplayer shooter to play with your friends this game is great.
>>Comparison<<
Paladins or Overwatch?
**I have alot more time in paladins so please know this isn't perfect**
Champions? Paladins with 50. (As of gl update) (Going to stop updating this, there is over 50)
Player-base? Both games can be really toxic or great.
Comp? Overwatch has OWL, Plus a better ranked system.
Early Game? OW for sure, you insta-unlock all the heros.
Late Game? Paladins, by a bit. There's more skins, emotes, sprays, titles, and borders. 
Graphics? OW easily has it (beware low-end computers/systems)
Paladins is f2p
Overwatch is 20$
Your choice
Overall, I do love this game and rate it 80/100
(be ready for bugs btw :))

It uses EAC though, so that sucks. Only real complaints I have are that like any other game I ran into a fair amount of bots/boosters and that kinda kills the fun, but matchmaking was quick. Didn't encounter any toxic players.

tl;dr: chill game to play with friends that know how to run party comps.

One of the better free-to-play games out there.

A nice hero-shooter that leans more heavily on it's moba side than games like Overwatch, Paladins focus more on combat versatility than pure objective-based gameplay.

The Deck, Items and Talents mechanics allow for countless combinations that makes it so two players selecting the same hero won't play quite the same way.

Everything tied to gameplay can be unlocked with the earnable in-game currency at a very acceptable pace.

Overall, the game is deep enough, well-enough built, and content rich to warrant you give it a go.

The concept of the game is pretty simple and sometimes it can be fun to play multiplayer with your buddies. And here comes the BUT... The game is completely broken. 

Prepare yourself to wait 10 min for a lobby just to get that lobby error message and wait a bit longer. Probably that's the reason why the competitive / ranked players are so toxic. Not mentioning that during my 61 hours of gaming I did not receive any of the 'skull' currency. 

The amount of payed content is another topic on its own. If you want to flex on your fellow buddies there is plenty of skins for most of the characters, although many of them are just copies in different color schemes. Then you have some emotes, sprays and other useless stuff that nobody wants, but you need something to fill the mystery boxes with, right. 

All in all the game is made to make money on you, so prepare your wallet.

pros:
+cute characters
+somewhat addicting

cons:
-complete lack of team balance
-promotion of microtransactions (champions cost a whole lot, but you can buy crystals or a champion pack)
-there are only a couple things in the game that you can buy with the in-game currency, even if, you have to grind a lot for them
-another game with a battle pass which you have to pay for to get some actually good stuff
-generally a big ripoff

conclusion: if you dont have to, dont start playing this game for the sake of your bank account/steam wallet and your own mental health. Teams are extremely unbalanced in a way you always get team mates that just started playing champions that were in the game for years, and you get enemies that might as well play pro league. You're just wasting your time.

Everything good about the game: Card system so you can make a champion the most interesting for you to play possible, the talent system which gives champions cool interesting abilities, items allow you to counter other strategies so nothing is too op.


Everything bad about the game: Hi-Rez, Hitboxes worse than a 2008 game, certain items are a must-buy so you don't really have a choice, nobody here is happy, you can get insulted for running a non-meta loadout in the NORMAL MODE of the game, like Furia with Exterminate, Furries exist, Hi-Rez doesn't care about the bugs and just spams limited skins, every single new champion they add has abilities already in the game for example Vora has a ability that is the exact same as grover's plant spiderman thing, imani has fernando's fireball but higher damage.
you need to grind for 20 hours to obtain a single champion out of the 40 you'll be trying to unlock in the game, and even then you'll probably end up not liking it, cause honestly if you buy willow and play a match as her it'll be the ultimate challenge to last more than 40 seconds without leaving, the game also has chests which are just a scam and nothing more than that, the only thing worth buying is battle pass but the battle pass usually just contains skins for the exact same 15 or so characters because Hi-Rez ignores all other characters, honestly i would actually like this game if all champions were free from the start, because currently every single team is almost exactly the same, 2 flanks 1 damage 1 support 1 frontline, and there are characters which are just obvious power creep, like seris and ying, Seris has higher damage than ying, and better talents aswell as her base damage being bigger, seris has a MUCH better ult than ying aswell as a way bigger healing output and a better ability to escape out of danger, the only advantage ying has over seris is that ying can send her clones in to kill people for her, which deals such low damage that theres no real point in doing it, but its not like the clones heal for more than 2 hp every 10 seconds. Hi-Rez had a very interesting character customizing system which everyone liked, but then they removed it for no reason at all and i think that shows their approach to caring about this game, they don't actually take the people's opinions in consideration, they just sort of randomly nerf and buff every hero, especially since i've heard from some youtube videos that they are trying to balance every champion around a 50/50 winrate, which is just ridiculous.

After 200h put into the game sadly I need to give it negative review. I love the gameplay (actually prefer it over Overwatch) but constant crashes, bugs in every aspect of the game and poor matchmaking makes this game quite really hard to enjoy. Devs are more focused on another battle passes with more skins where game needs proper fixes. New champions are just mix of abilities of other champions, and their original abilities are not really working as they should. Reporting system doesn't seem to work with so many trolls, smurfs or unprepared players in ranked games.  Even shops have their problems with bounty shop being down constantly and had many issues when I couldn't earn points from missions.

I played 5 games on rank today:
1. Got 1 kid who said he can only play 2 characters with roles already taken, He shouldn't be allowed with his time spent in the game into ranked. Lost in last round in effective 4v5.
2. Easy 4-0 win, matchmaking put kids in enemy team, who started flaming each other after the game.
3. Actual good, balanced game. Won in last round.
4. Had a 2 smurfs in my team, who didn't even bother to hide, easy win. Yes, I reported them, but there is not even an option to report someone for smurfing.
5. My entire team crushed at 3-3 and only one person from opposite team, so they could push through bots. Lost miserably and unfairly.

If you are prepared to spend money for the game like this, just try Overwatch, it can save you a lot of disappointment. I paid for the champions pack which is really important if you want to get serious in ranked (not being able to save a character or swap with someone else put you in big disadvantage). Rest of the paid stuff can be in theory bought or awarded for game currency, but they are mostly cosmetics.

 I can recommend this game if you don't care about technical problems and want to enjoy gameplay (which is somewhat balanced with all it's complexity) when playing with friends. Beware that after reaching diamond rank you can team up only with one more player, so if you want your 5 stack you are forced to go in casuals after this point.

EDIT: After another 30 hours or so I've decided to uninstall the game. Nothing changes, too many crushes, people who shouldn't play ranked and in general the game is not fun anymore.

Initially the game is fun but when you play it more and more and have encounters with each and every character a major flaw in it's design shows itself: Everything deals too much damage. Let me elaborate.

Whenever you make a character which is based in dealing lots of damage you don't make it so if you pick the character you are guaranteed to get a lot of kills because it is not fun neither for the giving or receiving end, on one side it is very easy and the other it is very frustrating. The major problem isn't the damage numbers by themselves but the inability to consistently avoid damage. Because everything does a lot of damage you should be awarded for dodging and punishing with your own but because you can't you are just left frustrated because the other player chose to pick a certain character.

I like the game, but because of this it is getting less and less enjoyable.

It is Overwatch, but far better in every single way possible, if you play Overwatch or was considering getting it, then play this instead, it simply takes everything that makes Overwatch great and makes it so much better. Not to mention Paladins is free. (maybe not graphics but who cares about that when gameplay is so much better?)
Edit: I now have 624 hours on the game and I regret nothing, when I wrote this I had 80.

I loved the game initially. Played it before it got on steam. 
Wanted to play overwatch but couldn't afford it. Paladins was my go to then. 
It turned out good with Loadout initially but then there was a point it started going downhill.
Hi-rez started to experiment and tried as much to balance from that point but no matter what they try to fix it wasn't worth it because they would damage the game in another way. But it really didn't matter anymore with introduction of lazy champion designs more and more. Kinessa and Viktor: ok they were your basic fps classes, but this game isn't TF2! with gun, it was about magic and brawling focused. Clones designs like tyra, strix, lian were being made since they ran out of ideas. Dont mention Vivian she's born because whoever designed her probably the most laziest person in the world. Characters in paladins needed to work together to play effectively as a group it doesn't matter if every role was picked there were combinations that had too picked for team synergy and that's where champions like Vivian come in. Doesn't matter what your team or the enemy team is for her to play effectively. All she has to do is sit back and hold lmb and rmb. Flanks? Hahah she can detect them coming with her drones. And get the jump on them. Two flanks?! No problem has a shield. Her ult is here have some more dps since we think your dps is too low for being a DMG champion. Hitbox? Lol what hitbox. My ult buddy got destroyed but no problem I'm a deploy a 2nd time. But how? Because I can charge my ult even with my ult already active. Mean while old favorites like drogoz get nerfed because of console scrubs and Vivian trash mains that complained about hard it was to hit drogoz on wyrm jets. His hitbox is big, his rockets are projectiles that require leading since their aoe is dog shit. A fucking crossbow shoots faster than a rocket.
A Rpg projectile moves at a speed of around 300 metres per second so since drogoz uses a handheld it should atleast shoot at half the speed, a hunting crossbow shoots a a arrow at a speed of 500 feets per second converted to 150metres per second. But in this game however it doesn't matter the rockets move like fuck all and the fire rate is slower than kindergarten kid spelling the alphabet. You can't play him unless you have a healer and another champion to cover your ass. You have to have actual skill to use him and when you do you get punished and get your ass handed over to most of the champions in the roster. Drogoz isn't what he used to be , he used to be a flying nightmare but not he's just a fly waiting to get swatted out of the sky. Only way to play with him is now cowering behind covers and making safe plays. Can't go crazy like before especially how most of my matches are giving me the best EVAH! recently.
If anything I wouldn't be suprised if they decide to stack her ultimate with the direction hirez is going.
Game breaking bugs, random DC's, bad servers, I usually don;t write reviews but I writing this because at this point of time I couldn't get to play a game because as soon as the match started I was getting dced to login screen only to get stuck in a loop of relogin reloading and dced. I live in SEA and I'm getting 120-150 ping as opposed to 40-60 in the earlier days because HI-rez turned out to be just another greedy low rez company that doesn't polish the game rather just vomit as many champions as it can with skins and stuff.
Characters that need skill to play are getting nerfed more while the ones that need actual nerf aren't getting them.
The new champion Vora is as boring and uninspiring as well, grover+zhin= vora. 
And now they are going to introduce another character soon which looks promising but unbalanced asf.
They are straying too far from the original soul of the game. 
This might be the last time I replay the game.

This game saved my life.

I am 25.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline broken. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ing minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you

The clearly superior game between this and Overwatch. This game isn't as polished as Overwatch but it makes up in better gameplay, mechanics, and balance. 

The Good - Hit detection is far superior to Overwatch and alot of other shooters that have been out in recent years. The characters are all for the most part pretty fun to play and all roles will have a character that you will enjoy. It is a great game to just casually play off and on as its easy to pick up and play a few rounds then move on. The Character designs are pretty unique and it has a charm for its aesthetic. This game does actually reward you for actually being good at it. It is possible to carry matches you should lose albeit they are hard and you have picked good perks and the character.  Balance feels for the most part pretty solid the only stand out overpowered character I felt was Inara but she was nerfed and doesn't feel as bad now. Unlike overwatches terrible character swapping mid match to ruin the balance of the game paladins opted in for a much better idea of giving you virtually perks or "items" (they aren't items they are perks) That you can buy in the match by killing/objective/time and they all have some uses the only real issue is that Cauterize is virtually manadatory on everyone since nearly everyone has some for of self sustain and you should be taking kill to heal every game on 90% of characters or life rip so that helps offset healing as well so those tie up 2-3 of the 4 slots you get and some characters really depend on having deft hands (a reload speed perk cutting it down by 20-40-60%) So you may be locked out of 4 perks and not be able to take a few of the counter perks like illuminate or i don't recall the name the one that reduces cc duration. But all though those are virtually mandatory its still a far better system of counter play then lol they have Roadhog pick zarya haha you lose trash design. 

The Bad - The monetization is atrociously anti consumer. So for new players getting new characters expecting to not pay is excessively bad. You can spend all day grinding and still wont be able to afford the highest gold tier characters further pushing you to want to spend money on it. I do think the pack for buying all champions forever is a decent deal but I don't like how bad it is forced on you and you can't realistically earn all the characters without sinking 1000's of hours to do so. Before I caved in and bought the character pack I had around 20 hours and I had afforded 1 60,000 and maybe 1 or 2 30,000. I can't recall to be exact but roughly around that and this is with the bonus starting gold new players get. Gold isn't super useful as its mostly cosmetic related which is fine just the amount that anything requires is ridiculous and the fact for mastery or character rewards you have to get the character to that level then pay your gold to unlock it instead of be given it for free is a rip off. Character leveling is extremely slow outside the 1st few levels and with a large portion if not most of the characters best talent from the 3 they get being normally the 8th level one it is also a big negative. And further to the cash monetization the skins for some really bad reason were almost all gated in old battlepasses which make them unobtainable completely or once in a blue moon to come back out or having to be found in a loot box. I may have some misinfo on how the skins work but majority are locked and obtainable by just picking the one you want and buying it. Some characters do feel a bit clunky to play unnecassarily from not being able to animation cancel some of your abilities like Dragos unable to use salvo without a full clip, Zhin unable to bellow to cancel his counterstrike things like this are minor but still a bit annoying.

The Why - Really this is just the mount system. It's really just tacked on and virtually useless since you can only use it at your spawn and it spawns you on it. It would be useful if you could mount up in the middle of a big map but can't outside getting to the point its just really tacted on and you wonder why they couldn't just make the maps smaller and not had the mount option since the perk for it is a noob trap. And fun fact you can literally unbind the key and you'll be fine.

All together if you are willing to spend 30 or 15 i think if you start its discounted to be cheap so if you never have played and see that advertisement i do recommend getting it for as cheap as possible to own all current and future heroes.  Then this game is I believe a good investment for fun. If you hate overwatch like me, or just want to play a different team based shooter like it and TF2,  Paladins may be a good choice for you. Even with the big bad segment i do recommend the game with its flaws. I'd rate the game as a whole 7/10.

I originally got this game a year or more ago because I wanted an alternative to Overwatch. Some people call it a clone and while I see similarities, they aren't the same game. One of the reasons I've started playing Paladins more recently is that I enjoy playing it as a casual player rather than a competitive player, which removes a lot of the normal stressors I have with playing Overwatch. 

Also, my craptop can actually run Paladins at 40-60fps (medium graphic settings, 1080p), but it can only run Overwatch at 10-30fps with all of the lowest settings, which makes Overwatch unplayable as an FPS for me. 

As for Paladins, I've really come to appreciate the massive character roster over time. Normally I'm a flex player in class-based shooters, but I feel as though my skillset is much more niche in Paladins. This isn't a bad thing, I just think that my playstyle isn't suited to as many characters in Paladins as other games I've played. 

I really appreciate the diversity in race and ethnicity for both real and fantasy races. I also really appreciate that there are gay pride profile pictures available for pocket change in game. I really love that the developers showed their support for the LGBTQIA+ community with that. It made me feel a lot more happy with the game, even if I'm not part of the community myself. 

Overall, I get an itch to shoot stuff in video games sometimes, Paladins has been my go-to game to scratch that itch for the past few years. If I had to issue one complaint, it's that I wish cosmetic items were more accessible to f2p players. I've paid to unlock all heroes and have played for 55 hours at the time of writing this review, and still have probably less than 10-20 skins for different heroes (thankfully, I have some for most of my favorite characters). The game is f2p and I understand that Paladins probably makes all of its money through its battle pass and cosmetics, but I wish I had the option to get more skins without paying money. 

It's possible that those opportunities exist and I missed them because I'm a casual player that just hops on to play whenever I'm bored or want to shoot stuff. But, that's my experience. Thanks for making such a great game and I'm looking forward to seeing its continued development as new characters are released!

I'll say one thing or maybe a few things. Both good and bad in my opinion.

The game is very good, game play is well, the mechanics can be buggy and the game can tend to crash sometimes but otherwise the game is pretty good. I enjoy the cross-play that was implemented in the game, I actually haven't had many issues with playing cross-play before. Though I don't really play paladin's at all on the computer, I know their servers aren't all that different. Don't @ me at that though if I am wrong about the servers ._.

 Now The bad part about it is where they basically reduce and continuously reduce the hero's ability's just because of a small portion of people who complain about character's being "too op" or "broken". Also why, just why add a healing reduction, damage do damage as it is, the healing reduction sometimes makes it really frustrating to heal, it makes healers feel like no matter what they do their healing just wont suffice. Like Ughh.

Anyways, On the character topic, I'm not saying there isn't ever any issues with characters possibly being bugged, the characters can be broken sometimes, i'm well aware of the fact that there is times when new updates come out and the game has a million different bugs. There even tends to be some hackers who like to casually take advantage of the game as well. Though that can really happen with any online game. 

In all honesty though, It's definitely a great game and I'd recommend it to other's. Just be prepared for a lot of bugs when new characters or battle passes come out, takes about a good month before everything actually gets fixed and there isn't as many bugs.

Paladins is one of the only hero shooters I actually like, the characters are distinct and easy to pick out in a fight by their silhouettes.

Aside from the bug fixes and the polish this game needs, it's actually pretty fun and well made game. It has enough features and differences to not just be considered an "Overwatch Clone". You can call me impressed in that regard.

The reason I'm giving this game a bad review however is for two reasons that go a bit hand-in-hand.

1. Matchmaking
2. New Player Experience

The Matchmaking has absolutely dumbfounded me time and time again, matching me against players with play-time on a single character that is approximately 10 times that of my total play-time. The amount of games I've played that have been 4-0 wins or losses is just way too damn high. There's absolutely no fun in stomping others or just getting straight stomped yourself. Maybe it's because the game doesn't have a player base as big as it's competitors but regardless it's frustrating playing for a couple hours and only getting 1 or maybe 2 good games in.

I want this game to succeed but the matchmaking really makes the game unbearable at times. Early on I was seeing myself playing solo at times but now I think I'm only going to play this game with my buds in the future.
