I have around 6000 hours total played on this game and well this game has seen better days.

This game used to be much more about individual skill but has been slowly pushed into a game where you heavily depend on your teammates. 

The constant nerfs to mobility while buffing the burst dmg has heavily changed the feel and flow of the game it honestly is starting to feel  more and more like Overwatch with every patch so those jokes about it being a Overwatch clone are starting to become relevant.

However the biggest issue in the game a the moment is the atrocious matchmaking it honestly feels more like a lottery than it being about your actual skill it's not uncommon that platinum rank players play vs grandmasters, add to the the fact that last picks are usually people that just started ranked and will pick whatever they want not what the team actually needs and it can happen often that you lose purely because that one teammate didn't take a tank or support and you're left without one of those roles

meta has become stale as well currently there a so many broken champs there is no way to ban them all and if the other team secures them it's usually gg champions like IO makoa torvald are very frustrating to play against as the have powerful abilities which require little skill to use and are quite overpowered 
for example makoa can build a loadout where you can get a shield reset if someone shoots his shield this can lead to him having a shield up 24/7 
or io having 15% dmg reduction to anyone she heals which makes them insanely tanky
meanwhile torvald gives the flank 1000hp a 50% movement speed boost and extra ammo while also healing him for a small amount 
even with wrecker the enemy still has a decent advantage vs you just because torvald  pressed q on him


Tl.dr is this game worth playing? : Kind of, I mean it's still the best hero shooter but it's nowhere near as good as it used to be I still suggest you try it out but  please please learn to play all roles decently before you go into ranked YOU are the one who can help fix matchmaking since apparently hirez doesn't give a damn

My First Game Review

I just started PC Gaming and when I wanted to find games that are simple by design and gameplay, I found Paladins to be just that. So far my enjoyment for the game is good! I feel that this game is good for beginners for the FPS genre or for those who want something not to "technical" or stressful.
My experience on casual play has been enjoyable. So far on all of my causal games, there wasn't any toxic chat. BUT I can't say the same for Ranked, when there is ranked, there are players who are competitive. My ranked experience is bad. [b]Overview[/b] - Paladins is a champion shooter that was taken out of early access in 2018. The game itself has three game-modes with the main mode being Siege, a fast 5v5 mode with the goal of capturing a point and pushing it's payload to the enemies spawn. The other two modes consist of an average Team Death-match and Onslaught, which is a mode to hold a point till one team reaches the point goal. The game is of course based around it's champions which have reached up to 46 different characters. The newest champion being Vora as of this review's writing. Each character is fairly balanced with a small few taking the meta's spotlight for that update. The biggest feature in my opinion is every champion's ability to have a custom load-out. This system allows a player to change a card deck and slightly edit abilities and stats in small ways that fix to the players chosen play-style. This allows extremely varied character style and game-play. 

[b]Pros[/b] - Paladins itself is varied in it's matches, with the high amount of characters and playstyles making every game feel different and competitive in a enjoyable way. The loadout system is fairly simple, easy to learn, fun to use and perfect for customizing a person's play style. The game is constantly updated with every patch bringing new content, bug fixes, balance changes and other small fixes. There are no pay-to-win features which allow's everyone to have fair matches based on skill. Everything bought is used for cosmetic reasons, let it be skins, death-cards, avatars, or even music. 

[b]Cons[/b] - With every good thing about Paladins there are a few small bad's. The biggest complaint I see with this game is it's extremely toxic community. Every once in a while you might play a game and be verbally attacked by a single player or possibly a whole stacked team calling you bad, trash, or something similar. Another complaint would be older characters not getting enough attention compared to newer champions. Most players would point to Torvald and Pip. A few other problems might come from performance hiccups or crashes. 

[b]Final Statement[/b] - Overall Paladins is a fantastic game held-back by a few problems and a bad community. The game itself has many enjoyable moments and allows a lot of play-style customization, replay-ability, and over-all fun. Personally I see the game getting better and better over time, with the newest updates showing the developers getting better with their craft. The art team (Specifically Thunderbrush for being the most noticeable) make some fantastic splash-art for the character with each piece being beautiful and satisfying to look at. I suggest for a people to install the game and try it personally to see if they enjoy it or not. 

[b]Final Rating[/b] - 8/10

I love Deathmatch, but I am also aware that it is a dying game mode. 

Paladins is one of the more recent games that is helping to keep it alive and with the all of the unique abilities that come with each Champion, it mixes each engagement enough to where it's not the same thing over and over again.

I think the production quality does not reach AAA, 5-star studio quality and that's important to mention because that might be the selling point for some people. If that is the case, I implore you to set your differences aside and play the game for a day or two. Find a character you might be able to tap into.

Once you start tapping into Champion loadouts, you'll start to see how this game actually plays very smart. Whether you go DPS, Tank, Support, etc. you have the ability to capitalize on certain aspects of your build that might suit you well in combat. Depending on what you choose, it can work for (or against) the composition of your team's build. 

The Payload pushing mode is not bad, but I personally would say that it's not the game's main attraction. If you're looking for a F2P Overwatch, I can understand why you are looking at this game, but when you own and play both, you see how differently they handle and they are hard to hold next to each other, despite the number of similarities.

If you're trying this out for the first time, I would DEFINITELY try out Deathmatch first, Siege second, and Payload only if you insist.

Tl;dr: Lots of fun characters to try with customizable loadouts, though you do have to grind to unlock most of them (unless of course you're willing to pay some money to unlock them). Bring friends for the best experience. Expect the occasional crash or disconnect.

Paladins is a fun team-based hero-shooter, with a wide selection of Champions to choose from (though you only have a select few unlocked at the start unless you buy the Champion's Pack) and you can change how you play them with the Talent and Loadout system.  However, I would STRONGLY recommend you grab a couple friends to play with you.  

Solo queue-ing in Paladins is entertaining at best, but infuriating at worst.  Playing with a team of randoms while going up against high-ranked players or a team that is obviously coordinating via something like Discord is often one-sided. The causal modes will only have voice chat enabled for the other players are in your party, so no voice communication with random teammates. There is a VGS (Voice Guided System) to make your character say callouts, but I've found that takes some getting used to in order to use effectively, and even then your random teammates may not heed your callouts.  Also, because you cannot see what the enemy has selected  until everyone is locked in, it can lead to infuriating games where your team composition is hard-countered.

Ranked mode does have team voice chat enabled and a pick/ban system, so games should (theoretically) be more evenly matched and should alleviate some of my criticisms above, but in order to play ranked you need a certain number of Champions unlocked. I have not played ranked mode, however, and cannot say with certainty that the experience is better than casual modes.

Additionally, be prepared for occasional crashes and disconnects.  I've had this happen to me more frequently than with any other game I've played, and when it happens the disconnected player is replaced by a Bot, which is almost worse than just playing a 4v5. There's also no obvious notification when a player is replaced by a Bot, so you may not even realize a teammate has disconnected until you see their character meandering straight into the objective. Fortunately, disconnected players can reconnect, so if they can reboot their game quickly, the amount of time the Bot has to feed into the enemy team is minimal.

Despite my criticisms above, I've had a lot of fun playing this with my friends. I've enjoyed trying out different characters, experimenting with loadouts and trying to find ways to best synergize with my friends. A few rage moments, sure, but that's to be expected with any competitive game.

I highly recommend that you play Paladins.

The Paladins community can be very self-consuming and the game has been declared dead 100 times by now, almost as often as TF2. However I believe that right now is a golden era of the game that you should experience while it still lasts. As of writing this, infinite shield Makoa and [i] Burn Monster! [/i] Tyra are the largest balance issues the game faces. While these are issues that are certainly deserving of changes, I find that as a whole, Paladins is in a really good place. It has a high and consistently playing base. The content we've gotten hasn't always been perfect but the newest champions we've received, like Vora, Raum, Tiberius, Atlas, etc. have all been A+ additions. Not to mention that we've seen positive reworks of older maps, Frozen Guard especially. The real issue with the game at the moment is just that balance changes are sometimes slow to come, leading to long periods of meta dominance. However, something that makes Paladins so special is that although there is a "meta", virtually any team composition can work so long as the players are skilled and choose characters that compliment each other properly. Even deeper than that is the ability to create card loadouts for each champion, meaning that an experienced player can transform a champion that is often ignored by the meta into a powerful fighting force that compliments the uniqueness of that individual's playstyle. While HiRez definitely has a lot of control over which champions are best, the players have an equal amount of say over the matter as they develop loadouts in creative, personal, and often surprising or unpredictable ways. For this reason, Paladins continues to grow not only because the developers continuously add content, but also because players slowly develop playstyles and tactics for their favorite champions, perpetually heightening their own learning curves and becoming better players as a result.

[h1] It was a good, until it got killed by it's own creators [/h1]

I, personally, has a mixed feelings about this game. It was a nice game with developers actually care for the community. 

[b] Bugs: [/b]
Of course any games have bugs, however the bugs in this game seem to almost never get fixed. They promised to fix them, but instead they removed some good features in order to "fix those bugs", ironically creating more bugs in the process and not fixing any. 

[b] Lack of content: [/b]
Some battle pass themes are cool but the content are bad due to skins only for famous characters, somewhat badly-made and not fitting to the characters at all. The battle passes seems to be rushed in a way and they're only a few weeks long.
Since 2018, they stopped making events for the players, so basically it's just Siege, Team Deathmatch, Objective and Ranked (basically Siege but more pressure). It'd be unfair to compare, but back in the beta version, there were many cool events with good lore for new characters.

[b] Characters: [/b]
To be honest, the characters are cool with their own skills, lores and interactions with specific characters. Some characters' abilities are cool but can be sometimes unbalanced, thus being requested by many players to nerf or remove. There are some old characters from beta that "died" because the dev don't want to add any more content to them and instead they give those contents to the "more popular" characters.

[b] Community: [/b]
The community is somewhat nice, better than Overwatch's in a way or two. In Ranked you can find people who make tactics to their team, trolls that don't want to cooperate, salty people, toxic people who will try to destroy you and your life etc. The same goes to normal matches.

[b] My opinions: [/b]
A good game for people who like hero-shooting type games. Recommend to play with friends instead of alone.

[spoiler] I enjoyed the game, call me weak but the lack of contents and community make it harder to play. The game would be better if their developers care for it like the Smite team, who actually fixing stuffs and adding good battle pass themes. [/spoiler]

When hearing about this game, the first thing that comes to mind is OW clone. I love both games and next are 3 reasons why you should try Paladins:
1. Champion customization: You can create up to 5 different loadouts, modifying the champion abilities.
For example, you can play a healer as a flank (Pip) or a flank as a healer (Moji). And given the right situation, hybrid playstyles are actually in the meta.
2. In-game Item shop: You earn “Credits” by kills, objective time, assists, healing, shielding. With Credits, you can buy items that counter the enemy playstyles.
For example Wrecker is an item that gives bonus dmg to shields, Resilience reduces the effects of slows and stuns.
3. Balanced game mode: Siege is the main game mode and personally it’s the main reason I love Paladins. How many times have you felt hopeless after a defend or attack round in OW, TF2 or Dirty Bomb? In Siege, you have a chance to win till the last overtime.

The objective is taking control of the “Capture Point” by standing on it. Once it’s captured, a payload spawns and the score changes from 0-0 to 1-0 for the team that capped the point.
The team in the lead has to escort the payload into the enemy base before the 2:30 minutes mark. A successful payload push would give another point to the leading team, making the score 2-0. A successful defense from the losing team would equalize the score (1-1). First team reaching 4 points wins, and you can’t earn the fourth score by defending, but only by capturing the point or pushing the payload.

You could say: “But if I’m losing 2-0, I practically lost!” And you wouldn’t be more wrong. The team with the score disadvantage captures the point with a faster rate, meaning you have to stay less time on the point to cap it.

The fight is never over until the last fight, and this is why I love this game

This is a gem of a game. It offers fast gameplay and most of all, champion ability customizations with a card loadout system and itemization. The game also has cross-platform play now. You can play with PC, Xbox, PlayStation and Switch players in the same match. You can change this in the settings.

Each champion has 4 or more abilities plus an ultimate ability that has to charge up over time. Rate of charge is dependent on how you play. There are 4 cards to customize each ability and there are 4 more cards to add more utility to your champion. 5 Cards can be added to a loadout and each card can be upgraded in its ability for up to five points. Each loadout has 15 points max to use. You can build your champion the way you want to play and experiment on different loadouts. 

There are items to be purchased during a match using credits earned during a match. All champions have access to these items and choosing a certain item in a certain scenario can tip the match into your team's favour. This adds another level to the game. 

There are bad things about this game as well. Bugs are a major issue that plague the game. If you are a casual player then it is easy to overlook. Champion balance is an issue as well but with a game that is this customizable, it is too be expected. The matchmaking is poor depending on the server you are playing on. 

So if you are looking for fast pace casual gaming experience with "play it your way" champions then this is a definite pickup for a fun time. Though, don't blame the developers if you get addicted

It's hard not to compare this game to Overwatch, as it's obviously a clone with an extra layer. If you're looking for Overwatch with a little extra depth in character playstyle, this'll scratch the itch.

Each character has a loadout that allows them to invest points into up to 5 perks (decreased cooldown on an ability, increased hp, movespeed buffs, etc.) and they can invest 15 points per loadout. So basically, you can buff one of your abilities to be super strong, or tweak some numbers to suit your playstyle. Cool concept.

There's also in-game item builds. The builds are super simple, which I appreciate. If you're familiar with mobas, this'll be really easy to pick up. It's stuff like "increased cooldown reduction" or "dmg reduces enemy healing". 4 skills per category (tank, dmg, cooldown, heal), so 16 items total.

The games are steamrolly at first, but seem to get better as you play more. Though I still see some players not buying items at all, which really hurts some matches.

Overall, would recommend! It's free. It's fun.

This Game has evolved so much over the years. In a positive way.
It has so many amazing champs at this point with really unique abilities.
The Card and the ingame perks system really make it stand out over overwatch.

Of course it can not compete with it completely graphicwise but even if the graphic does not look realistic af or 4k it has a unique charm to it and in no way looks bad.

The skins in this game also are fucking incredible. There is such a big amount of amazing skins to get for your champ its crazy. 

The developers in recent seasons have been very interactive with the community which means:
- (actually not broken) balance changes and several great updates
- twitch drops!!
- maps/map reworks
- slight champ reworks
- new skins
- battlepass (game is free so..)
- new free loot through a trials section every season
- new champs every season (looking at you Overwatch)
- A lot of timed modes which can be a lot of fun as they sometimes are absolutely ridicoulus ideas such as everybody plays the same champ with insanely short ultimate charges.

Of course there are also some negative points which mostly come from a ever slightly declining player base though:
- missing players (main problem) which leads to long que times for ranked (and overall missing practice in ranked) as most players play casual matchs. 
This leads to occasionally very unbalanced matchmaking as almost maxed out players with thousands of hours will play casual against total beginners as they dont want to wait that long to play ranked.
- Ranked could use more rewards although when you look at games such as apex it defenitely has more rewards 
- A new standard mode would be amazing but yeah its an overwatch game so I dont really expect more to come to it other than the existing modes which btw are:

Push the payload
TDM
Capture the point
Ranked Mode (Push the Payload with Champion Bans)
Shooting range
Tutorials for each mode
Custom matches
Limited time modes

All in all this game is a lot of fun and defenitely worth playing. This Game is of course similar to Overwatch but in no way is it a clone. It absolutely has a lot of advantages and some disadvantages.

Yes, I have 181 hours in this game. Yes, I enjoy this game. No, I definitely cannot recommend it as it remains one of the buggiest games in my Steam library. What is the point of leveling a Battle Pass and unlocking things if all of those unlocks force me to close the game after I get stuck on a "claim item" loop? Not to mention the constant disconnects, bounty store issues, etc. Honestly, there are far too many bugs to count, and in most games I would consider them unplayable, but I deal with them in this game for god knows what reason.

Absolutely fantastic game, the champion customization cards, the skins, the teamwork, the smoothness, the variety.  Different game every time.  Seige is the best game mode.  Sometimes there are aimbotters, which ruins the balance of the game, which is overall quite good.  Some champions seem OP sometimes, but there is a counter to everything.  Community is for the most part really fun and positive, every once in a while you get a grumpy baby but hey everyone gets grumpy sometimes.  The personalities of the champions and the voice packs are also loads of fun, including the standard ones.  I have laughed out loud many many times from the banter we get going with these.  I wasn't going to buy anything, but then I loved the game so much that I wanted to donate, and I figured hey might as well get a skin out of it too.  Currently saving up for more.

Despite the game being riddled with bugs (sometimes game-breaking), the customisation given through the Card, Talent and Item systems give the game a distinct edge gameplay-wise over other hero shooters like Overwatch. This great gameplay is pretty much the only reason to play this game, along with fact that it's free.

Along with my time on PC - I've played over 200 hours on Switch. From this time spent playing, the biggest problem I've come across is the excessive number of bugs (many of which have been around for years) and how unstable the game can be. The Switch version kept crashing every 20 minutes and the PC version also crashes occasionally which can make playing ranked risky. But only if you find a ranked match in the first place. Ranked matches often take 20+ minutes to find, ranked lobbies are very toxic and there are barely any rewards for playing ranked.
Characters are badly balanced and most of the new maps are badly designed. TDM is a broken mode where you often respawn right next to the player who killed you. The publishers are greedy (although the game isn't pay to win thankfully) and the developers are questionable.

To summarise, good gameplay but the rest of the game could be better. Because it's free, it's worth checking out for the gameplay alone.

The the game is fairly fun and very open to new players. Though it is plagued by some very annoying glitches and bugs that range from, an annoying noise being played at max volume endlessly, to not being able to fire your gun, or just straight up not allowing a team to win despite meeting the winning requirements.

Another glaring issue with the game, is the lack of skillbased matchmaking while in Ranked mode. The game does not put you up aganist opponents of a simular rank, nor does it fill your team with a same rank. More often than not, the game will put up 5 bronze players up aganist 5 platinum players. 

When these glitches happen they really put a damper on the mood, and if these glitches were to be patched out, I think this game would be able to grow a lot more.

P.s. I know this is a steam review, but please do not play this game on console. On every console I've tried it on, the game full on crashes every 5 games for no apparent reason.

For a free to play game, Paladins offers much to someone looking to pick up a free-to-play game and settle down with it. Offering a wide variety of different play styles to players with new champions coming out annually. But like most free-to-play titles, Paladins falls short with it's trauma inducing and grindy game play, with only 3 official modes and a little over 10 maps it can be hard to play Public matches and really enjoy the game. The grind filled game play of course has a way to progress faster with gems, also known as micro transactions. These can be used to buy skins, emotes, champions and more. Just gotta hand them your wallet. All in all Paladins is a fun game with friends and at it's core great if you can look past the micro transactions and the grinding.

honestly, in the short amount of time that i have played, i have found myself almost fully engrossed in the fast-paced team battle action, and often constantly screaming at my friends for help, which only makes the game more fun. there's an array of characters to choose from, and each one appealing to a different type of player. if you're comfortable with fps games, and used to tactical shooters, you might find yourself playing more Viktor. there's a lot to this game that makes it appealing, and i think that's what makes it so special.

+ Game is dynamic and addicting, each match is different its almost impossible to feel like you are fighting against and with the same players.
+ There is ton of champions all of them have "Talents" and "Cards" which hugely increases lots of playstyles suited for any one.
+ Not Pay2Win
+ Skins are high quality and changes their entire voice lines according to the theme of the skin( I haven't seen another game do this ).
+ it's very much possible to get tons of fr-ee ski-ns, you can grind crystals for the free track of 1 battle pass and the next you will be able to buy the battlepass and It will give you enough to get the next. Also there is a currency called bounty coins you can do daily quests to get gold and bounty coins which you can use to buy skins which go on a rotation every 2 days.
+ Tons of waifus to choose from.
+ Really easy to run, if you have a 7 year old or older PC your PC can run this. I have a 7 year old PC with a GTX 670 and run this with maximum graphics at a resolution scale of 120. Get consistent 120+fps.
+ You can really enjoy this game if you play casually, but before you do there is no shame in watching a paladins guide.

- sh-it servers, I play on consistent 47 ping which isn't bad, but sometimes it feels like its one 110. Champions that are projectile based get hit harder.
- sh-it tutorial, basically teaches you how to shoot and run.
- sh-it matchmaking pairs you up with people who barely know about the game against experienced players. This causes lots of frustration and sadness for new players and old.
- Takes a long time to unlock every champion.
- Toxic community, they sh-it on new players and old. Sometimes they do badly as well which is funny.

Even though you heard all these points I would highly advise to check the game for yourself. and START PLAYING WITH PLAYING THE MOST FAVORITE CHAMPION YOU THINK IS INTERESTING AND FUN THE MOST. Not only would this make your experience much better, but you would have tons of fun playing your favorite champion.

Its a decent enough game, if you can't be bothered to learn other games or you don't want to buy overwatch this is a alright choice. Its learning curve to play well is quite low although from what I could tell learning the meta game really boosts you up a notch so the customisation that can be done is sort of pointless and in the end goes for only a handful of great builds and when the majority uses the meta builds playing something wacky is kinda depressing. Last I played it some champions still needed to be balanced to be less noob friendly at least and others maybe a tap more into the Buff zone. There is still an active enough player base to find games relatively quick to load into even if the player base is dropping (If steam charts is to be trusted) there are still quite some years to play the game before death. The visuals are acceptable although don't have anything quite unique going for them and really does make it look like a free to play game although it will run on a potato to make up for it. In conclusion if you don't want something too hard to get into I could see this being a good choice, although id regret not saying give tf2 a proper try its a higher learning curve and bot issues but its well worth the learning.

I have played this game quite a bit in the past. It's simple enough. Paladins has lots of good characters to choose from and I had a lot of fun playing this game, but one day I just got so frustrated with this game that I never picked it up again. It wasn't just that one time either, everyone I knew was consistently having server problems. There were frequent bugs and glitches. Game breaking ones where I couldn't use any abilities and couldn't see my horse. Paladins is a game that has been out for a while now, but one that still acts as if it is in the beta stage.The queuing system in this game is broken as well. You don't queue for a certain role, so I've been on teams with five supports. The ranked system is annoying as well because your rank is determined by win or lose, so if you can't carry the other randoms to victory, you're going to be stuck. The most disappointing part is that none of this has ever been fixed. I say this because it makes me upset that a game I enjoyed had bugs so bad that one day I put the game down and never seriously played it again. Also, the furries...too many furries. Overall, do I recommend it? I really wish I could say yes, but I just feel as though there are better games to play instead, ahem* Overwatch. I'm serious I know this game is free and people argue they're just different, but as someone who was actually pulling for Paladins in the beginning, I can now tell you, just play Overwatch. This advice will save you a lot of time and pain, trust me.

Lord Garmadons son; Lloyd Garmadon releases the serpentine back into the world and the ninja have to try and defeat them too. The point is it's a amazing show with an amazing plot and I think you guys should watch it.

Ah, Paladins. They called you an Overwatch clone but you stood the test of time and are still going strong while OW is just an embarrassment. You've evolved into a unique experience unlike anything else on the market.

Despite what the number above might say I have been in the Realm since Closed Beta and have over 500+ hours in this game. 
TL:DR - its a very very fun shooter and you should definitely play it.

Long version since I have a lot to say:

Pros:
-very fast paced nuts to buts gameplay, tons of fun. Also as soon as the gates open, the action is non-stop until the round ends. There's basically no downtime.
-the Champions are all super cool, fun and interesting but simple and easy to pick up. They also vary a lot by playstyle and strategy, so you're bound to find someone you enjoy
-maps are quite well made, keep the flow of combat going nicely
-healthy playerbase, in EU i can consistently get a match in under a minute
-the Loadout+Talent system is fantastic, it lets you customize and min-max your Champion to fit you better and to optimize them in combat
-the lore they've built over the years is surprisingly good
-a lot of battle passes, quests, events and cosmetics to work on and collect if you care about that. In other words, there's always something to do

Cons:
-Bugs. Lots of Bugs. Luckily rarely so bad that it makes the game unplayable, but glitches and bugs are part and parcel of this game, always have been. The devs do a lot of work to fix them and bugs most of the time don't stick around too long, but new ones just keep popping up.
-Because of said bugs, some cool and useful features like the Death Cam and Play of the Game had to be removed since they caused so many bugs that they just had to be axed, since the underlying code itself was broken (the devs admitted this themselves)
-The average people you will get matched with tend to suck. Matchmaking is good, that's just how the playerbase always has been. It's a very teamwork reliant game, what do you expect? The community isn't toxic per se, but it's not the best and has its issues
-Some people can be toxic af, but what else is new? This applies to basically every multiplayer game like this
-Personal opinion, but the graphics could use improvement. The artstyle itself is fantastic but the textures, shadows and all the like look a bit dated. At least the ability effects look nice
-I miss old Torvald :(

Conclusion:

Paladins isn't the prettiest game and bugs can be frequent, but it's amazing gameplay is it's saving grace. I strongly recommend you give it a shot, if you like fast paced action, you will love this game. Just remember: pick Supp and Front Line when the team needs it, stay on the objective and buy Cauterize.

Ah, now this takes me back. When Paladins first came out, it was a bit before the battle royal craze had really kicked into full gear in popularity, and games like Team Fortress and Overwatch were all the rage. Then Paladins came out. We the players loved it; heck, there were OW and TF fans who enjoyed it too. But the drama that dominated the net for the next year or to was 'blah blah this is such a copy of OW!'. I eventually got bored of TF back in the day, and no doubt I would have gotten bored of OW had I played it long enough for the same reasons. Paladins instantly solved the issues I had with both games (TF and OW) and I never looked back since. Yeah the company Hi Rez have made a few oopsies here and there but they seem to always come full circle and listen to the good feedback (as opposed to other devs listening to someone just because their the most obnoxious/loud). 

Between the card system (good to see it back to normal), the talents, the revised battle modes and the ever increasing number of champions to choose from and you have a real winner on your hands that will most likely be around for years to come (here's to hoping). Both OW and TF grew incredibly stale for the very reasons Paladins has not and that innovation to keep the strategic layer of things interesting and influential on the tactical level is a game changer. 

The champions are very different to each other and how they work so I'm sure most of you will be able to find at least one that fits your play style. I was lucky enough to purchase the founders pack (no longer available) way back when so I can jump around a lot, but the same time if I had joined later post founder-pack I can tell you that the grind to unlock new champs is worth it. Just check out a few youtubes to find a champ that gels with you.

I wish I could give a positive review since I have spent way too much time playing this game. It's a shame because the gameplay mechanics and champions can be really fun and rewarding to play and you can change loadouts to fit your preferred playstyle. I love the variety of champions and their unique abilities.

But this game has way too many issues, each patch brings even more bugs, piling on top of thousands of old ones that have never been fixed. The servers are unstable and seem to get slower and more buggy all the time. Random crashes in the middle of the matches, login problems, players running around in t-pose, you name it. They basically have more people employed to create skins than actual developers trying to fix the damn game. Paladins has a lot of potential but all these issues sadly overtake the positive sides and make it very demotivating to play this game.

This was the first shooter game I picked up. It was really easy to pick up the controls and understand what the characters did without having to test them. The lore behind the characters is absolutely fantastic as well. I really enjoy Seris' and Vora's backstories. A lot of people love to talk about how the champions are "broken," meaning that certain abilities the characters have are overpowered and have an unfair advantage over the collective abilities of the other champions. I find this to be a little unfair for people to say, as almost all characters can be considered "broken" in one way or another, which I think makes everyone's abilities on par. I also think it adds another level of strategic game play and skill to take into account. Overall, I think the game and developers deserve a lot more credit than they get. They're developing an entire narrative, multiple backstories to explain each character's abilities, and new characters with skins and emotes on top of a battlepass. Well done.

If you say ANYTHING in-game other than "gg" after a match, like if you even say "hi" the moronic nerds will report you for "abusive chat" and, despite the fact that Blizzard has sidelined making maps worth a damn or more/better tank heroes in order to ban "toxic" players, their report system is completely automated and unmanned. So if a party wants to report you for abusive chat because you asked for a shield tank in chat, you're simply screwed.

The only real skill ladder in this game is understanding how ults and ult economy work. It's funny because there are tons of ults like Zarya's gravity pull or Junkrat's tire that can team kill effortlessly and is a great source of frustration for new players, because the game specifically encourages grouping up behind your tanks, only to punish you for it with these sorts of things.

Blizzard has been chasing the comp scene way too hard and for some reason is obsessed with making even the casual mode competitive even though there's no scoreboard in-game and everyone is more than happy to snitch on you like it's friggin Nazi Germany if you attempt coordination. So where's the competitive aspect? Quick play matches are a total mess, around 70% of matches are lopsided and over within 3 minutes because one team has grandmaster players and the other has people that installed an hour ago. 

What boggles my mind is how your average Overwatch player navigates life if anything and everything offends them. I've seen tumblrinas with thicker skin. Where did this term "toxic players" come from? I've never heard it outside of Overwatch and especially before its unveiling. It's literally mentioned every time someone brings up the game, as if mute buttons don't exist. You can even blacklist people from your queue if you don't like them. So you have mutes, reports, and blacklists. What more do you people want? An in-game moderator for every match? Grow the fuck up. After some investigation, I've found out like 80% of people that play Overwatch are basement dwelling NEETs who are wannabe e-sports streamers. You know what offends me personally? Losing a game because of bad teammates.

Just fix the little things. Like when players can skip a ban in ranked matches. Annoying. And 2 hour bans? yall need to be served up in a legal battle. I might be the one to do it. Go scre yourselves you wannabe developers.

This game is a fun competitive fps that has far too many cosmetics one must pay for, as well as the grind to unlock more champions is real.

It is a decent game, but I've become increasingly frustrated with it.
Some champs can seem broken at times, while other times they seem like punching bags for the other team (of course all depends on player and their loadout). It's hard to see what exactly happened other than the kill report with damage numbers. You're never sure of how they hit you or how fast they were hitting you, or if there was something weird going on.

Then there's the actual broken parts of the game that are noticeable by everyone. The backbone of the game: objectives.
There have been several games now where myself or multiple teammates are in the objective circle and it was not counting us. Especially on payload and we are trying to defend. Makes no sense for this to be broken after all this time.
Hit detection, still an issue. With snipers it can be seen easier than other champs.

Bots are still useless subs for when a player DCs. Half the time they just feed the enemy team without doing anything.
Then there are players that are still learning or play really really bad that make you question if they're bots or not. Wish hi-rez would actually label who is a bot so we know when a player had DCed, but that's just me.

The game has more going for it than Overwatch, but it is still not as polished after all this time.
I rate it a 7/10.
Recommend to, at the very least, try it since it is free to play. Like many team based games (any co-op game really), it preferable to have some friends to play with as randoms can be...difficult...to play with at times.

Comp experience (Tips and tricks)

Don't play comp if you rage alot .  I REPEAT DON'T.

5th/4th pick player will always pick against you so be prepared. They will make sure you lose so from the start count them with your opponents.

There are still Teammates who will pick for the team but those are very rare species. So just say thank you to them.

You might get matched with masters / grandmasters. And if you do get matched with them the match will be hopeless but don't give up trying.

Also if you want to avoid some these you can queue in an party.

Would recommend it 100% if you want more salt in your life.

In conclusion conclusion: MATCH MAKING SUCKS. The community is toxic, and that includes me being part of it.

Upon returning to Paladins after a long hiatus, I can say it has captivated me once more. 
It's not without its flaws but overall you can have a good time if you don't take it too seriously. (lpretty much like overwatch)

I do enjoy the whole "mastery" leveling system as it gives you the incentive to keep getting better with a certain champion and flaunt your level to others (even though it does not necessarily mean you're good at it). The cards and loadouts also add flavor to the game and can lead to different playstyles with the same champion.
The visuals and maps are really enjoyable with bright colors, although limited. The skins are original for the most part and really enhance the experience (though difficult to obtain). The champions vary from sexy to cute, to rough, to cool and I strongly recommend getting the champion's pack to try them all out. 

Personally, I feel like, in general, it's very DPS oriented and more often than not even playing as support feels more like damage, with no dedicated healing heroes. That creates the illusion for new players that they can play it as CoD, completely disregarding the whole class system and that's when it gets irritating. But you'll also have some really good matches when the whole team composition comes together with splendid results that make you love it again.

Another area that needs polishing is champion selection. If they're to copy overwatch they should at least copy the good aspects as well, that is being able to change champions midgame, and maybe even obliging players to play certain classes for better team composition (I can't stand another Viktor, Tyra, Strix insta-lock combination).

There are, unfortunately, many OP champions that feel out of place (pure dmg that no one can withstand) that make healers almost powerless. And when it comes to "ultis", I find it unfair for certain to get "insta kill" and overall powerful ultis while others rather useless ones (eg Io).  

Then there's the whole cosmetics issue. When I started playing couple of years ago, you could unlock cosmetics simply by leveling up and unlocking chests (like in overwatch), but now, to my disappointment, you need crystals (=basically real money), to unlock pretty much anything and as such simply leveling up has lost its meaning. I really hope they bring back the normal leveling up loot boxes.

Overall, I like it for unwinding and having a good time, and if you keep your calm and see it as a game and not a challenge you'll enjoy it as well. "See you in the realm!"

Paladins is a hero shooter, much in the likes of Overwatch, but with more pronounced MOBA elements. The cast of numerous characters is colorful and they all have their own personality, even though some of them come off as rushed or not very well thought out. The graphics are serviceable, which means they are not the best but not the worst either; they are colorful and get the job done.

What makes Paladins special is its unique Card system, which allows you to customize each and every hero with your personal play style. It’s rare that you’ll see two players using a certain hero the same way, and this makes the game less stale overtime than other similar offerings. Because of this, each and every game ends up playing differently, and this is exactly what I love about the game.

The in game economy is based on cosmetic only loot boxes, which means that despite being free to play and not counting individual skill, no player will ever be stronger than another.

The game receives updates, events and new heroes extremely frequently. Even though some bugs and glitches tend to stay longer than necessary at times, they rarely become game breaking or end up taking away from the enjoyment of the game.

Paladins is a free to play title that simply doesn’t feel like one, and this balance is very difficult to achieve nowadays. A well crafted card system, colorful heroes and good shooting mechanics make this game a joy to play, allowing it to stand out among the crowd of otherwise stale titles offered by much more renowned names in the industry.

However, there's this incredibly annoying bug where if the game fails to load a match and it forces you to close the game via task manager, the next time you boot up the game it'll try to load into that match that never really started (I've confirmed with some friends that when this happens it happens for all players in the match). This will continue to happen every time you log into the game until you reinstall.

ON TOP OF THAT after the game successfully fails to load into that match, YOU WONT BE ABLE TO CLICK ANYWHERE ON THE SCREEN/MENU.

Well, it's exceedingly buggy. The first time my group played this game, it crashed 4+ times. Everytime I boot the game, I get a message my 'bounty' has been refunded, including when I started the game the first time.

The game also sometimes have tooltips about gameplay? Those sometimes never go away, and stay on your screen until you restart the game. The battle pass asks you to pay to unlock items you have already gotten. A few times I alt tabbed to do something else, and the game window turned permanently black.

The UI is very poorly designed, and it's not intuitive at all. Took several hours for of playing for us to figure out what we could spend gold on. There's tons of buttons that don't really do anything, just pop up a tooltip. We're still not sure how you accept a party invite, so we've been partying through steam instead.

The first few matches you play (until level 5) are against bots. Nowhere does the game tell you this. The art style is kinda fuzzy and inconsistent, The music lacks any personality or distinction and generally just makes it hard to hear. when you select a champion they say their name like they're pokemon lol.

Many of the champions are not balanced at all. Maeve, Skye, and a few others are very difficult to kill, as almost all of them have healing abilities, can fly or use stealth, and can out damage your main dps as a flanker.

Many of the payload maps are HUGE. Like, it takes you a 15 second horse ride to get back into the match when you die huge. This also means practically all of them are extremely imbalanced, since dying means playing a man down for about 30 seconds. Even grouping, all it takes is one or two characters watching payload to completely lock down the other team after a bunch of deaths. It's annoying.

Many of the healers have such poor healing abilities, that DPS / frontline can genuinely outheal them with a minimum of effort. This happened 3/7 times we played.

But despite all of this, I like the game. for one, it's free. the actual game portion works, and is really fun and easy to learn. I just wish almost everything else wasn't broken

[h1]Step 1[/h1]
In a large mixing bowl, whisk together the flour and the eggs. Gradually add in the milk and water, stirring to combine. Add the salt and butter; beat until smooth.

[h1]Step 2[/h1]
Heat a lightly oiled griddle or frying pan over medium high heat. Pour or scoop the batter onto the griddle, using approximately 1/4 cup for each crepe. Tilt the pan with a circular motion so that the batter coats the surface evenly.

[h1]Step 3[/h1]
Cook the crepe for about 2 minutes, until the bottom is light brown. Loosen with a spatula, turn and cook the other side. Serve hot.

Sadly as a player which has played since the beta on ps4 and later moved on to pc to further play into it, i just can't recommend it. The bugs in this game are terrible, some of them are even game-breaking, for example the bug which jets off your complete team in ranked with no way to reconnect but still lose elo points. I first encountered this bug in 2018, then dropped the game for 2 years, came now back in 2020 and this bug still exists. Solely that point is enough proof for how little the devs care for this game. I played too much overwatch and hero-shooter in general to say Paladins is per sé bad, but i just cannot let this game go on how it goes right now. The balancing is [u] horrible [/u], some champions that were broken back in 2018 are still broken, like how do you get to this point? Everything in this game just feels unclean and unloved. There is no point in this game where you could say "Wow, the devs really put some thought to it". I think it's sad, could be a great contrary to Overwatch, but got destroyed by the devs themselves, just like every other Hi-Rez or Evilmojo Game. 
[b]TLDR:[/b] Great Potential, low effort

Having played the game on and off since OB43 and I have got to say that I love this game. It has so much potential to be one of the best competitive games on the market, but the reason that I leave a negative review is that this game has deteriorated both figuratively and literally over the years. From bad updates such as the infamous OB64 that killed the game's early momentum up the ranks and the neglect of implementing a proper fix to the servers as of recently. I have very fond memories of downloading and playing this with my friends. Even though I am the last one to leave this game for good, we all still mention this game and every time it comes up in topic we always say it sad to see this game die when thinking back to the old days.

This game is amazingggg. I got into this thinking that this was a cheap low quality game but it actually looks amazing and plays smoothly. Almost all champions are really well balanced and that’s hard to accomplish considering how many ways you can customize your settings and gameplay during and before matches. Paladins is really about customization. One champion can be played as a passive backline healer in one match and an amazing dps character with lots of crowd control in the next. It all depends on how you alter your champion’s “loadout”, and this makes the game so much fun and I never get bored. The pacing is perfect too~ the fights actually give you time to think and react and there are tons of outplay opportunities.

The game does need some polishing in terms of bugs and some maps aren’t that great, but overall it’s such an amazing game and I love it!

No team balancing what so ever from the player side ruins this game.
It often feels like i'm playing with people have never played a game their entire life (or i'm playing with team full of literal little kids) and will stand there and be filled with holes and not move even once before getting killed, run blindly into enemy fire multiple times and Other times people will pick a sniper character on a CTP map yet never once do anything other than snipe from a long distance just for the sake of racking up kills. Even when we're loosing the point. I've also seen people start a match then go AFK(?) in the corner and do absolutely nothing outside of spawn multiple times. 

I guess i expected this to be on par with smite where it was generally 50/50 chance of win or loose with fairly even balanced skill between people on both sides buts with Paladins your entire team is either being stomped or doing the stomping ALL THE TIME. There is rarely ever a time were the rounds aren't one sided as hell, i've played several matches where there were 0 kills from the enemy team and i just felt bad for them. 
Some kind of skill level/match making system needs to be put in place if there isn't one behind the scenes to combat this.

It's a nice game. Free to play, although buying champions without spending money takes A LOT of time. There are some bugs, glitches and problems in the game. But overall, the game itself is fun, laid back and a nice way to spend your time. Different fun gamemodes, cool champions and lovely designs. If you don't take the game too serious it's very fun. Sometimes broken hitboxes can be very tilting though.

The large cylinder hitboxes that often allow for body shots in empty space around champion models, the fact that the only ohko's are abilities that you press while looking near somebody (read: because of the terrible hitboxes), and the recent frequent server issues that make some games unbearably laggy turn this game into an absolute joke competitively relative most of the competitive titles in the FPS, MOBA and Hero Shooter genres.

This game is not perfect. i just want to address this now because no matter what anyone says this game is full of bugs, glitches, and questionable decisions from low rez. that being said if you can get past that you will find a fun rewarding game with a ton of fun characters and customizability.
let's go over the main reason I think this game stands out. the card system. when you start a match you can choose from 3 "legendary'' cards. each one drastically changes how the character is played, some even replace other abilities entirely. but it doesn't end there. after you pick that you can pick from 6 card sets that you make out of the game. These card sets can be built to help with cooldowns, tanking, healing, or many other things depending on the champion. and all of these are unique to each of the 46 (at the time of this review) different champions.
overall I believe that this is an amazing game despite its flaws and if you put some time into it i'm sure you will enjoy it.

Pros :
1. Large and unique roster of champions (drogoz is the coolest imo)
2. Has a loadout system where  you can tinker and make each champion unique with different ability card sets.
3. No p2w
4. Isn't required to be run on a high end pc.

Cons :
1. Server has many issues (lag and disconnects)
2. Some champions are unbalanced 
3. Buggy maps (clipping and you can get stuck in corners sometimes)
4. Champions takes too long to unlock unless you pay for the champion pack or have the premium battle pass where you get a lot of gold and gems.
5. Most female champions look lame imo lol
6. Potg and 3rd person is removed (stupid decision)

This is my favorite game, I play it everyday. There are many pros and cons to this game and I will get into them but I personally enjoy this game very much.

The cons, most players are extremely toxic: every match you will enter (casual or not) people will be harassing you, taunting you, or trying to get a rise out of you. There are bugs and glitches: in every update a new annoying bug or glitch will occur. 

The pros: The game has some super cool battle passes that always give me a reason to play and it will only cost $10 or less if you don't have enough crystals and you have to buy them. Leveling up characters isn't super easy and grinding or getting high leveled characters is rewarding. The game is pretty much unlimited, the matches last 30 mins give or take and you can play without limits.

I've played this game on and off for a few years now (on console) and every time I come back I remember why I fell in love with it to begin with. Personally my favorite system in this game that separates it from the titles it is compared to is the card system. The way you build each hero can change the way they play drastically. You can make the character fit your play style and make it specific to you. Experimenting with this and the talents you can choose before a match is always fun to try if you get too bored. You never know if you find something that makes a character you love even that much better. 

For being a free to play this game is also very considerate. Not predatory or pay to win which is great and it is fairly easy to unlock all 40 something characters without paying a dime. Personally I have spent a good amount of money on the game because I support Hi-Rez and this brilliant game they have created.

On the downside there are bugs here and there but I have never considered them game breaking or even that much of an annoyance on console or even PC. Give the game a fair try and just a heads up, your first few matches will be against very very boring bots that may turn you off from the game. Please try and push through to the real games to get a true sense of what Paladins is all about.

Have sunk over 700 hours into this game and I honestly can't say I recommend it. 

The game used to have a thriving community in which players would actually communicate in game and work together - I don't know what's happened in recent years but this no longer seems to happen.  

The worst thing by far is the matchmaking -  instead of grouping you with and against roughly equally skilled players it tries to balance matches by forcing complete beginner players into games with veterans and vice versa, using winrates or something to try and make the outcome of the match 50:50. In reality this simply means veteran players have to constantly put up with absolute beginners who won't even buy items, and beginners get absolutely crushed, or completely carried in some games by people who have been playing thousands of hours. It ends up, more often than not being frustrating for everyone. 

It's fairly common to play games in which people are blatantly aimbotting and wallhacking - the report system only allows you to report for "other" and then you still end up queued against them again weeks later and they're still hacking. 

Many of the characters are almost unseen in the game because they're outclassed by newer characters and need a rework. 

The loadout system offers some depth but needs another rework - there are cards that are almost worthless and nobody uses that need buffing. 

The game still has lots of bugs which have existed for years and will never be fixed. 

The clear priority for the developers is to sell microtransactions, rather than create a quality game. 

Wish I could get my 700 hours back.

This game is a broken mess, the champions are unbalanced, the servers lag terribly, they don't patch the game unless its to buff an already broken champ and nerf one that needs a buff. It seems HiRez is more focused on adding cosmetics and terrible battle pass systems that require real money than fixing their game that has so much potential to be good. Sadly I cannot recommend this game.

Paladins for people without the patience to read the whole thing: It’s a hero shooter with more MOBA elements without the complexity of Smite.
Paladins for people who read the whole thing: I struggled to choose whether or not this should receive the all powerful thumbs up. It’s a fun hero shooter that stays interesting after lots of playtime. Constant new characters keeps it fresh and the grind is pretty low (unless you want cosmetics, which I’ll get to later). The maps are bland visually, but the layouts are very well designed and keeps you on your toes. The hero abilities are OK, ranging from “this is great!” to “wayyyyyy to technical/situational”. A nice rotation of the characters allows you to test them against real people to see how you like them. A few weird bugs but overall pretty polished. My main concern gameplay-wise is the cosmetics. They’re incredibly difficult to unlock without spending real money and the amount of things to customize pressures you to buy them. If you’re one of those people who’s immune to this, then it’s great. My biggest non-gameplay problem is with what I think is the publisher. The constant licensing tie-ins are cringy at best and feel detached from the theme. EDIT 3: In my 2nd edit I noted the push of LGBTQ content and how offensive it was. After replaying the game a bit, I can say that they’ve toned it down quite a bit. It’s still there, but not so forced. If you can put up with numerous micro transactions then I think you’ll enjoy this.

This game is very fun to play and easy to pick up. The characters do take some time to unlock but it isn't that long and through the weekly cycle of free champions it is very easy to find out what every champion can do. Also if needed you can choose any champion the practice range. The best thing about this game is the control you have over your champion. Outside of matchmaking you make a character specific loadout that will enhance the abilities and play style that suit you. Each character has 16 cards which you can choose from. You divide 15 points in 5 different cards. That makes almost all loadout's unique. There are also legendary cards. Each character has 3. These cards can totally change your play style to more mobile, more sustain, more healing, it is different for each character. Loadout, legendary card and champion are chosen in the beginning of a game and can't bechanged. However if you're in a match you can also buy items. This store is easy to understand and doesn't need a lot of game knowledge to use good. There are 16 items you can buy and level up. These can be dmg reduction, lifesteal, extra dmg against shield, etc. Overall this game is fantastic and i would really recommend it,

This game is mostly described by comparing it to overwatch, so first of all. This game shares similarities to Overwatch, and is criticised for it. Yet every game on the planet is based off another game, and shares similarities, take Fortnite/H1Z1 etc and those types of games are literally just another version of minecraft yet aren't criticised for it, overwatch was literally based around TF2 and copied ideas from it. But when Hi-Rez takes ideas and gets inspiration its somehow copying. So stop with this silly logic.~

Anyway, Paladins is a good game. It's sad to see this game is dying quite quickly, the main reasons being:
1. Bugs - Bugs seem to be in the game way longer than they should be and aren't the developers priorities which they indeed should be.

2. Matchmaking is very random especially in casual mods, you could be going against Diamonds/Masters/grandmasters even though you aren't even ranked. This unfair matchmaking is something that needs to be looked at.

3. Lag - There's definitely a lot of issues with lag in this game, while not everyone experiences it. For some it's quite common, for some reason I'm pretty sure Ranked has Peer to peer connection making it so you're connected to the host, which is an outdated method of online matchmaking as it's awful and doesn't work especially if the host has a bad connection, you're in for a rough game.

4. Lack of maps, this game has been out for over 4 years yet only has a select few maps to even play which makes the overall experience sometimes very repetitive to play.

5. Lack of game modes - Again the game has been out for over 4 years yet shares the same problem with overwatch, the lack of game modes like the maps can make the experience again pretty repetitive to play.

I could easily think of more issues this game has, and the most biggest of all is Hi-Rez themselves. I don't think they really care about the state of this game anymore, and are just milking it for what's left before the game just dies. Which is actually sad because this game actually has potential:

It's awesome to play with your friends, you had a large amount of skins/emotes etc to keep you entertained or make your champion look badass, large amount of champions to choose from, you can make custom card builds to develop the playstyle of the champion you want to your own needs which is something other games don't do so I'd like to give Hi-rez props on that. Overall this game is actually so fun to play, and has so many little  tricks and things for you to find out like for example shooting on the floor with Evie the attack has knockback so you can actually use this as bonus movement at the end of say a Soar with Evie. little things like that you can learn, and develop your knowledge off.

I've honestly no clue what else to type here. but again this game is very fun but has a lot of issues, but yet again does have potential while the game is still alive... sorta.

Yes I do recommend this game because I believe the game itself and the mechanics are awesome and very fun. I do however feel like the developers need to make this game grow to become more successfull because right now if you want to play it seriously it's rediculous.

Here is why:
There is hitboxes and buggs everywhere. It's getting less but many buggs have been around for years and right now it starts to feel like the developers are lazy enough to just call it 'part of the game'.
The ranked system is the worst I've seen in any game ever. In any game where you play ranked you will get matched with people of around the same skill lvl. That's not the case here. I don't want to sound like I think that I am much better than the players I play with but the ranked system doesn't work and here is why. New players will get matched with anyone, even has high plat/low diamond players (top 5%) you will often get matched with total new players who have no clue of what's happening. This results in an instant lose. I get often matched with grandmasters/pro's who can either stomp you (not fun) or lose while trying all they can because their teammates are entirely new to the game aswell. If I'd play call of duty, rocket league or league of legends I'd never get matched with a player more than 1 league above/below mine. In this game it's normal which makes it impossible to trust your teammates and takes away from the teamplay. A well matched game is rare.
Way to much focus on skins. While all these problems have pointed out many times it doesn't seem like the developers will do anything about it. It's just there and we just release overpriced skins for a game of which the gameplay just doesn't work yet.
Teamplay in ranked. There is no way to teamup with more than 1 friend above diamond. Splitting all friends up. This has in my friend circles caused 75% of my friends to once they hit diamond to stop playing. Teamplay is THE most populair thing right now, this is a teamgame and Paladins punishes it by breaking teams up.

The focus is on making money and not on creating a good game. Which is a shame because this game has huge potential.

What i love about Paladins:
> The deck building & talent systems. You can pick 5 out of 16 + 1 out of 3 talents which can modify the abilities and stats of your champion. These systems means that a champion can have several playstyles, which makes it really fun to experiment with one champion and doesn't bore you even if you play / fight against one champion for several matches.
> When you die, you only have to wait several seconds to respawn. I know this feature is not unique to Paladins, but i dont like FPS games that makes you wait until next round when you die and the only thing you can do till then is just watching your teammate's pov.
> No Pay-to-Win mechanic even though the game is free.
> The devs are still active and updating the game.

Not the fanciest or most high budget class-based shooter but a lot of fun to play, very hard to put down. Biggest problem is the low graphical fidelity, needs a config mod to really take advantage of a decent GPU, good skins aren't as accessible as Apex for example.

But generally character roles work very well together, but also every character has great offensive abilities so every match is super fun and hectic.

A very enjoyable game with lots of playable characters which can be further customized with loadouts. Compared to Overwatch, this game is decided more by good teamplay and positioning rather than raw skill. No ingame character switching means there are far less (if any) hard counters to worry about and most unfavourable matchups can be balanced out via the ingame item store and adjusting your strategy.

You start out with 6 champions unlocked by default and more can be purchased with gold (which is earned ingame by playing matches and doing daily quests) so if you like continuously unlocking and learning new champions, this is an optimal way to play the game. There is also a free rotation of 4 champions that changes every week so you can try out new characters without having to buy them. The shooting range also lets you try out every champion without owning them so you can get a feel for their kit and see if you would like them, before you spend any gold.

While the devs try hard to fix bugs, unfortunately they also remove old and beloved features because they can't seem to fix them. Top Play (which is basically Overwatch's Play of the Game) as well as the third person mode have been removed in favour of reducing the amount of bugs. A lot of unique and fun character voice lines have been removed to make the voice guidance system easier for new players, instead of making it an option you can toggle between (You can toggle the VGS between new and old style but that won't bring back the removed voice lines). As someone who bases skin purchases mostly on the included voice packs, this just means that the value of skins dropped for me. The game is built on spaghetti code and at some point you will experience it. It has gotten a lot better, I just wish existing game features wouldn't have to suffer for it.

I like this game. People call it an overwatch clone, but that's mostly on a surface level. Any custom to casual class based shooter will look similar to another, like how people call Overwatch a TF2 clone. But there's always stuff that sets a game apart. For TF2 and overwatch, it was that overwatch had a larger cast, and a more serious feel. TF2 has a smaller cast and a more goofy feel. TF2 has fewer classes, but a large variety of customization for those classes. Paladins has It's card system setting it apart. This way, similarly to TF2, no two heroes will be exactly the same. It has it's ups and downs, but overall, an excellent game, and does not deserve to be called an Overwatch clone any more than Overwatch deserves to be called a TF2 clone.

First a quick list of pro's and cons for anyone that doesn't like reading too much (certain aspects are explained in detail after the list):

Pro's:
Lots of skins
Lots of customization (titles, avatars, announcers, music etc)
Customizable gameplay (talents + loadouts)
Battle passes (since they contain lots of skins, offer fun (or sometimes frustrating) challenges and are free if you complete it (after purchase))

Cons:
Skins are often too expensive to get
Crystals (most valuable currency) is near-impossible to get
Customizable gameplay (more on why in both lists later)
Battle passes since they force you to play the game alot.

Amazing game that has alot of content and customization.
I have been playing this game since the open Beta's and have loved it ever since i started.
The game itself is really well made and the graphics look amazing too. There are tons of skins which make it even more fun to try and collect them all, the only sad part is that they are incredibly expensive since crystals are near-impossible to gain and the skins cost about 400 crystals each (epic, not rares).
The most fun part in my opinion is that you can customize your gameplay with the loadouts system, it allows the player to choose 5 out of 20 cards for a champion then you can set them all at a level of your choice (as long as it doesnt exceed the max points you can set), this combined with different talents for each champion makes it so you can choose how to play as certain champions and i really love that.
Again the bad part about that is that certain people can just choose to play damage as a healer and ruin the team, but that isn't the game's fault, it's that player's fault.
The community doesn't feel toxic to me or anything, it's just that there are some selfish or trolling people like in every other game, that is why the loadouts and talents system is both positive and negative.
Now, the populair thing games like to have all the time, the battle pass.
I personally think that battle passes in this game are among the most fair ones, you buy it (the newer ones are around 600 crystals) and if you complete the whole pass, you get 600 crystals back, meaning if you had 600 crystals you can buy every battle pass without having to spend any money, unlike most games where it costs real money to begin with.
Now i love having an objective in games, thats why i love this battle pass system. It gives you lots of challenges and even gives title(s) for completing half of them and title(s) for completing all of them.
I would like it if it would be in waves like it used to be, get to a certain level to unlock newer and harder quests instead of all at once, but i can understand why unlocking them all at once for anyone to complete would be nice to some.

Last words for the review would be these: I find the game really fun and so is customizing and trying new loadouts and skins, just wish that getting crystals would be a little easier.

If there are any mistakes in here I apologize since I don't have English as my native language.
Also yes I remembered that the I's need to be capitalized, sorry.

Hope this review helped in some way.

OK. So here's my review.

Are there bugs? PLENTY
Are they gonna fix the bugs? NO
Is the game still fun to play? Yes
Should you try it? DEFINITELY

this game is NOT an Overwatch clone. It's easy to see that from the outside looking in, but once you play your first game, the differences between the two are like night and day. The advantage Paladins has over a game like Overwatch is the fact that each Champion can have a multitude of different playstyles. With Overwatch, each hero has one single playstyle, and that's it.

Obviously a AAA title like Overwatch is going to be a lot more polished with next to no bugs, good graphics, and reliable servers. Paladins is on the other side of the coin when it comes to this. With quite a few bugs, above average graphics, and pretty bad servers. But what Paladins suffers in company backing, it excels in gameplay. The uniqueness of Paladins is the sole reason why I have played since mid-late 2018. Ask any Paladins player with over 500 hours in, how they feel about the game and what will they say? Something along the lines of; The servers are frustrating or the meta is sometimes dumb, but the game is just pure fun.

The game might make me wanna kill myself at some points, and sometimes there are some rat players, but this game isn't one that I can just put down.

Do I Recommend it? YES!

This game is the thinking mans Overwatch.... If Overwatch was CSGO, then Paladins would be R6 Siege..... The gameplay is a bit slower but still explosive.... its more about setup then pure aim / mechanical skill. My best advice to new players, watch some youtube videos / live streamers and ask a few questions.... It takes time to learn all of the characters. There are characters for every play style.... your typical Tank / Healer / DPS focus and many hybrids inbetween. But what makes this game standout is the customizations of the abilities. UNLIKe in overwatch, you can pick certain areas to Buff or outright change to support your team or play style. I have many builds that will have a dmg focus, or healing focus or mobility focus etc.... Thats the part where this game stands out, is the adaptability. All of this for free is a sweet deal ! Also you can eventually earn all of the characters... my advice, if you really enjoy the game after a while, just buy the champions pack to get all of the characters. 

Lets talk about the one major problem i have with this game.... and weirdly it has almost nothing to do with the game but its playerbase.... most of the people that play in casual are bad. No easy way to sugar coat it, if you want to play the game, you will either have to carry in solos OR find people to play with.... The good news, its easy to find people to play with as long as you make the effort. Then other stupid little things like the friends list being weird or audio bugs on rare occasions.

Overall, my reccomendation is simple.... Its free and worth a try, worst case you dont like it and only waste an hour or so of your time.  If you are looking for people to play with that dont suck, feel free to msg me about it. Thanks !

The game is pretty good as it shows different ways to play with each character on the roster with their own lore and abilities that compliments the champion you play as. You're able to make a load out to fit your own style for each character adding more ammo, health, or just a boost on abilities. Not to mention 3 skills each character has that you can choose from. You are given 4 characters each one from Frontline, Support, Damage, and Flank. Develop your skills to earn gold to buy more champions and see how combat differs from each champion you buy. If your not so confident on your skills don't worry since Paladins also offers matches with bots and a training room where not only can you practice your load outs but you can also practice with champions you don't own yet to see if they fit your play style and earn gold to get the one you like the most. You might think of it as free Overwatch, but it's not quite right. This game has its own unique mechanics which separate it from OW. It's actual cost is measured in time you'd put in grinding champions, or in amount of money you're willing to spend because almost every champion isn't free, but the entire bundle of every present and future champion is quite cheap.

Why would you like to buy this game:

You can play almost any character in a number of ways, thanks to the cards, talents, and market in match
Game is easy to learn and hard to master
Even similar champions are quite different in match
Strangely, almost no cheaters on EU servers

Why wouldn't you like to buy this game:

If you can make yourself builds, there will always be a problem of annoying easy to use builds
Existence of Vivian
Kinda toxic community (at least on gold/plat)
If you don't want to pay, you'd have to grind each character for ages
Bugs, not a lot, but sure annoying

That's pretty much it

It's fun, kinda like FPS version of Dota but different.
