I can feel my hands shaking whenever I start a new round. It's ok to go without in-game purchases, but it's gotta take significant time to stock up enough crystals for new champions, so don't even think about chests unless you are rich boi.
Also there are bound to be toxic players, just remember to stay cool. In a battle on the last day of 2019, my team was pinned down and scattered, enemy were strong and swift their flank was totally on me(Support [Seris]), busted me in seconds each time we meet. Obviously we had no chance of winning. Then our tank who charged blindly into deathtrap started blaming flank meanly. The flank seemed fairly new, saying "It's 2020!!!" feels like he was excited by the coming of a new year and was in a good mood. Losing a battle wouldn't ruin the mood but having a toxic player definitely would. They repeated similar conversation few times then we were done. Ended up reporting each others. Bruh

First off the game is really fun. I like the style of the game. But the amount of bugs in this game is ridiculous. I've played this game for a long time now and some bugs that have been in the game for years are still there and instead of fixing them they push out more paid content like a battle pass. Even their 'fixes' are terrible. Paladins used to have a feature with replays and showing the best play of the match which surprise surprise was buggy as fuck. Their solution to this was to just give up on it and remove it, even tho getting best play or seeing it was one of the best parts of a match. I've been trying to play this game more recently but every game without fail I come across a bug. For a game that was in beta for years and claims they're in full release it needs major improvement.

I hear a lot of people hate on this game, and I don't get it. I'll explain why.

This game gets compared to overwatch, understandable,  but I think this game has enough differences to have a different target audience, and I feel like I'm that target audience, The thing with this game is there isn't going to be a situation where you like one character and its the only one that really fits how you like to play, this happens to me in overwatch and seige, but not here. In this game you can customize the champions to fit a desired role, so I don't mind playing a healer for instance, because I can play a healer that I gave high damaging and slightly tanky stats so I can heal my team a little less efficiently, but bully the other team at the same time. I can choose a all damage character, but give them movement speed so they can fill a more flank style role, I can play a tank and make them deal a little more damage, I can make the characters fit my playstyle rather than having to get a character that is my playstyle. This to me makes the game so much more fun and dynamic, and i no longer get mad when someone chooses my main character. Super fun, can't wait to try out ranked.

I've put countless hours into this game on the PS4, recently started to shift towards gaming on PC and wasn't sure how I would find it using a mouse and keyboard (Yes, I know you can plug in controllers these days but I wanted to give it a try). So far i'm loving it, movement is taking a bit of getting used to, but aiming and firing is much easier to be accurate.
Now onto the game, Paladins is one of those games which is fairly easy to pick up and very hard to put down, no, it's not perfect, matchmaking can sometimes be a little whack, but if you're looking for something fun that you don't have to concentrate on too much, give this a go. I do recommend paying the £12 ingame cost to unlock all current and future characters as it gives your gameplay possibilites for more options when you're last pick on your team and need to balance out the character types (Support, damage, flank, Frontline). 
When you start playing, you will find that there are a lot of people who don't understand the different character roles and strengths (They just pick someone they think looks cool and run round the map like a headless chicken trying to run up face to face with enemy frontlines and go toe to toe using a squishy little flank character etc) or the need for balanced Team make-up. You will have games where the enemy just rolls right over you because of players like this, but persist and get to level 15 and you can unlock ranked games and you'll find that the majority of ranked players have a much better understanding of this game and you will have far more close fought, enjoyable games.

Idk even how to rate it, but my 432 hours are gonna give it a thumbs up. Just play it.

Game terbaik pada masanya. mampu memberikan kebahagiaan semu kepada gamer ekonomi lemah yang tidak bisa mencoba overwatch. If you prefer a healing role, this isn't the game for you.
Being a healer in this game is terrible, even when they nerfed Cauterize several times (biggest nerf so far is 30%/60%/90% reduced healing to 25%/50%/75% reduce healing,) which still cripples healers to double digit healing numbers trying to beat 4 digit damage numbers. Everyone rushes Cauterize first, it even stacked with team mates (at the time I quit). Your team mates have dozens of ways to heal that's way better than what you can provide. You're better off going completely offensive or just going anything else. Not to mention there still a lot of bugs with healers even after my two year break from the game.
I've tried as a healer in ranked and ended up in plat I (borderlined diamond V) before I quit. The game had a lot of balance issues and other things I was hoping they'd ironed out, but never really did. I had way more fun playing any other role than healer, aside from completely offensive Jenos who has respectable headshot damage for a healer.
It just sucks not being able to do anything, all you're really doing is trying to kill the enemy before trying to heal team mates which should sounds good on paper because you're part of the action, but in this situation, just makes healer kind of pointless when your team mates could just invest into Kill To Heal and gain just as much health compared to your healing.

Paladins
Generally a fun game, while it can take a long time to unlock all the heroes (I simply paid the 15 dollars to unlock them all instantly, which is a steal) this doesn't take away from the fact that it's a good, free alternative to some team based shooters out there that might be a tad bit more expensive. Easy to pick up, games will only last anywhere from 5-10 minutes. Best part is, it's completely free. There is no "Pay 2 Win" aspects, most, if not all champions are balanced in their own ways, and can all counter one another in some way. The only micro-transactions that exist are when it comes to buying crystals which are used to buy skins, which don't affect gameplay at all. With 25 hours ingame currently, I can confidently say that I am enjoying Paladins.

PROS:

-Very fun game especially with friends
-Most skins and legendary skins are actually grindable, Not even that hard to grind
-Developers always listening to their community
-Wide range of champions to play
-Only 2-3 hackers encountered so far after 1k+ hours of playing
-Progressive enhancements to the game
-Welcoming community (sometimes)
-It doesn't need a high end pc
-Nice graphics
-It's free!


CONS:


-Champion abilities and roles can put the enemies or you at a huge advantage in 1v1's
-Some champions actually require no aim and deal damage which kinda goes against the idea of an fps shooter
-Sometimes the match making gets fucked up
-The game has tons of bugs and unstable matches (the bugs got reduced a lot as new patches come in)
-Toxic community at higher levels
-Hitboxes are the same for all champions, However sometimes they act really weird in registering 


Overall a very nice game and I recommend it to anyone who enjoys FPS games, It might not be that much of tactical game like CSGO or R6S. It leans more to the get in and kick ass style, But it is very enjoyable especially with friends where you can do ult combos and stuff together.
every patch has a different line up of problems, so if you don't like it now, wait a month or 2. at least it's fun like less than TF2, but better than Overwatch.

Haven't come across a game-changing bug in many months, which used to be a real drawback. There are still some pesky graphical ones, especially on the home page, but other than that the game is in really good shape. Currently well balanced, with interesting and fun characters on some dynamic maps. The mechanics of the game has always been its best aspect for me. People will complain about comeback mechanic but it's balanced by credits gained for capturing objectives. By far the best mechanic though is all the in-game customization. Each champion can choose one of 3 legendary talents that provide a large buff to one of their basekit abilities, as well as a set of 5 cards with 15 cumulative levels that give smaller buffs to other parts of their kit (base or ability proc-based cooldown reduction, health increase, reload decrease, increased healing below certain health, etc). Additionally, credits earned in-game for objective time, kills, damage and healing allow one to buy items at spawn, which give specific utility for enemy obstacles. Enemy team has a lot of direct damage (snipers, blaster dps)? Each level of Haven is 7% dmg decrease. Enemy team has a lot of shields? Wrecker increases weapon dmg on shields by 20%. It's infinitely customizable and many playstyles for each champion are viable. On paper it's much better than OW, and in practice it's at least on par, especially considering it's a free game. Highly recommend!

Though it may say I have 60 hrs on steam, I have 1500+ hrs on the Switch, and I have quite a few things to say.

To start off, this game is NOT an Overwatch clone. It's easy to see that from the outside looking in, but once you play your first game, the differences between the two are like night and day. The advantage Paladins has over a game like Overwatch is the fact that each Champion can have a multitude of different playstyles. With Overwatch, each hero has one single playstyle, and that's it. 

Obviously a AAA title like Overwatch is going to be a lot more polished with next to no bugs, good graphics, and reliable servers. Paladins is on the other side of the coin when it comes to this. With quite a few bugs, above average graphics, and pretty bad servers. But what Paladins suffers in company backing, it excels in gameplay. The uniqueness of Paladins is the sole reason why I have played since mid-late 2018. Ask any Paladins player with over 500 hours in paladins how the feel about the game and what will they say? Something among the lines of; The servers are frustrating or the meta is sometimes dumb, but the game is just fun. 

The game might make me wanna kill myself at some points, and sometimes there are some rat players, but this game isn't one that I can just put down.

Pretty good game. I'm still a total beginner, but came from Overwatch so there's a few of the characters function similarly to Overwatch heroes - some almost exactly, some similar, some a mix of multiple characters in one. 

It is easy to pick up, with 20 hours play I'm already reasonably competent with 4 characters. Viktor (functions almost identical to Soldier 76), Seris (similar to Moira), Androxus (McCree meets Doomfist, looks like Reaper) and Tyra (female Soldier 76 mixed with Zen)

The big advantage of this game is that it's free, and it would run on a baked potato. Running at 1080p ultra @ 175fps, my GPU sits at around 35% usage. 

You would run this easily on integrated graphics, but it still has a nice charming look to it. 

And it is fun, loads of heroes to chose from, nice mix of game modes, decent maps that are really simple, colorful, and easy to learn. 

It's not as good or as polished as Overwatch, but it's fairly solid entertainment and different enough that it's not really  a case of playing one or the other.

Is Team Fortress too old for you? Is Overwatch too expensive or you just don't feel like using another launcher? Well congratulations you found a free knock off that does the same thing as every other routine FPS team game.

You can debate over which game borrowed ideas from which, and it shares some passing resemblance with Global Agenda, just reskinned with less sci-fi elements and that wasn't a bad game either,

There's nothing terribly wrong with the game, but in the end they all just kind of blend together. If this had a price tag i might thumb it down, but it's free and if you are into this sort of thing it's probably at least worth looking at to see if you want this option.

I ignored Paladins since it was known as the poor man's Overwatch, but after trying it for the first time in 2020 I am legit impressed and shocked that it's not like Overwatch at all. In a lot of ways, it's better.

Time of death is longer so it gives you more time to react and counterplay, ultimates feel more impactful and the ability to customize your skills to fit certain playstyles or team comps adds a welcome layer of depth. 

It's less FPS skill heavy and emphasizes more on positioning and ability use from MOBA gameplay.

Have you ever wanted to play a MOBA/FPS and also pop a huge boner? Then this is the game for you. What are you in to? Boobs? This game has you covered. Butts? Definitely. You a furry? Yea that too. Do you like dragons? yea we've got those. Are you in to girls made out of rock? Well guess what this game has.

A somewhat shallow but enjoyable class-based shooter with light-tectics goal-focused modes that seems to suffer a bit from a balance/pacing issue as matches snowball hard either way - however, with the rare saving grace in 2020 gaming where the more unbalanced a match is, the faster it ends. The fastest queue times of any online game I've seen so far also ensure that a badly-paired match is going to be a minor bump only.

To testify that this is not an "everyone gets a participation prize" proposal but a no-skill-ceiling experience, I myself (a veteran but rusty FPS player) have, in 2 hours of playtime, gotten no less than 4 Achievements that only half or a third of the playerbase have unlocked. I'm interested to see if the ranked mode adds more depth to the matches, given more appropriate skill-based matchmaking. At current rate I'd assume it'll take 6 hours total to unlock it.

Monetization seems to be built around only cosmetics and unlocking heroes - the latter being doable with in-game currency too or by a reasonable one-time payment of a fraction of an AAA game title's price to own all present and future champions. In these 2 hours I seem to have gained enough gold to unlock between 1-4 of the heroes, depending on their prices. Assuming hero prices have no bearing on power, it's safe to say this isn't pay-to-win.

Playing Paladins, I couldn't help but mourn how far from the best entries of the genre from back in the 90s (and their later descendants) we've fallen, in favor of dumbed-down, handholding, mass-appealing titles that pale in comparison in any and all types of online competition. If like me, however, you've seen your old favorites' servers die down with every year, Paladins is more than capable of offering an alternative that is a free, fast, skill-based, minimally-strategic FPS with a healthy community around it. 

Fans of MOBAs who are tired of enforced metas, pandering to the lowest-common-denominators of skill segments, draconic or senseless game design, infuriating matchmaking and inadequate community moderation may also find the class-based approach here an interesting proposal, as a different but similar type of mostly-action, minimally-brainy pastime.

I personally would give the game a 9.6/10, it's free to play, play to win and is really enjoyable to kill time,

“Paladins” is a free cooperative FPS developed and published by the well-known Hi-Rez Games. "Paladins" drew attention for its similarity to the bombastic and celebrated "Overwatch", however the game still manages to have an independence and bring different qualities.

A very interesting initial information that should be stressed is that “Paladins” is entirely in Portuguese, making it a great facility and attractive for the Brazilian public.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2236024259

Like most MMOs and MOBAs, “Paladins” offers reward scores, skills and coins to people who enter the game every day.

Five servers are also available to choose from: North America, Europe, Australia, Asia and Brazil. Being another great attraction for the national audience that is interested in playing and easily finding other Brazilian players.

The game features four options for modes to play. The casual, which is a four against four battle of domination and taking the cart to a certain point, the competitive one, which is blocked, which is to conquer and do certain challenges, the training to improve and perfect your techniques and the personalized where you can choose the number of players and the style of play.

“Paladins”, like all MOBA, presents characters with functions for the player to choose which one suits him best. We have several champions, in this case the characters that are playable, divided between different functions. Each character has their specific abilities according to their function, which will be better explained later.

Support: One of the classic functions of the entire MOBA. Its total mission is to support the team, increasing the amount of life and improving the quality of skills. They are fast characters, who must stay away from the center of attacks, even though they have some ranged attack skills. His main skills are healing and restoration, as well as being able to hinder, or even attack, enemies.

Tank: The strongest and toughest character in the game. Your main mission is to go ahead to the attack zone and try to eliminate as many enemies as possible. His life is very long, managing to take a lot of damage. They are slow and stocky characters, and can attack, most of the time, close to the enemy. Good parts of the characters can also create a shield for defense, both from him and from some point that must be protected. His main skills are attacking, having a defense.

Damage: Your main mission on the battlefield is to eliminate enemies. Their skills are focused exclusively on attacks and skills that help to create and improve the attack strategy. Your defensive ability, if you can say so, is an aid to escape some intense battle, until you regain your life. They are not the strongest characters, but can handle a battle. Their speed varies a lot depending on the chosen champion, but they are agile in general. It is possible to use stealth skills to surprise opponents.

Flank: They are fast characters, who must attack from the flanks, as the class name already says, without being much noticed. Your skills have a lot of focus on teleporting, increasing speed, reaching higher places with faster and faster and more direct attacks. They are extremely fast and stealthy. It is an important class to help attack or defend without being noticed, dying very little.

A good number of roles, often occurring a certain imbalance between them, especially when certain champions are chosen.

Each champion had five skills, for defense, attack and special, being molded from the class belonging to the champion.

The skills that the game offers are very pleasant and diverse. Characters with the same functions on the battlefield have completely different abilities, thus being able to make the player closer, attached and satisfied to the player with a specific champion. This distinction between skills also makes the battle system less monotonous.

The game provides a system to create an arsenal of improvements to your card-based skills. The player can choose five cards to be the basis for improving the champion's skills, which can be improved even more during a match. It is an interesting system, which allows the player to create a better strategy for his game, however the cards are still of little choice, perhaps there is still a little more constructive creativity to create more specific cards that give the player more excitement. -over there.

Until then, the most popular mode of the game is casual, matches between teams of four against four.

Each player must choose a champion, who will stay with him until the end of the game, unlike other FPS Online where you can change characters at any time. It's a somewhat arr ideabaited and that holds the player very much to his initial choice, mainly the beginners who are still learning about the champions, however the way to improve their skills during a match, leaves less submissive.

The team is given two goals. The first is to achieve a certain point, staying in the place as long as possible, before the other team. The other is to be able to take, or not let the other team take, a cart to another point.

These two simple goals cause a good tension between the teams, if they manage to organize themselves well and choose the right characters. Simplicity is a correct choice, as the matches are direct, fast and very objective, without having to do a lot of crazy things or dilemmas, and a simple organization is enough.

One cannot help comparing “Paladins” with “Overwatch”, even though both have their specific qualities and defects. One of the big differences between the two is the construction of the maps by the developers. While the Blizzard shooter risks a lot on the maps, with big differences between them and points to make its strategies, the Hi-Rez shooter has its weakest point on the maps, having a very similar construction always, looking like it is always playing the same .

This problem with the maps in “Paladins” makes the game extremely monotonous after playing for a while. There comes a time when the player can no longer bear all the resemblance, looking like he is always playing the same thing in every new game.

In this case, due to the question that they want to bring simple and easy-to-understand objectives for the players, in a correct way, the maps should be the opposite, with different environments, points for hidden player or going into direct battle, and not just a repetition of ideas. One of the worst, if not the worst, "Paladins" point - which can be corrected over time.

The graphics are quite acceptable. They focus a lot on the idea of ​​less is more, without great details and realism, but with plenty of colors and nothing that makes players uncomfortable or complaining about visual defects.

The environments, although always similar, are very beautiful too, leaving a very hostile and pleasant battlefield.

The interface of a MOBA FPS is difficult to do, because any detail that is exaggerated.
Kinda like an Overwatch, but more fun, free to play, and easier to learn. The characters are much easier to learn and use as well

If you reopen the game too soon, it'll throw you right back into that bad match.

The game is buggy as heck and it's prone to freezing and crashing, despite being played on decent gaming hardware. i7, GTX 1050, 16GB RAM.

[h1]Paladins a fun game to play with a few friends. BUT. Still to this date a buggy, laggy, unfinished mess. Its impossible to play this game seriously and even when just playing "casualy" its frustrating and messy.[/h1]

[b]Hitboxes, headshots, and aiming feels slugish and is extremely inconsistant. Latency seems to be a huge problem[/b] - having close intense combats is very weird and hits sometimes take a few moments to appear. 

[b]TONS and TONS of bugs and glitches.[/b] Have not had a single playing session without [b]visual bugs[/b] such as one player not showing what cards they picked; beeing in a party and not actualy joining the que with them; not beeing able to pick a hero in champselect; not seeing what your alies pick in champselect; crashes at the start of a match - not able to rejoin; getting stuck in objects on the map; etc (dont remember all of them^^)
Sometimes [b]matchmaking feels kind of unbalanced[/b] having to play against 3 people with some hero at lvl200+ and getting completely annihilated.

As I mentioned before its [b]still fun[/b]; great variety of playstyles with cards, decks, ingame Items and pretty cool map designs.
Overall the problems above make this game [b]frustrating to play,[/b] by still sqeezing a few laughts out with my friends here and there.

Interesting concept, but a very easy game. Takes mere hours to master a character and memorise all the details of a map (not too much variety on that front). My biggest issue is the matchmaking, I got calibrated to gold because the matchmaking dice roll gave me vegetables as teammates for the games I've lost. After climbing with friends to diamond the game told me I am no longer allowed to play with more than one friend as a premade (only duoqueue) on diamond rank. Having two friends greatly reduced the RNG that is matchmaking, the worst case scenario being two vegetables in my team, but apparently on high ranks your teammates should only be decided by the matchmaking dice roll. The online in this game is pretty bad, check out on steam stats for the numbers. All in all, it's a pretty cheap knock-off of overwatch which, despite being F2P, seems more dead than Overwatch is. I have had games where I got the same teammates/enemies three times in a row in matchmaking.

I have to write as someone with experience with Overwatch. In short, I think Paladins is a much more unique and fresh perspective. I also don't think that is a 1:1 comparison though because they are radically different games. Paladins is almost a hero shooter mixed with a moba, whereas Overwatch is the traditional hero shooter. There are a few major differences that I think make Paladins the better game, primarily the following:

1) Each individual character is super customizable. The card system makes can radically change playstyle, and during the match you can buy items much like a moba. The cards generally alter your main weapons and skills in some way (faster reload, adding health, speeding up skill recharges, etc) making different builds feel pretty different in game. You also pick 1 of 3 major skill changes at the beginning of the match. For example, Viktor can heal while sprinting, shoot his rifle in burst mode, or have really improved grenades. So there's a lot to unpack here that make the playstyle different.

2) Matches feel a bit shorter than OW, and maps are much smaller. While you'll find long LOS opportunities in OW, they aren't really there in Paladins. Maps are much more crowded and it makes the action faster. You even have mounts to get you back to the action quicker.

3) There's an enormous roster of heroes here. And a lot of skins. It's fun, I have played a handful and there is a lot of variety. They generally fill traditional hero shooter roles (Frontline, Damage, Flanker, and Support) and each role has over 10 heroes. Just a lot to play around with and they all feel different.

4) On PC, I haven't waited long to play a match. Like 15 second wait times for a game at 5am. That's cool, because I often play at weird hours.

I do think there are some flaws. It clearly isn't a AAA title, and you can tell sometimes. The game can be buggy. Communication is a little hard (I think I'm spoiled from Apex). On PC you might have to edit the keybindings so you're comfortable, but overall I think it's a really good experience. 

This title breathes a lot of fresh air into the genre, and is legitimately an incredible game. I've enjoyed playing around with the skills of the heroes I like (so far Khan, Viktor and my fave so far- Grohk).

Paladins is a game I have a love-hate relationship with. There are many things to love, and also hate so I'll explain some of it. 

Pros: 
-Nice characters
-Unique abilities
-Free To Play
-Cross-play
-Cards for better abilities and items you can buy in match. 
-Fairly-nice community
-Beautiful skins
-Hours of fun
-New characters frequently

Cons:
-Bugs, bugs and more bugs. There are so many bugs, some are worse that others, and it is difficult for the devs to fix due to bad initial programming.
-Some characters are ridiculously overpowered, some having auto-aim abilities.
-Big Hitboxes.
-Joining and creating party issues.

Final Review: Paladins is a fun game, and if you can work past some of the minor inconveniences, you are in for a fun time.

With almost 2000 hours in this game and playing since early beta, I've got a pretty good idea of the game. I absolutely recommend this game to newcomers into the FPS genre however, people that don't have that great of a computer, expect the game to be poorly optimised for you and bugs to (maybe) run rampant. The in game community for this game can either be people on servers that don't speak any English with you having no way to communicate with them unless you thoroughly learn the VGS system (which takes a while, trust me) or the most vicious and whiny people. Casuals feel like competitive games and competitive games feel like you're either heavily getting rolled or rolling. Matchmaking has gotten better but isn't all the best it could be yet.

The few things I loved about Paladins was the loadout system and how unique each champion was to play. I have unlocked and played every single champion in this game so far and each is a pleasure to look forward to play. However if you're playing casuals and have an idea of who you want to play and if they're coincidentally a DPS character, you might want to insta-lock before the rest of the team auto-locks a DPS. However if you're looking to play a fair game you might want to pick up at least 4-5 champions in each class because it's a lot more common than you think, even with 45(?) characters in this game to choose the same champion as someone else.

The community is almost worse compared to Overwatch. It is actually quite unfair to compare this game to Overwatch. However at the start, Paladins was a completely refreshing and enjoyable game. Loadouts made this game unique and the fact you can customise your loadouts to fit your play style was amazing! That's what I loved about Paladins. 

But over time it seemed like Paladins was trying to compete with Overwatch. It's very sad because as much as I love Paladins, it was built on code that was combined from different games which meant that bugs are going to be hard to fix which frankly, over half of the community complains about at least 10 different bugs in their social media comment sections each day. And if they aren't complaining about bugs, they are complaining about how the Evil Mojo team should be focusing on bugs instead of skins despite there being separate groups for each. 

Which is unfair to Evil Mojo, ultimately. If they had the same resources and time most other games did, I couldn't fathom how amazing Paladins could've been. And that's IF they never stretched the teams so thin. So I'm only giving this game a slightly bad review based off of how poorly the developers seem to be treated, by both the community and its company.

*Edit, Paladins just announced Vora and I've just watched the trailer. I'm a bit sick and tired of the over sexualised characters in this game. I'm not saying sexy characters can't exist but It really gives me the vibe that all they care about is fanservice when it comes to female characters. I can provide a list of such. These characters include Io, Lian, Seris, Skye, Willo, and Ying but this list doesn't include any skins, just the default skins. It is also disgusting that they put boobs on a female character that is canonically 3 years old (Willo.)

As time passes by, I notice more issues with Paladins and I hope they try to better themselves as a brand because its getting pretty bad (IMO) at this point.

Is Team Fortress too old for you? Is Overwatch too expensive or you just don't feel like using another launcher? Well congratulations you found a free knock off that does the same thing as every other routine FPS team game.

You can debate over which game borrowed ideas from which, and it shares some passing resemblance with Global Agenda, just reskinned with less  sci-fi elements and that wasn't a bad game either, 

There's nothing terribly wrong with the game, but in the end they all just kind of blend together. If this had a price tag i might thumb it down, but it's free and if you are into this sort of thing it's probably at least worth looking at to see if you want this option.

Non-transparent ban system / auto-bans for no reason

Played this game over 2.000 hours and was banned twice (1st time 24 hours, now 72 hours in august 2020) in this game. It was just my 3rd ban in my total playtime in 1,5 years.
Last year when I had the my 1st ban (24 hours) I tried to get some information from hi-rez support. But they couldn't tell me the reason in more than 4 requests.
So I decided then not to contact them any more for possible occuring further bans...

A totally non-transparent auto-ban system makes a real good game unplayable in competitive mode. People seem to report you for no reason: jealous gamer, troll player, non-serious player which where confronted with the truth while playing ranked mode... All of 'em can report you so that many pro-players use 2-3 different accounts just to be able to continue to play this game.
I am not willing or going to create different accounts just to play a game in which I reached that progress with my characters on my account just because developers don't check the legitimacy of the reports of a player before banning him.

THIS is the FIRST(!) game which banned me in my over 25 years(!) on PC-gaming experience.
And there was a lot(!) MP-games I played in these years.

It's a shame but I won't play this game any more (after 2.088 hours gaming time exactly) because of this non-transparent ban system or either recomment it to any other players.
Could have learned two foreign languages in that time I wasted in this game.

It's a shame...

Don't waste your time when you wanna play competitive!!

I've spent a lot of hours on this game.  Its fun for a free game.  No need to actually buy anything as you're able to unlock, I believe, all the characters eventually.

As of 2020 Aug:
Lots of bugs though, that causes the game to crash often.  In my house we have two Nintendo Switch consoles.  Paladin's crashes about every 5th - 7th game.  Pretty irritating too, in that if it crashes while you're in queue, you end up with a deserter penalty which prevents you from re queuing for a period of time.

If you crash during game the system AI takes over your character while you're restarting and purchases trash items that you're stuck with when you log back in.

Poor balancing when it comes to groups, or PC vs console.  When you're on console you can choose to only play against console players but if another PC player is group'd with a console player,  you'll still end up playing against that team.

Pros:
- Unreal Engine Graphics
- Build Customization
- Many Champions
- Many Cosmetics

Cons:
- Graphics are bugged whenever you try to change settings.
- Audio issues when using headphones.
- 90% of the champions are behind a pay and grind wall.
- Some champions are way better than others, some are practically useless or have better alternatives.
- 90% of cosmetics are behind gambling loot boxes (chests) with not have specific results.
- The gold you get after matches are very low and almost impossible to play for free.
- There is no pack that unlocks all champions like Smite.
- Many content are behind time limits and season passes which forces you to pay more money.

Overall a big downgrade from Smite and an absolute grindfest to play. If you don't have many friends who can play with you or you don't have lot of money just don't play it. Not recommended. Not player friendly.

[h1] So what to say about Paladins? [/h1]

I've always heard, literally since I started playing in Open Beta, that people say it's just an Overwatch clone, which considering that

A. any shooter is a Overwatch clone by that logic?
B. they came out just a few months apart (OW before Paladins with Paladins being 1-2 months after)

I've always found it unfair to label it as a clone of something it's just losely based on (both are shooters and both have hero/champion characters to play as). Paladins has a lot of neat quirks and features that OW doesnt have and vice versa.

The main thing that sets Paladins apart though is how the gameplay flows:
[list]
    [*]You pick a Character for the whole game- no mid round swapping around
    [*]You make Cart Sets and pick Talents to make your character more unique in play style
    [*]You buy items like in a MOBA to get less cooldown, life rip etc.
[/list]

I've always called Paladins a ''weird MOBA shooter'' and it really is. The concept of making Card sets to really suit how you wanna play that champion makes the gameplay so different from Overwatch. The same with not being able to switch characters mid match. Team comps matter more and you gotta think more about what you think may help your team or yourself at winning the game.

All in all, it's a unique experience, one that i definitely recommend for anyone who's into shooter games and wants to try a new way of playing that familiar Genre.

This game always gets that "oh it's just an OW clone", however for something that has its roots in that statement, it's come a very long way. The game still has it's bugs here and there but not nearly as much as at launch. There's a large character roster, and the item system combined with the loadout card system brings much more variety than any other class-based shooter I've played. Characters need to be unlocked (unless you're a pleb like me who payed $15 to unlock every champ ever), but they can be unlocked using the in game currency, and even $15 isn't a bad price for the amount of work put into this. The devs also are actively keeping up with the community as well with weekly updates. Def give it a shot, all it'll cost you is some storage space going in.

I've owned the game since 2016 and I know I don't have a bunch of hours in the game (Due to another game with a similar take.. *cough*) but I can tell the game has gotten better since it's first few steps.

It's a pretty great game at no cost and I find it to be less toxic and less demanding of your very get good attitude. Though as of recent with the events taken place at Blizzard I'm starting to see chat be a bit more.. outspoken. Though most of the time you don't feel DEMANDED of you to be the best or carry the team.

Now going to actual game-play it's good & very fun. you have 3 basic game modes: 

Siege (Claim an area to move the payload to the enemy base) 

Team Deathmatch (first team to 40 kills wins. The first team to 400 tickets wins.)

Onslaught (I'll let HighRez explain this one: Two teams. One Control Point. Capture and hold the center point in King of the Hill-style gameplay with a Paladins twist. Slay your enemies to keep them off the point and earn 5 tickets for your team. Plus, get 1 ticket per second your team controls the point. The first team to 400 tickets wins.) 

Overall basic game modes but enough to keep the game fun and somewhat fresh every time!

I also enjoy the elements of customizing your abilities known as talents and creating card decks each with their own advantages and playstyle to how you want to play. I also feel like each character is very unique to their own without having to have a huge story to introduce them, they all fit very well into the established universe in which they all reside in.

Things I find disappointing:

The main thing I find problematic & wish that were better are the In-game currency you use to buy actual chests (loot-boxes) that are provided in the Season pass, you only get about 5 Crystals every so level ups compared to the only example I can think of which is Fortnite that gives you 100 V-Bucks every so often. Now the reason I state it's problematic is because Chests (Loot Boxes) are crazy expensive, they cost about 400-500 for the base chests and sometimes they go on sale for 100-200-300 Crystals sometimes. but you're making about 5 Crystals every so often at least a good increment in the amount of Crystals you get would be stellar maybe 50 or 100 would be amazing. but 5 is staggering, personally.

Also minor nitpick but some of the models in-game don't have any animation to their eyes.. yeah it's a small detail but I'm like that personally, and the models while playing the game feel lifeless due to that sometimes. BUT in the lobby when you're choosing your character or customizing your character, the model there has actual animation to the eyes/facial animations.. So I just find it odd it's not added to the real game-play portion and not just the lobby/customization menu.

Last thing I wish Hi-Rez Studios could do is finally add more maps and or at least variations to current maps to spice it up each round. Since I quit playing the game a while ago and just came back last year 2020, it's been the same maps since then + some added new ones which honestly I can't recall what is new. I noticed that the maps got smaller, back then maps were massive and it for sure was more of a pain to traverse those old bigger maps compared to these tight and somewhat better versions. Nonetheless no real complaints to the current maps, more of a wish to get new maps and or variations to current ones to shuffle through during each finished match also just to spice things up. 

Now back to the game and not my rant on the Season pass crystal amounts.

If you're thinking about playing this game or you find it interesting enough, or simply you don't have money for another certain shooter game that is about the same as this one, or you're escaping that very game for some very shady practices THEN I definitely encourage you to give this game a try. If you have friends to play with it's even more of a blast also.

Overall I love it, besides the complaints I've stated. I like the way Hi-Rez is continuing to update the game and not give up on it. The updates have made the game better overtime and I hope they continue to give the game more polish and not just release a character every 2.5 milliseconds.

Thanks for your time!

You're at the Dollar Tree and you notice a soda you've never heard of before, [i]Dr. Thunder[/i]. It's half the cost of Dr. Pepper and comes in a 3 liter bottle. You could drink that all night and still have THUNDER left over for tomorrow. [i]Quality over Quantity,[/i] you think before passing on the bottle. It's what I did for 3 years on Paladins, before downloading and playing it in wine fueled evening.

Buy the Dr Thunder.

When compared to the on brand variant, there is evidence of cut corners. Characters are flatter than a defective traffic cone, and while there are more choices, it's like shopping at a Japanese specialty store for Kit Kats. They might have a green tea flavor, but it's still a Kit Kat. The objective based game types are not nearly as tense as the on brand, big brother, but death match is it's own special thing. Plenty of recompense in a good arena, with lots of trash talk, and bullets. 

This testament to brands are bullshit, and love doesn't make a thing [i]better,[/i] sad as that may be, is still a great time, if not cynical. This wouldn't be here without the other more popular thing, but for accessibility and market share, I sure am happy this is here. I suppose my frustration is in its quality, far from a demo of the full hero shooter experience, it's all here on display, with more (less tailored) ideas. 

And if you do end up wanting to throw some money at the game (I did, after 10 hours or so) you'll often find the champ pack on sale. 

The last point, is about generics, and about brand ethos. Is it worth supporting a company that sells an arguably worse product, when their R&D allow something like this to exist so cheaply? 

I don't know, but it doesn't bother me when I'm making people salty with Kinessa.

Honestly, it's a game that one should definitely try at some point. I am surprised at how varied the gameplay is, there are over 45+ champions and each champion can be customized using Talents and on top of that you can use Cards to create Loadouts for each Champion and each Champion has their own set of Talents and Cards. So basically this game never gets old, there are multiple ways of playing a champion, for example a support/healer cane be played as the main Damage dealer or a tank can be used to flank and so on all thanks to the Loadout and Talent system. 

It has to be one of the most fun game I have played and for those interested in Story, this game has a really deep Lore and has been expanding since the release. There's frequent updates and patches and new Champions every now and then, Community is really nice and constantly growing, and the Developers always take an extra step to encourage community made stuffs by having things like FanArt Friday, Showing off good Art on their Youtube Channel and having events like Community BattlePass and FanForge and so on.

To top it all off, this game can run on basically all types of PC and you can even play with players playing on Consoles if you wish to or just queue against other PC Players.

 Overall definitely a game I would recommend.

Initially a game me and my friends flocked to as a free Overwatch alternative, this game quickly showed it's colors and showed how much more unique it really is. Paladins has been joked about before due to some similarities to Overwatch, but with much more frequent updates, as well as being free from the get go, Paladins is already ahead in some regard. Paladins also has many more characters to play as, allowing for a larger variety in how you play the game. Unfortunately, this game suffers from the same thing many other major games suffer from: how easy it can be to feel angry at either your enemies or your team. This was the main reason our group stopped playing, as we always felt like we were angrier after finishing a couple games. If you can deal with this issue, or are already acquainted with this feeling due to LoL or Overwatch, then this game is for you.

That said this game is absolutely riddled with bugs that have been around for several patches and the team clearly just doesn't have the know-how to fix. Most of them are non-game-breaking but just annoying.

And THAT said it looks like Mojo is trying to hire senior and lead programmers, so hopefully they'll find good people to fill those roles that are actually capable of fixing the bugs.

If they fix the bugs then the only remaining issue will be imperfect netcode, but at least everyone suffers equally and consistently from that. Get prepared to die after thinking you've escaped behind a wall by .7 seconds.

I still play Smite occasionally and this game was made by the same company, so I figured it would be worth checking out. I really wanted to like this game and for some time, I enjoyed playing it despite my initial reservations. It's one of those titles you have to play to actually experience the fun of, gameplay videos don't really do it justice.

But the further I got, the more obvious it was to me that Paladins lacked proper direction. It's artstyle is an unappealing mess, and while the level you can customize your playstyle with cards is simply unmatched this also leads to a number of problems with balancing everything out. Things would be much easier with the usual approach to asymmetrical balance, but the depth this system offers is precisely the biggest appeal of this game and why I would consider checking it out.

What made me actually quit Paladins was the terrible, awful, salt-on-a-wound matchmaking system it has. As with almost every multiplayer game, the people who are skillful but not quite at the top (such as diamond- and masters- level players) make for the most toxic part of the community; and their toxicity is further amplified by said matchmaking system that creates tremendous amounts of frustration. I don't plan on ever going pro and don't spend 6 hours a day honing my FPS skills, so for a casual looking to spend his free time on lowering stress levels dealing with them isn't a good experience.

While Overwatch kept getting worse and worse after each update, I feel like Paladins has just keep improving. I first played it years ago, and even though I liked it, it still felt a bit "Budget OW", it had some good executions and ideas, but lacked that little bit of extra polish and feel OW nailed. However, while that 'extra' was never implemented, Paladins just keep on delivering. There are a few minor bugs here and there, and the matchmaking may be a little be "weird" at times, but overall it keeps that original idea intact and just improves on it. Among all things, I think I enjoy the character design the most, at the same time they are very varied, but they still feel like they could belong in a world all together, and they all have different ways to be played. There's nothing really bad to say, if you like Hero Shooter, you'll very likely like this one too.
The game itself is really good. The only bad thing about it is the match queuing time (1-5 minutes).

I want to like this game, and it's certainly good enough that it wouldn't be fair for me to not recommend it (I played for a couple hundred hours on the Switch before putting in the 43 hours I've got logged on the PC), but as my SSD continues to fill up, Paladins didn't make the cut, and here's why...

With many multiplayer games that I've put a lot of time into, like DCUO, my review is something along the lines of "Flawed game, stayed for the great community." Paladins is the opposite. I love the characters, I love the gameplay, and I love the level design. It's the social interaction that detracts from it.

As with all games of this type, in which the characters are quite different from each other, and even the talents you then choose and the perks you purchase throughout the match continue to significantly affect the role you fill and the result of the match, there is always going to be a divide between the casual players who just want to play a fun, relaxed game, and the more serious players, who feel it is their duty in life to nag at you about everything you're doing wrong, boot you from the group if you choose the wrong character, etc. Regardless of which end of that spectrum you fall under, this aspect of it can make it difficult to enjoy what otherwise has the potential to be a great game.

Now, if you've got a few buddies you intend to group up with on a regular basis, that's a lot of fun. But if you intend to rely on random groups (I'm a night shift worker who has no life and therefore no friends :p ), be prepared for the toxic environment that is becoming all too common in this type of game.

It's Overwatch, but free to play, deeper (more choices of playstyle per hero) and a fair bit buggier. A couple of the heros can feel a bit unfair to play against and matches can be decided on the character select screen (composition is very important), but if you put some time into learning a role and have a few friends to party up with then you can have a lot of fun.

The Seige game mode is fantastic - capture the point turns into payload escort, demanding your team to adapt to what you have to do and how your opponents are attacking/defending. Close games going either way seem to be fairly common, and are where the game feels at its best. You'll occasionally be stomped (or stomp) but the matchmaking is fairly good at balancing (it takes recent matches into account, so win streaks are pretty tough).

Paladins is a free to play hero shooter with a roster of 30-or-so characters divided into four groups; flank, damage, support and frontline. The charaters range from shooty soldiers to dagger-throwing catgirls and giant cannon-wielding tortoises. The game is played over three different modes; team deathmatch, capture point and siege - a payload escorting game mode. In each mode five players form a team against five other players. In ranked mode you can also ban out problematic champions.Paladins puts its own spin on the hero-shooter genre by allowing you to customize your characters playstyle by allocating five "cards" to your loadout that can alter how you can utilize your skills. You might have a shorter cooldown on some key skills, more health, faster movement etc. In a match you will also earn credits to spend on further modifiers that can reduce reload speed, increase movements speed or healing etc. It's a good system and is fun to mess around with. The game has a few monetization forms, which don't feel too invasive or predatory (unless you count in lootboxes). You can buy a champion pass that opens up every champion available and all future champions too. You can buy the battlepass to get cosmetics, you can buy skins and other cosmetic crap with either direct purchases or in lootboxes. Grinding for in-game currency to open up new champs is pretty fair, but the wait for premium currency can be quite long, unless you really grind out the battlepass system. Even then it's a long wait for a single particular skin or even a box. The game has pure crossplay too, making play possible between ps4, switch and pc. This is very big, as the player base is not that expansive.Paladins is also buggy, messy piece of crap code that will drive you utterly insane.The game crashes frequently, the party system can just bug out, there is barely any matchmaking in the game, the playerbase is toxic and this frequently results in games with bots replacing ragequitters (this problem is probably caused by the non-existent matchmaking causing unwinnable stomps). Hit/hurtboxes are wildly inaccurate with headshots happening even on blatant misses and deaths behind cover happening every now and then. These negatives can make the game an extremely painful experience, even if there is fun to be had.Oh and the lagging servers are apparently out of control. Howabout shots going through walls, players glitching through floors, shots and abilities never firing out, teleporting players, the list just goes on and on and on. At least on EU, the game can become pretty much unplayable at times and Evil Mojo barely does anything to alleviate the situation. Maybe it's because of crossplay like Street Fighter 5, maybe the game is utter spaghetti code and the servers are the cheapest they can find. Who knows. Try the game out for free, but don't spend money on it unless you REALLY love it. The game is a total mess and isn't really improving over time.

I recommend this game because it is free, fun,full of action and it will probably give you more hours of enjoyment then many payed games will. It's a Hero kind of 5vs5 battlearena with 4 gamemodes (TDM, Hardpoint, Siege and Ranked Siege). All heroes have mutliple skills but only the ultimate skills are really OP. Somehow they never feel as frustrating as in other Hero games, it always feels somewhat fair or logic when you die. The weapons itself do enough damage that good aim really is rewarded and gunfights don't feel like an endless grindfest decided only by skills. At the same time the time to kill is long enough that you can't dominate the whole lobby only with great aim. It will be very difficult to win 2v1 or 3v1 fights so teamplay and sticking together makes all the difference. There is a long list of heroes to choose from, but it seems like a lot of them have comparable outcome of skills. That results in just a different cosmetic display of the same skill.  What i really enjoy is that you can build/tweak each hero with the cards to fit your own personal playstyle. The que time for finding a game are maybe a little bit longer then most games (+-3min), especially if a player leaves the lobby when the match is about to start, but at the same time this is probably the first game i played where every game all the positions of the teams are filled and nobody ever left during the game either. So i'm glad to wait a bit longer for better quality games.

Cons of the game:
- Earning Gold bug. Sometimes you don't get any of the gold you earn after each match, untill you restart the game. I find it a bit worrying that for a game that's been out this long these kind of bugs haven't been fixed yet. Especially since this gold is pretty much the only way to unlock new heroes.
- Ranked: Ranked is only available in the gamemode i liked the least. You will need to put 10 hours into the game to unlock ranked.  And once you get there, the community seems fairly toxic in the experiences i had. It reminded me of CS. Prepare for 14 year olds telling you what legend or class you should pick almost every single game, and leaving the lobby when you dare to pick a different one  even if it's in the same class (because you didn't unlock the other legend yet because you don't get the gold). This often rises the que times to 10+minutes. One was also of the oppinion you shouldn't play ranked if you haven't played for over a year because a lvl 7 character is useless to their team. Apparently they seem to think, that this game is rocketscience and you need to graduate from their university before you are allowed to have the honor to play with them. Also a lot of namecalling, wishing eachother deseases and all that good stuff during games. People dieing and shouting they needed heals while the healer was allready dead, because the one who died ran off 20km away from the objective into enemy base, only shooting in front of them and not paying attention what's happening behind or to the sides. Overal it's mostly a game about sticking together to win. But because of the bad experiences i think i'll stick to normal gameplay instead of tanked, also because i found TDM and Hardpoint modes way more fun and less predictable for me. And the people are way more chill.
this is an amazing online pvp game if your r looking for some quick action and something a little cartoony

s a team-based multiplayer first-person shooter developed and published by Blizzard Entertainment. Described as a "hero shooter", Overwatch assigns players into two teams of six, with each player selecting from a roster of over 30 characters, known as "heroes", each with a unique style of play that is divided into three general roles that fit their purpose. Players on a team work together to secure and defend control points on a map or escort a payload across the map in a limited amount of time. Players gain cosmetic rewards that do not affect gameplay, such as character skins and victory poses, as they play the game. The game was initially launched with only casual play, but a competitive ranked mode, various 'arcade' game modes, and a player-customizable server browser were added after release. Additionally, Blizzard has added new characters, maps, and game modes post-release, all free of charge, with the only additional cost to players being optional loot boxes to earn cosmetic items. It was released for PlayStation 4, Xbox One, and Windows in May 2016, and Nintendo Switch in October 2019.

Overwatch is Blizzard's fourth major franchise and came about following the 2014 cancellation of the ambitious massively multiplayer online role-playing game Titan. A portion of the Titan team came up with the concept of Overwatch, based on the success of team-based first-person shooters like Team Fortress 2 and the popularity of multiplayer online battle arena games, creating a hero-based shooter that emphasized teamwork. Some elements of Overwatch borrow assets and concepts from the canceled Titan project. After establishing the narrative of an optimistic near-future Earth setting after a global crisis, the developers aimed to create a diverse cast of heroes that spanned genders and ethnicities as part of this setting. Significant time is spent adjusting the balance of the characters, making sure that new players would still be able to have fun while skilled players would present each other with a challenge.

I've been playing for a while, and recently there have been more and more bugs that make this game a drag and unplayable. I just tried loading into the game, but it said "version mismatch- reconnect" before I logged in. I clicked it, and logged in fine. Jumped into a match only to play for two minutes before everything froze and I was magically back at the log in page. I get placed back into the game again, (Same one. they put you back into the same game if you get disconnected, replacing you with a bot in the meantime) and then immediately get disconnected again to a black screen. I Alt-f4 the game and check my internet to see if I'm the problem, if I truly am on the wrong version, and my connection is good, my ping was 32-64 in game, and I was on the most up to date version. I load the game again, and try to get into a lobby with a friend. after five minutes of trying to lobby up, I get put into the same game again, only to have it last about 30 seconds before we lose. I know this game was free, but the bar was set pretty low and I am still disappointed in this games performance. I can even overlook the fact that you have to either unlock or buy all the characters, I just want it to be playable which is a roll of the dice, at best, whenever I log on.

Given a larger budget and more resources I feel it could really be amazing and a stand-out gem in the market, but as it stands it's mostly an arcade-y, "one more match" type of game best played from a relaxed distance. This is by far the most fun hero shooter I’ve invested my time into, where in most other games I end up growing a distaste for playing against certain characters and load outs, Paladins is a game that presents you with a slew of characters that guarantees that at least one fits you like a glove. The item and card systems present in the game do a lot to promote unique and creative playstyles, or just copying top player builds to turn your brain off and have fun. My complaints with this game are that outside of Siege and Ranked, I don’t think there’s a single game mode I enjoy, and that the game’s physics engine, for lack of better words, feels unpolished where something about character weight and the gravity of the game don’t work well to create refined consistent and fluid movement and often feels like “Overwatch under water”. With changes to the physics engine, this would absolutely be the greatest shooter I’ve ever played, but because of the movement I end up feeling an odd dissatisfaction with my actions in game. Though the physics could just be a me problem, I’d recommend giving it a shot, with some friends preferably.

Super fun and gets a bad rap as 'discount Overwatch', but it really is its own game!

PROS:
Awesome roster of heroes
The talent and 'deck' system makes for some really diverse playstyles
Fun cosmetics and voice lines
Easy to grind coins to unlock more champions, however the default roster is definitely playable and viable from the first time you play

CONS:
As with all F2P games, there is a heavily monitised item shop for cosmetics, however you can no longer buy levels on champions to unlock their talents faster, which is good.
They removed some of the best voice commands/VGS systems and the play of the game, so sometimes your awesome plays go unseen
Gameplay can sometimes feel a bit slow, or even empty on the bigger maps even if there is a full 5v5 game.


Overall a solid 4/5 game for me, especially because its free and holds its own against OW and other arena shooters

A game with high potential which seemed promising at the start however now is seemingly abandoned by it's developers. Each update brings one bad decision after the other and also introduces more and more game breaking bugs. 
Server issues have a been a problem for multiple months now with seemingly no end to them. 
Perhaps Hi-Rez or Evil Mojo knows that the game can't live on much longer which explains the financial pain you have to go through in order to buy something you want. You can't. You can only either A) Buy lootboxes (hooray...) with a CHANCE to get what you want or B) Wait for your desired item to potentially appear in the "Deal of the day" which costs 8€ and includes 3 completely random items which can either be a skin, emote, spray, avatar, ... however it is stated nowhere clearly if the item you want is even in the item pool that can appear in this deal.
Game balance is something Hi-Rez hasn't learned much about in the past few years. There have been so many big changes and harsh reworks that it feels like a completely new game today, both in a good but mostly in a bad way. Community feedback looks to be ignored on this topic.

Would I recommend it? If you have no money to buy Overwatch or aren't interested in other team-based online FPS games, then yes. Otherwise, no. The server problems, horrible matchmaking and excruciating game balance make this game an absolute nightmare and complete waste of time to play.

So where to start on Paladins.  I do feel like this game is a hidden gem.

A long time ago this game lived in the shadow of Overwatch and its kind of impossible to talk about Paladins without bringing that up.  Overwatch had much shorter of a shelf-life that I thought.  In the beginning, there was a mass fandom on near starwars level of zealotry.  Now everyone plays either Fortnite or Valorant.  Overwatch has languished and no new heroes are really being released.

In the interim, Paladins grew into its own and is now what I would consider a superior game.  First off, Paladins is constantly updates, frequently, with new battle passes.  New champions are churned out on a monthly basis, which each one being unique and for the most part decently balanced.  No champ is universally useless, while some are hated.  Rebalances and meta-shake ups happen frequently.

Where Paladins really succeeds is in its role as a competitive experience.  Overwatch ultimately failed as a competitive game because the meta was left to tarnish.  Champions have set skills and are not changable.  The action was too frentic and esports commentators could not really follow the action through the jump spams and bullet clouds.

Paladins is simple yet clean, its easy to find out whats going on.  The game has incredibly clear indicators to give situational awareness as to what is happening around you whether it may be a Viktor grenade or a Skye Bomb ult.  When watching competitve Paladins tournaments hosted by Hi-Rez, the action and commentary is very easy to follow.

In Overwatch, champions have set skills with ZERO customizations.  Overwatch tactics are based off picking a champ to counter your enemy even though you hate playing that role or champ.  Overwatch forced you to be "good" with everyone and you didn't see people be able to focus on one champ to become a master because someone would just counter pick you and own you because their kit cancelled yours.  I HATED that about Overwatch and I think that contributed to why it failed as a competitive game.

In Paladins each champion has 3 unique legendary skill and a "deck of cards" that can be created to support specific playstyles.  Paladins has over 45+ champions that grow every quarter and each champion can be custom tailored through legendary skills and decks to achieve completely different playstyles.  I have seen crazy crap that works, like a smoke bomb skye (who is normally a flanker assassin) carry the team as a primary healer with a skill that causes her smoke bomb to heal allies and with skillpoints that enhanced the effectiveness of said bomb.  You cannot do crap like that in Overwatch.

After the time I put into Paladins, I would say is a good game.  Sure the graphics are cartoony and not on Overwatch level, but they are enough to convey the action and have their own fantasy charm.  The champions are interesting with hundreds of playstyles that fit any player from any other FPS game.  If there is certain gun in another game, its probably in Paladins in some strange way.

You can conduct all sorts of crazy skilled plays.  There is always a handful of champs that will "click" for you.  My only complains are that yes matchmaking can be better, but no game has perfect matchmaking and getting stomped by a legendary player during the rare moments you encounter one happens in every FPS known to man.

Paladins is also free to play, the battlepasses and cosmetics are relatively cheap compared to say Valorant's 100$ dragon guns.  Skins range in all flavors from goofy to serious.  There are plenty of waifus like Grohk if your into that sort of thing.

I think anyone who likes competitive shooters should give this a try -for at least a week before passing judgement.  It's one of those games that may not feel so amazing at first but when it starts to click and you see the depth it becomes really addicting and grows on you.  It also has a stable and fairly large community, a competitive scene, and stays within high activity.

Paladins is a high-octane and fast paced team shooter. Many say it is an Overwatch clone -- it is not. There is plenty unique to this game and distinguishable between the two.

The art direction is beautiful, and the champion roster is vast and diverse in both gameplay and aesthetics. The maps are easy to learn, and easy to use. The game has a low skill floor, high skill ceiling. The champions and maps are approachable for newcomers with or without team shooter experience, and new characters are being regularly added. 

The loadouts present a bit of a learning curve, but guides for these can easily be found online. Each hero also comes with a set of preset loadouts for you to roll out of the gate with.

100% would recommend.  This game is a lot of fun.

Paladins is a hero shooter, much in the likes of Overwatch, but with more pronounced MOBA elements. The cast of numerous characters is colorful and they all have their own personality, even though some of them come off as rushed or not very well thought out. The graphics are serviceable, which means they are not the best but not the worst either; they are colorful and get the job done.

What makes Paladins special is its unique Card system, which allows you to customize each and every hero with your personal play style. It’s rare that you’ll see two players using a certain hero the same way, and this makes the game less stale overtime than other similar offerings. Because of this, each and every game ends up playing differently, and this is exactly what I love about the game.

The in game economy is based on cosmetic only loot boxes, which means that despite being free to play and not counting individual skill, no player will ever be stronger than another.

The game receives updates, events and new heroes extremely frequently. Even though some bugs and glitches tend to stay longer than necessary at times, they rarely become game breaking or end up taking away from the enjoyment of the game.

Paladins is a free to play title that simply doesn’t feel like one, and this balance is very difficult to achieve nowadays. A well crafted card system, colorful heroes and good shooting mechanics make this game a joy to play, allowing it to stand out among the crowd of otherwise stale titles offered by much more renowned names in the industry.

I really don't understand why the rating for this game is so high. 

The game is such a level of "casual" that it's barely competitive at all. AFKs every match, dead/empty chat in games, no skill gradient - It's awful. 

Plus I noticed you just flat-out removed POTG since I played last. Why? That seems like a move you only make if you're hiding the degree of exploits in your game, or just working around how bad the sever performance is. 

Further, the UI is a pretty far departure from other competitive shooters. It's not cool or charming, it's just clunky and irritating. Feels like a UI for a mobile shooter, tbh - the ridiculous prevalence of cash-grab extras and lack of new content support that claim too.

I am a simple man, I was raised on a farm in the midwestern United States. I never had much growing up, all I had was school, a handful of friends, and a good work ethic. From the age of 4 I was taught to never take anything for granted, I grew up fairly poor. I was living my life on the farm when a tornado came through and destroyed our entire farm, we had no means of making money now, and no money to rebuild. I did what any boy my age would do and I took up bounty hunting, which was very fruitful until my late teenage years. I then moved on to be a contractural assassin, where I have stayed for 40 years. I have many hours in this game and I can affirm that the rush I get from playing sneaky characters is similar to what I first felt 40 years ago.

I wanted to like this game. I really did. It's FUN, when it works. I'm on a brand new PC and 500Mbps internet and have constant problems.

Problems I have experienced...
1.) The server-side of the game constantly goes down booting everyone back to main menu. 

2.) The client crashes a lot too kicking you to main menu or even to desktop.
      I'm told this frequently happens with updates but gets fixed/patched. It shouldn't be this way. 

3.) Bots. Lots of Bots. If your friends loose connection... which they will. They get turned into bots who even have the name of your friend. There is no way to know your friends are even gone unless your on Mic and they stop talking.

4.) Combine these issues and your often discovering all real players either left the match or crashed and you're only playing with bots. This isn't fun and drastically ruins a match due to the matchmaking AI(?) of the bots.

5.) The refer a friend and be referred by a friend features do not work at all for me. Even contacted support, twice, and never heard back. No point in offering incentives to play with your friends when the incentives don't work, oh and your friends always getting disconnected and turning into bots.
