This game is this weird kind of bad, where you actually love the game itself but hate playing it. Let me explain...

I have over 1 300 hours in this game and found lots of great people in it, with whom I love to play with but... the toxicity of playerbase in paladins is just damn too high. It is so high that I tend to constantly find new great people to play it with, just to find out later that they quit it after investing few months of their time, out of sheer frustration. And it roots from two things - lots of lost games due things players cannot control and toxicity around them.

Toxicity is actually created by the game itself. Just look at this mechanic:

1) You wait 1-2 minutes to find lobby after queuing. 
2) Then you spend around 5 minutes (sometimes even longer) to choose champions and disscuss strategy a bit. 
3) Then you wait around 1-2 minute for it to load. 
4) Then you wait a bit for match to start while you prepare in spawn room for match which last around:
-   8 minutes, if literally enemies let you push objectives without almost any struggle,
- 15 minutes if one side is winning but youhave some nice fighting going on.
- 25 minutes if both sides are so balanced that neither can get point till last possible minute.

That gives us between 15 minutes to 34 for one game. And here comes the problem... sometimes you actually don't want to play that particular match. And you cannot quit. Maybe you get troll who picked in that first 2 minutes of game 3th tank and you know for 300% it will not work. Maybe someone disconects in first minutes of match and stand in spawn room not moving for rest of the match. Maybe he is actually not afk, but just writting on chat how bad others play and he won't help team.... etc etc etc. But you cannot quit - there is just no option to do it normally. So you get stuck sometimes even for a half an hour in matches you just constatly think about quiting match. But if you do, both your team and you will suffer for it - they need to finish match with constant disadvantage of having 4vs5 which is impossible situation if enemies are not total noobs, and you will get banned from queuing for next matches. That punishment actually gets bigger and bigger with each time you quit (it can even get longer time that one hour). If you play ranked game, you also lose points... which is extra frustrating since if you stayed you had small chance to not lose them, but if you quit you will lose them for sure. So you start to blame others. 

It became so bad recently that every second or third match is won or lost due to having AFK, trolling, disconnected or just refusing to play dude in one of the teams. 

To sum up, this game mechanic create vicious circle: 
1) Some people get disconnected due to internet problems, game crashing (also happens) or just pick wrong champion in the lobby before match started. This makes all other 4 people stick in an unbalanced, frustrating match fo an half an hour.
2) Next match you just get inexperienced teammates... and you lose again.  
3) Repeat that few times -> people will actually think they are doing good job by flaming other people mistakes. At least they feel a bit better and other frustrated people in team will agree with them.
4) More toxic players, create more matches with first situation, but now its due to them trolling or just refusing to play.

This create more and more toxicity.

And it is such a shame that it happens in this particular game. It has some really simple, easy and cool mechanics to grasp but also has many niuances harder to understand. Thx to that you can quickly get into playing it but also don't run into problem that you cannot improve your playstyle - there is always something you could do better or maybe way to help your team to win. It has impressive number of different champions, with more comming every now and then. And even the champions themselves can be played in totally different styles since each get 3 talents which hugely change how you use their skills, then you have cards system where you create different loadouts allowing you to emphasize different strenghs of your character. This allows you to not only adjust them to your playstyle, but also adjust them according to what enemies can do. Thanks to that, the game require some more strategic thinking than many others shooters... on the flip side, lots of characters and options for them create many unbalanced situations. And with such a huge number of them, many good options are actually regarded by people as bad, because they require some different playstyles to actually benefit from. 
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
In short - great gameplay with huge problems of toxicity created by game mechanics itself, with impressive variety of playstyle which gets a bit clunky due to unbalanced characters.

Right now, I can only recommend playing it with few friends. Playing solo will be way too frustrating.

Pros:
+ It is free
+ Addicting, gives you nice rush of adrenaline you want more 
+ Simple, easy, cool mechanics
+ Cards and talent system allowing unique playstyles and variety
+ Heavy emphasis on teamplay 
+ Impresive list of champions with very unique playstyles
+ Include playstyles involving something else that pure reflex and godly accuracy 
+ Punishes stupidity and reward strategic thinking

Cons:
- It is free -> no cost allows banned players to just create new account
- Addicting, gives you nice rush of adrenaline you want more... and more
- Toxicity created by game mechanics
- Every second or third match is lost or won due to AFK, trolling or flaming player.
- More than half of talents and cards are either bad or totally useless
- Not very balanced champions
- While it has anti-cheat protection, you still see cheaters around
- No options to quit or forfeit match
- No mechanic to replace disconnected player or even-out unbalanced matches
- Time consuming, it is hard to play casually

A completely free game that has 5v5 "champion" based combat, similar to Overwatch. There are many characters to choose from, and each has three perks to choose from, which can completely change their playstyle, You only start with a few, characters, like R6 Siege, meaning you have things to work towards and unlock as you progress through the game. Each champion has loads of cosmetics, and the game is regularly updated. The matchmaking is really good too, when you do get matched against a lvl 499 Maeve, you'll have a level 499 Lex on your team. It's completely free, much better than Overwatch and less sweaty than siege, and zero bots unlike TF2. Again, It's free - give it a go.

As of 7/19/2020, Paladins is my most played game on Steam with about 700 hours [i] (I know that compared to most people on steam, this isn't much, I have a busy life outside of gaming 20 hours a day) [/i]. The reason for this is because I can proudly say that [i] [b] this game is FANTASTIC [/b] [/i] and definitely worth playing or at least trying. I do of course think that there are things that make this game far from perfect, which I will get into later on in this review.
To start off, I very much appreciate all of the customization that this game has to offer. In Paladins [i] (as of July, 2020) [/i] there are 45 champions in the game. Each champion can be customized with a loadout that allows for 5 different unique passives to be upgraded to amplify abilities and base stats, making almost every player unique with how they can play a specific champion. Players who have the mentality that there should be one type of optimal loadout are just wrong, and I recommend that those people go find another hero shooter without this mechanic if you dread it so much. On top of customizing passive effects, there is a buy menu that is simple to work with and isn't as complex as League of Legends [i] (especially when LoL has 175+ items, compared to the 16 in Paladins). [/i] I am comfortable saying that this is very helpful, simplifying the buying process allows for better decision making mid game, in turn making the experience more fun.
I also really like the developer's creative skills. Evil Mojo [i] (as bad as they may be, which I will again expand upon very soon) [/i] has a great team designing very cool skins, battle pass rewards, and new champions to slap people with. Another fantastic trait behind this game is its vast amount of lore. I've struggled to get involved in the game's lore and story, as I find it more fun to just play the game for how it is. Although I haven't thoroughly educated myself in the story that guides the realm, I still appreciate that there is a whole team behind putting together lore to make the game and characters more interesting.
The gamemodes and fast paced gameplay that most first person hero shooters provide is definitely present here. All of the characters have unique abilities and roles [i] (other than Vivian, Tyra, and Victor, I find it hard to differentiate the three with how they are designed and played by most players). [/i] On top of the loadout customization that I touched on earlier, players can even customize champions that are intended to have supporting roles on a team to turn them into damage based champion, making it important for players to understand how characters can be used and to expect the unexpected. I also think that the game balance is done well, and that the meta is in a good place right now.
[b] NOW, [/b] everything above is what makes this game great, and I would even go as far to say that Paladins, because of all the cool stuff it has, is better than Overwatch [i] (feel free to ignite the comments section of this post on fire, you will be ignored based on negativity PepeLaugh). [/i] BUT, there are of course many things that hold this game back from truly being better than Overwatch.
The are countless bugs to this game. If you don't encounter a single bug during a one hour session, then congrats, you basically just won the f**king lottery. Most of the bugs are minor, and they usually don't cause much damage to your game, but it is still very unfortunate to see that who ever is coding this game clearly has no idea how to troubleshoot problems and fix them. Most of the major bugs do get patched, but the minor ones that are a nuisance to deal with remain, and it is unfortunate that players have to deal with it. I've always found it hard to explain to new players that they are experiencing a bug infested game, because sometimes it can be hard to notice and easy to say that "it is just an implemented feature of the game", when in reality it is probably unintended and that the devs are simply too lazy to fix the problem.
While I'm slamming the devs for not being able fix their game mechanically, I'll also say that the developers have kept the respect for the community to a minimal. The last thing I remember them doing something important that involved the community was for the community themed battle pass at the beginning of 2020, where they held a Google forms poll to determine which champions should get skins for the pass. Other than that, they've been taking feedback on Reddit that they don't even respond to or care about half the time. The activity on twitter that the devs also engage in is very unhealthy and makes the community look very bad. They're toxic people on social media who choose to add to the fires that bring down their game rather than to put them out.
Finally, I would like to end this review on a good note and say that Paladins really is a truly fun game to play. The devs are bad [i] (but not as bad as FreeJam PepeLaugh) [/i] but the people behind designing the game have a great creative outlet here, and it definitely shows how passionate these artists are with fantastic looking champions and a fulfilling story that brings the game to life. Unless the devs pull a Robocraft catastrophe, I don't see myself not playing this game for a long time. I will surely post another review if it ever does go down that path, but for now I am excited to say that this game is great. I recommend you play it, and I am definitely glad that it is my most played game on Steam.
Thanks for reading this review.

[i] (P.S: plz give Moji more skins peepoSad) [/i]

The characters are pretty cool, and it's pretty easy compared to other games, which makes this game good for people who aren't interested in games that require hundreds of hours of practice in order to be okay at the game. It works pretty well as a casual game, but as free games go I would definitely say that Team Fortress 2 is a better casual game. Paladins is still great when you just want to sit down and be competitive, but not super sweaty. The game engine is nice, and mobility is used really well in this game. I just wish you didn't have to grind just to own and play specific characters, and considering that quests don't make you much money it's kind of lame that I have to grind for a week just to buy a single champion. Still a great game though. I really wish that they would flesh out the "story" a lot more, I would love to see a comic series like they did with TF2 or an animated short of Lex and Androxus before Androxus got cursed, like a little buddy cop thing. The character descriptions paint a pretty cool world, I would love to see more of that. Overall, a pretty good game.

To be honest, this game is good, like really good. It's not the best, but it doesn't get enough credit that it deserves. When it was first released, they drew a good amount of inspiration from the oh-so popular OverWatch. But since then, it has verged off into a different game of it's own. The card system is really interesting and gives you different ways to play the same class. So in the end, the vast cast of characters becomes even more vast. Also, don't get me started with the weapon and gun skins, because they are amazing. Now this, is were we get into the bad parts. The Battle Pass is "eh" and is only mildly interesting. If you buy anything via. crystals, it is way overpriced. I think that's about it; Oh right, it's free! So if you are interested, there's now reason not to get it ;)
Play Overwatch or LITERALLY any other shooter instead

After a lot more playtime, I cannot recommend this game. This would be playable if:
- Evil Moji fixed their servers. I cannot count the number of games that were doomed from the start by something that isn't exactly lag, but means you can't jump, are killed around corners, and can't use some character abilities reliably. 
- Matchmaking stayed within continent. Why for the love of god would I want to play an entire team that doesn't speak my language and is 500 ms behind?
- Matchmaking matched with skill. About 90% of the time, if the above conditions haven't ruined the game already, the matchmaking will do the rest. Its a wipe in one direction or the other. Really unfortunate, because its not fun to steamroll other people, and it's not fun to get completely rolled either.

It's maybe 1 out of 100 games that are just fun with no complaints. I really wanted to love this game, and did for a while, but the more champions I unlocked, the more the flaws stood out. Some abilities require perfect timing to use. Hugh lag, or server jankiness, absolutely destroys a game. I was hoping these would be fixed as time went on, but they've only gotten worse. The game is being abandoned by the developer in favor of Rogue Company it seems.

2/10. Would not recommend.

It doesn't help that the braindead idiots hardly speak any English (or hardly speak at all), instalock one of 6 champs (Viktor, Koga, Tyra, Androxus, Vivian, Lex), and then die to the most obvious, easy to counter garbage. One of my absolute favourite games ever. People like to compare it to Overwatch, and since I've played both games I can tell you that I much prefer this game.

This game may not look as good as OW, and is definetly buggier, it feels less polished. But to put it simply, The polished good-looking state of overwatch is overshadowed by it's lack of balance and proper gameplay. On the other hand, paladins trades graphics for depth: An item store to add a feeling of progression to the game, no paper/scissors/rock action by switching champs mid game, personalization of characters trough very customizable loadouts and the choice of a game-changing talent. Also Paladins has more champions than Overwatch, and is much more balanced: while some champions are a little bit too powerful, it's not by much and to an extent every champion (apart from one or two, like skye) can be viable if played right or in the right situation. Somewhat frequent updates too although it feels like the glory days are long gone and so is the budget: new content consists of just skins in a battlepass, and sometimes a new ranked split/season, occasionnaly a champion... We used to get new gamemodes as events and such but it seems like Hi-Rez is done with throwing money onto this game...

Whatever, I still recommend this game, loads of fun, frustrating at times but it's the type of game that you keep coming back to despite the alleged flaws that it has had for years on.

Freemium game chocked full of sketchy psychological tactics that try to get you to spend money on it. Getting cosmetics is all but impossible unless you spend money on "shards" (funny money) to buy lootboxes, or a battle pass. It's really fun, especially with friends and there's a ton of different playstyles for each champion. It's free. It's extremely well optimized. However unlike overwatch, you have to unlock all the champions with coins which takes ages to grind for by playing matches. If you want, the champions pack is available for around 30 dollars and unlocks everything for you. Skins in this game cost a fortune and there are a couple bugs now and then. Not to mention, playing casual is a nightmare since you'll often get low level teammates. They also got rid of POG which kind of sucks. Graphics in this game is somewhat ok and there isn't a lore to this game at all. Playing ranked in any country other than the US takes ages to queue and ping is horrible since you need to switch servers. If you have the money I'd just recommend Overwatch. It's better in every way :).

Absolutely Fantastic game. having well over 30 hrs in both Paladins and Overwatch, i can comfortably say; Paladins is the more enjoyable experience. I should clarify however, i do come from Call of Duty style shooters, where customization is more than abundant. So going into Overwatch for the first time, it felt bare, and void of grindable content. Sure you can grind for in-game currency to unlock skins for Heroes and such.
But there's a problem; Let's look at Call of Duty for a second. currently, there are 104 unique camoflage patterns earnable via weapon progression and challenges, signifying one's mastery over a given weapon, or in the instances of Plattinum and Demascus; multiple, and all. Now, lets go back to Paladins. Each and every character has Mastery Champion skins, weapon skins, titles and more, earnable via Champion progression and Challenges. Better yet... It's FTP. so i mean, why not give it a shot?

VERY FUN TO PLAY
Unique Gameplay

[h1] Unique Hero Shooter [/h1]

Paladins is a very fun hero shooter with a play style for any type of player. I would say this game is a fun and interesting hero shooter with amazing creativity. Paladins is similar in playstyle to Overwatch, but much slower. It is a really fun core gameplay loop. The champions are fun to play, the abilities feel powerful and mostly balanced and it's just enjoyable to play. The customization of different loadouts for champions sets it apart from Overwatch. In my opinion it's way more fun to tweak the champion of your choice to your playstyle, than it is to pick a static champion type like Overwatch.  

The downside can be the toxic community. You often get caught between players who take the game way too seriously or those who don't take it seriously enough. Team comp is very important and so many people just don't understand it. You'll see a lot of damage mains blaming heals or frontline, lots of people who don't understand the strategy of the game but think that they do, flame others for not "playing right." You'll hear complaining and claims that they're carrying you based on raw stats, but don't be fooled. Stats do matter, but they do not tell the whole story. You can have 100k healing without healing at the right times or places. You can do 100k damage and it's all to shields or aoe without doing much. People sometimes don't remember that the objective of the game is the objective and they get lost in solo gameplay instead of team gameplay.  There is a meta, and there are right ways to play the game, but it's varied unless you're at the very top 1% of the playing field. 

There certainly is a lot of fun to be had in Paladins, but it's not in solo queue very often. Just play some games, find someone who plays as a teammate, makes friends and queue together. Trust me, you'll have a lot more fun with just one other person willing to play as a team. You can carry teams much easier as a duo or trio than you could as a solo player. 

If you're into ranking, the ranked system is okay, you'll get bogged down in certain brackets but don't be discouraged. Just keep plugging at it and again bring a friend if you can. Please make sure you have several different types of each champion that you've played and unlocked all their legendary abilities for. There is a banning system and your team will expect you fill whatever position is open. Generally at first you'll be choosing last, so be ready to play any role with at least 2 champions in that role. Meaning Frontline (tank), Support (heals), Damage (main dps) or flank (priority target hunting).

Don't worry too much about unlocking things, as you play the game you'll get more and more stuff. If you're not good with certain champions, don't get discouraged, there are some that are difficult to play and some that are easier. There are also a couple not so good champions, but check the patch updates as often they balance these out. 

Play what you enjoy, don't worry about others telling you that champion X or Y are garbage. It may be that they are not the best, but all of them can be played and you can still win games with them. There is a mentality that if you're not playing the absolute best everything in the meta, then you're trash. Don't listen to that unless you're pushing for high ranks. You still should choose a role that best for your team comp, but pick any champion you enjoy in that role. You'll find out what champions are good together and the synergies as you play the game.

The game can be very buggy and that can be frustrating, so keep an eye out for the plethora of bugs.

All that being said, I love Paladins. I find myself enjoying it more and more. It frustrates the crap out of me, but I really enjoy the core gameplay loop. All those tragic bad moments where your teammates are throwing the game feel bad, but then when you win that 3/3 point by placing an ult at just the right time or dodging one or just making a really good play as a team, it feels all the better. Don't take this game too seriously and just have some fun.

[h1] Review [/h1]
Paladins is an exciting, action-packed rip-off of Overwatch. While the two games are incredibly similar, Paladins being free possibly gives it the edge over Overwatch, seeing as both games have large active playerbases and compelling team-oriented gameplay.

[h1] Pros [/h1]
+ casual and easy to learn
+ relatively well-optimised so runs smoothly
+ not many cheaters

[h1] Cons [/h1]
- very difficult to re-learn after leaving for a while because they are always adding new stuff
- some characters are unbalanced

[h1] SCORE: 6.5/10 [/h1]

If you haven’t rolled hundreds of hours in TF2 or clamped some money on Overwatch, then the game will be like a breath of fresh air.
Paladins are not demanding on iron. In addition to the game settings, the grafonchik is perfectly adjusted in ini-files.
There are not many heroes, in addition, they are divided into popular and not. A typical soldier from shooters, an archer (s), a sniper camper and an invisible killer are the backbone of 80% of all matches.
The maximum expectation of the match is 2 minutes, which is very pleasing.
Up to level 5 you will have to fight against bots, then already with real people. Here you can see who dodged in CS and who did not.
As elsewhere, nobody really wants to take on the role of a tank or a healer. Often a team is recruited from damage characters.
We spend money from frags on cards that add us bonuses of damage, defense, running speed, etc., but do not change the balance of teams much. There is no such thing as in MOVA - whoever quickly stocked up, he bends down.
There are ordinary skins (for gold), which differ only in color, there are rare (for rubles), but these are few and fig. With the skins here, the trouble is generally, it's not Heroes of the Storm.
There is no incentive in the game to strive for something. If you wish, you will buy all the heroes in 3-5 days, choose your favorites for yourself, buy cards for them, a total week and ... everything

The 400 hours are for *this* Steam account alone. I often have to switch between Steam and Epic for PC because of bugs that occur with the server and bugs recognising controllers. I've had several Hi-Rez accounts, previously used the standalone launcher, played every console version of the game. My time combined exceeds 5,000 hours (around a thousand for each year I've been playing).

After all that time on the game over several years, accounts & platforms - what I can say is the game at it's core is wonderful and still has huge potential to be something amazing.

If you don't take the game too seriously, you will have a lot of fun. Which is what is important.

The ranked mode clearly and badly needs an absolute overhaul, which unfortunately hasn't happened for this year's (2022/Season 5) ranked season. But they have at least tried to fix the matchmaking system, so there's that. But if I were a brand new player, I'd leave cross-play enabled and enjoy "Quick Play" for what it is. That's likely going to be your best bet for enjoying your Paladins experience (especially if you have some friendos you can play with).

I'm not going to go over all the pros and cons, I think those have been exhausted in other reviews. But I will say Paladins has the upper hand compared to it's peers in terms of customisation and play style.

I've seen people say the devs don't care, I think this is unfair. I believe the developers who are actually making the game, do care. But there seems to be a revolving door at Hi-Rez studios which is where a lot of the game's problems come from. Code being left unfinished by devs who worked on the game 6+ years ago makes it very hard to untangle bugs. Sometimes ideas/features are inconsistent because of the revolving door. Those things are forgivable (to me) you can't expect new people working on the game to have all the knowledge of the previous developers.

What really lets the game down is the report system/customer support. The game has an in built report system, which is abused by people reporting someone for playing "poorly" (i.e. not how they would play) or not utilising the in-match item store well (there is no in-game explanation for this). Therefore when something more serious happens, the reports on it are buried and the offending players are left to run rampant (despite what the community manager touts on Twitter, there is no in-game swift action against these offenders).

In terms of customer support, I've had support tickets go unanswered since 2019 about real world currency going missing, racial abuse & in game threats of physical harm.

So while the majority of the community are actually quite lovely, if you come across someone stepping over the line in terms of toxicity don't rely purely on Hi-Rez to sort it. Report it to the platform the person is playing on (you can usually find this out from a third party stat site).

Obviously take caution when spending any real money in game too, as this is unusually non-refundable and there are several bugs affecting crystals and skins.

Sep 30, 2021:

The balance issues are fluid and improving steadily, though new ones are introduced at regular intervals. Overall the game is fun to play, except when there's some ridiculously OP oversight or exploit that every loser with a self-esteem problem will take advantage of until it gets fixed. Which sometimes is literally months. My biggest complaint about the game however, is in how they've fucked up the Battle Pass/Event system with this most recent incarnation. While you can still earn back the crystals you spent on the pass, it's now about 5x more difficult/annoying. To earn all the crystals back before, you had to reach level 120 of the pass, which took a significant amount of play time, even with boosters, but, if you kept up with it, playing regularly, since the passes were 90 days, you had to maintain an average of 1.33 levels per day. This wasn't always feasible if you had any semblance of a social life, a job, or wanted to play something else, or whatever. But I was cool with that. Now, the majority of the crystals have been moved to the "achievements" in the Trials of the Realms or whatever it's called. Which uses pretty much the same tasks that used to award 150,000 Battle Pass XP each, but divides them up in groups of 5, with 3 more groups being unlocked each week. But to make matters worse, of the "unlocked" groups, you can only have 2 groups of 5 active at any given time, and once activated, you're locked into that one until you finish it. Even though you can see what the reward is for each group, even if you went through and did every crystal one as soon as it became available, it's an inconvenient, annoying, boring, and unsatisfying undertaking. Most of the tasks are either so trivial, they literally take no more effort than playing a specific champion 5 times. The problem is that it's going to take you a minimum of 5 games to complete. Others require particular Talents for a particular Champion. More often than not, it's one of the worst, most useless talents they have. And then, there are the most interesting ones, and only ones that are actually satisfying to complete, but are less about skill and more about luck, or at least chance. These are the ones that require you to do 150,000 Damage, Shielding, or Healing in a single match. The majority of matches end before you've reached that mark. Some right before reaching it. They often force you to play champions you aren't good at, with Talents that handicap you, and provide no real element of fun, which all generally culminates in you losing the match. Especially when others on your team are also grinding. I never even bothered with going out of my way to do them when they were optional bonus XP, because the amount of matches it caused me to lose attempting them, was actually totalling to more XP than they gave. So I only did the ones that I just happened to do while playing, or that were within my wheelhouse. Even still, all of this could be forgiven if not for the tedious way they've limited you, making it difficult to kill 2 birds with 1 stone as you used to could accomplish several objectives in a single match. But the system of getting 15 each week of the pass and only being able to work on 10 at a time, drags out the monotony and tedium to the point that I'd rather do without the Battle Pass altogether than to have to do.

Worse still, is that instead of getting 4 new skins and 4 recolors with the Battle Pass, you now get 2 of each. The other 2 skins and 2 recolors become available from chests. That cost more crystals. For a RANDOM CHANCE of getting them.

Until this is fixed, my review will remain negative.
______________________________________________________________

Aug 10, 2021:

I started playing during beta, right around the time Sha Lin was added to the game. Since then I've watched it take 1 step forward and 3 steps backward with nearly every update. The first real WTF? was introducing Moji to the game. The only champion to have a constant attack with no cooldown or reloading necessary. Oh, and that's just the left-click, right-click is a burst with a short delay between shots, and also no cooldown/reload. And both can be held down constantly with no real drawbacks. This finally got tweaked (only slightly) in a much later patch, but, by then, far worse had gotten shoehorned into the game.

We'll skip past all the dumb nerfs, flip-flopping on ideas, and terrible trends, like how every Front Line after Khan has a shield unaffected by Wrecker. Or how a Jenos with Power Cosmeum can literally render pretty much any champion on the other team useless for most of the match. They added some 4-year-old's idea in the form of a worm that has crazy high defense, can move faster than champions on their mounts, is immune to ALL knockback effects, and whose primary attack also leaves spam all over the ground that acts as a DoT to anyone standing in it. Meanwhile, they've left glaring balance issues unresolved for months.

One redeeming quality of the game was that you could earn crystals (the primary currency in-game,) albeit not a lot. They introduced unique events that were fun, only to end them despite their popularity. They replaced them with a Battle Pass like so many other cash-grab games. But, to their credit, each Battle Pass cost 600 crystals and, IF you completed the entire Battle Pass, you could actually earn 600 crystals back. Meaning, if you worked hard, you could take part in every Battle Pass for free, but sacrificing the ability to spend the crystals you earned on unique cosmetics, chests, etc. Now, they've completely changed the format, making the bulk of crystals come from boring chore-like "achievements" that either make you play a champion you don't want to play, or accomplish something that's only half skill and the other half luck, like dealing 150,000 damage in a single match, healing 150,000 in a single match, and shielding 150,000 in a single match. Most matches ending long before you can possibly get to that point. And, while these tedious "achievements" could just be done before, you now have to unlock locations on a map to even be able to fulfill them. You can unlock 2 locations at a time with 5 tasks per location. So you can only work on 10 at any given time, which is a pain in the ass, because later tasks have some overlap with earlier ones, where you could've killed 2 birds with 1 stone. They've also reduced the number of skins you get with each Pass from 4 + 4 re-colors, to 2 + 2 re-colors with 2 more and their re-colors purchasable in chests.

Finally, they had added Bounty Points, which you earned from doing your 3 daily quests and could use to buy whichever skin was currently available in the store tab. You could also go to the Bounty Store Market and sell ones you didn't want to other players for Bounty Points or buy a skin from another player. Now, pretty much all of that has been removed in lieu of a few arbitrary skins they offer, 1 of which can ONLY be purchased if you purchased the current Battle Pass. And Bounty Points can no longer be earned from quests, or in game AT ALL. You have to go watch Twitch streamers for 4hr blocks in exchange for "drops."

All of this garbage development combined with the fact that they removed one of the most satisfying mechanics in the game (The Top Play, which would show a replay of one of the best play of the match, measured by number of enemies killed within a few seconds,) and I've lost nearly everything I once loved about this game. It was such a great feeling to have a killer play getting a Penta and knowing everyone was gonna have to see it replayed after the match was over. Now, you just join a game and hope some sackless simp doesn't choose one of the OP champions and ruin the match. I used to highly recommend this game, but now, I urge you to steer clear. It's become as hollow and unsatisfying as the myriad others like it.

For a free to play title I think that this game handles its model very well, paying for cosmetics and the ability to have every character in the game is not too bad in my opinion but I do have a few issues with the game that I do want to talk about. 
The time that it takes to earn enough coins to buy a new legend is high and it does take a while to earn enough to actually but a new character. The only time that it feels like you get coins at a decent rate is when there is a double coin/XP weekend but when that isnt the case I feel that trying to get all of the characters without having to pay for them is going to take a while and for me, it does seem like there isnt enough characters on each weekly rotation (You do get quite a few characters by default for free without the rotation characters but i just thought I would point it out.)

Honestly if you want a game that you will enjoy playing for a while and you don't want to spend money, get this game. There is legit nothing to lose, the game is free and I think that you would get a good amount of fun out of this game.

For people who enjoy Overwatch will also enjoy this game, having played both of them here are some features done better in paladins:
-you can customise your character and gun (from different sets) 
-a nice voice system to be able to say the enemy is behind 
-you can choose which game modes you wish to play
-a better HUD so you can see who has Ult coming up without having to "TAB"
- a better cluster of play styles ( most champs have a common link with a gun e.g smg, assaut rifile etc.
- better explanation of what the weapons do ( paladins actually gives dmg/sec , range etc)
-being able to ban champions in competitive

Despite the game seeming relatively stable and, most of all, fun, you will find that playing Paladins is not an experience that can last very long.

It all probably has to do with the very beginning of its development: Paladins was doomed from the start. Bad decisions and negligence are present to this day, lying in the pile of spaghetti code that, although somewhat stabilized by latter patches, still manage to surface from time to time, giving you each time new wonders to behold in all kinds of visual and gameplay bugs and glitches. (It often occurs that, although patch notes say something was fixed, it obviously wasn't.)

It is all too bad, because the gameplay can be extremely fun at times, especially with friends (which is what kept me playing for so long), but ocasionally, the development team will attempt to "experiment" with objectively moronic and uncalled-for balance changes, only to remove them a patch later. (It really seems like they do this just to savor the tears of the playerbase.)

Despite you maybe giving it a chance to try it out, it is worth noting that the game itself might not give you a chance in return. Paladins' optimization is quite trash (spaghetti code, remember?) and a budget PC will certainly not be able to compensate for this lack of performance on part of the game. I don't care about Overwatch because i never got into it. However, many computers that can't run Paladins well can, actually, run Overwatch very well.

Worth mentioning: Hi-Rez is, generally, quite prone to failure, as a whole. When they launched the game on Epic Games, they screwed up their damn account data base, and now it's impossible for me to log in with my steam account. Yes, i had quite a few bucks worth of cosmetics in the game. The problem is, their customer support screwed me over, and answered my support ticket after 2 weeks (not kidding), only to literally give up on their customer later on. Now that's professionalism.

All in all, if you're looking to take it up: BE ADVISED! :)

I won't say this game is a knock off of overwatch, this game instead is inspired by overwatch. In paladins there is a lot of champions which you can unlock with either gold or diamonds, each one has special attacks. There is 3 modes in this game, deathmatch, siege and capture, deathmatch is well...your typical cod deathmatch, so it's a great mode for players who love killing enemies but doesn't want to capture anything, but it can get boring in a while, siege is capturing a point and after you capture the point, you need to move the payload, and the enemies will try to kill you to avoid moving the payload, you have to move the payload in 3 Minutes or you will lose, first team to get to 3 points wins, capture is capturing a point, but instead you have to capture it till you get it 400 points, just like your typical cod domination, but it's only 1 point.
This game's art style is pretty colorful and cartoon looking, it's a really great art style.
This game is optimized for low end hardware which is a great thing, I play this game at 768p max settings and it runs really well, this game is also optimized for slow internet (but not THAT slow).
Grinding for champions doesn't really take that long, ofc if you have money you can unlock the champion instantly, but champions doesn't a lot of gold so that's a big ups for people who don't to spend money on this game.
This game is really fun and matches can take a while, matchmaking can take a bit too long but the average for me is 1 minute, I say get this game, it's really great and it also has crossplay, so you can play with your friend on a different platform, and hey, it's free! So if you don't like it you can uninstall it  ¯\_(ツ)_/¯

[Paladins is a game that once was a passion project that you can tell had a lot of love and effort poured into it, but sadly it doesn't seem that the developers care very much about the gameplay, bugs, glitches, or instability anymore. Rather, they prefer to constantly push out cosmetic events for some quick cash every 2-3 months instead of addressing the issues that have been plaguing the game for a year or more that the community have been consistently vocal in bringing to the devs attention. If you want to play a game by a company that pushes their project out of beta prematurely so that they can generate revenue from it being on console platforms; devs that celebrate the banning of hundreds of players that had no previous reports against them because they went through direct messages and deemed some players too inappropriate to play their game without a week-long timeout; a company that will ignore and block influential community creators that critique their bad creative and business practices; has had more than their fair share of shady, internal politics, then Paladins is the game for you.]

If you want to sink money into a game that only offers meaningless cosmetics and tragically inconsistent gameplay then install Paladins ASAP. If you want a multiplayer game that offers more than this, you should probably keep browsing.


(A small bit of info about me if you wish to have some perspective on where my review comes from.)
I started playing Paladins I believe in May 2017 while it was still well entrenched in beta, I saw the game go through crashes and resurrections of updates that would tank and then revive the player count, I stuck to a fairly consistent play style that allowed me to see the changes in the game around me more than I changed with the game. Sometimes patches were kind to me, sometimes they nerfed things I relied upon, but I only ever took one real break from Paladins for around 6 months and played consistently for the rest of the time. I bounced between this and Dead by Daylight which also went through some balance updates that would destroy and surge player counts, so I ping-ponged between the games when "bad" patches came through. The events that finally led me to permanently uninstall Paladins were several moves by Hi-Rez that just disrespected the small community that propped their game up, and I don't like supporting ingrates. I won't be installing Paladins again, and if you don't believe me, you can look at my Brawlhalla review for my track record.

Re-submitting this since I've had more time to properly gather my thoughts on this.
This game really is a sad example of what happens when you try to jump on the bandwagon rather than coming up with your own ideas.

The characters, while often stealing their kits from other games (namely Overwatch and League of Legends) do have interesting designs but often don't get enough love from the devs to fully realize their full potential.  In addition, while the game tries to combine mechanics from both of the previously mentioned titles, it leans too heavily on their inspiration and ends up coming off as a cheep knockoff as a result.

I should have added this in when I first put out this review, but I was pressed for time at the time, but there is two more issues that desperately needs to be addressed.  The first is balance which is basically non-existent.  Several character (Dredge, Ash and Zin in particular) are able to dish out extreme amounts of damage, giving any team who has one of them a massive advantage and any team who all of them a surefire win).  This imbalance is a serious problem and one that needs to be worked out.

The second issue is the community. It is hands down one of the worst gaming communities I have ever been a part of, somehow managing to beat out both League of Legends and Overwatch in sheer toxicity.  A large portion of the community is made up of kids, griefers, cheaters, and throwers.  False reports are thrown out almost every game due to players not understanding how this genre of game works and the few truthful reports that are filed are constantly ignored by the moderation team (if there even is one).

Paladins was a game I loved. Back in the good ol days of 2018 even 2019 it shined of potential. I got many of my friends into it and I made many more in it, I climbed the ranks and held top 100 on multiple accounts, but to what end? Paladins at it's core is not a good game, it is a game that shows a lot of potential, but all of that has pretty much withered away. HIREZ has turned paladins into a cow that is being milked at every opportunity: CHECK OUT THESE NEW SKINS, ARE THESE LEWD SKINS BUY OUR NEW BATTLEPASS TO FIND OUT. But what this used cow that is paladins need is bug fixes, balancing and server care. There has always been issues like these in paladins, but at this moment they are more profound than any other time, what HIREZ need to do is to take a copy from the books of ubisoft and have their own version of "operation health" and not add any new content but focus hard on repairing their game. But sadly HIREZ is a company that does not care about their games, only making money, on multiple occasions I have personally sent in reports of players staying afk in spawn flaming my team with video evidence, aswell as their match history where they obviously throw multiple games and what I get 2 weeks later is a respone that it will be looked into (sad to say but most of these players kept on playing daily, since I'm a pityfull person I checked). But from what I said it may sound like it is difficult to get people banned, lol nah fam all you need to do is to spam report someone, 20 reports in a week will get your account suspended. If you are a new player I would highly advice you to stay clear of Paladins, and to not listen to the people with 20 hours on the gaming ZOOMING going good game man. 

TL:DR 
HIREZ PEEPEEPOOPOO COMPANY, their game development team and support makes me want to bash my head in with a rock. Paladins is terrible game, and has always been. The potential is gone and all you are left with is jewish moneygrabbing company that milks it for the last drops.
DO NOT GET THIS GAME.

Paladins provides various characters, called Champions, for the players to choose during their gaming sessions. Each of these Champions falls into one of the following categories: Front Line, Damage, Support, and Flank. Being a team-based shooter, players must rely on strategy, character knowledge, coordination, and teamwork in order to attain victory. Players may use VGS, along with text and voice chat to communicate. A good team will have a balanced choice of classes that will support each other during the game.
